fields.headline: Funhouse
fields.trailText:
Citizens Theatre, Glasgow
Rating: ***
fields.body:
"Welcome to the Freak Show" is a refrain in the Funhouse: a claustrophobically small, dark room in which Eric Bogosian's furious series of monologues plays out. The flipside of the American Dream, the dark underbelly of post-Vietnam masculinity, the outcasts and the repugnant insiders all around us: Bogosian is savage on the state we are in.

Or were in, in the early 1980s, when this was first performed. Then it must have been scorchingly revealing, exposing a desperate crisis in manhood, a dog-eat-dog culture in which the ordinary man can only flail around, or be brutalised into action. Now it only reminds us what we already know from Goodfellas, Louis Theroux interviews, Jerky Boys spoofs, and just about every NYPD Blue plot.

As social commentary, then, this is well-trodden, if still vicious, ground. What saves it is Kenny Miller's design and direction, squeezing the horror off of the page. Dollar bills coat every wall; there is too much of everything (a swarm of small black lights on the ceiling are like flies); the small space at once evokes the sleaziest bar, the scuzziest house, the filthiest gutter.

Stephen Scott is also close to faultless. He plays a dozen or so male characters: everything from TV evangelist Reverend Tim ("you can say it's not my fault when you see a beggar because you've sent me 18 bucks") to an S&M black rubber fiend, slinking about like an unspoken threat, via a fitness instructor, an insurance salesman, a beggar, a guy on death row who berates us woolly liberals, and a CIA agent on how to best do torture.

When the play begins, Scott is covered head to toe in sleek rubber; by the end he is almost naked. Peeling away layers of this constricting second skin mirrors what the writing is trying to do - reveal what we prefer to ignore. A bit like watching Iggy Pop these days (Funhouse is taken from a Stooges album title), we have seen this all before and it would have been better to have done so when it was fresh and radical. Even so, like Iggy Pop, the Funhouse still pulls us in: the Freak Show remains a draw, if only for its extremity.

Until 14 October. Box office: 0141-429 0022.

fields.headline: Tailgunner
fields.trailText:
Sheffield Casbah
Rating: ***
fields.body:
Following Nirvana producer Butch Vig's Garbage, Tailgunner are the latest rock band formed by a production wizard. In case you didn't know, Mark Coyle twiddled the knobs on Oasis' Definitely Maybe and was usually found mixing their live sound. The connection with the Gallaghers doesn't end there: until recently, Noel Gallagher was Tailgunner's drummer (he rolls with it on their album, released in three weeks), but he left under a ball of confusion bigger than any surrounding Oasis. "He [Coyle] sacked me!" Gallagher moaned recently. "I would never sack him. You don't sack Noel Gallagher," retorted Coyle (although on the evidence of the album, the nation's sticksmen shouldn't fear for their jobs).

Whatever the truth, Tailgunner still have the smell of brute Gallagher splashed all over them. Most intriguingly, Coyle (modelling Oasis' pre-fame, suedehead look) has inherited not only Noel's eyebrows, but his habit of moving them up and down his forehead as he sings.

Looking like a bunch of unreconstituted football hooligans, Tailgunner are unfeasibly loud. After mixing Oasis, Coyle's hearing may well require medical attention, but there's something refreshing about his four-piece's unapologetic row. It's a bizarre irony that nowadays successful people are allowed the luxury of producing music this raw (see also Johnny Marr), while the ambitious street kids who once spawned rock's rage are moulded by the business into cultural impotence.

Tailgunner's spewed swamp riffs and razor chords are the closest thing this side of Neil Young's Crazy Horse to rock music as it was meant to be played. However, their songwriting has yet to match the sound. Like Noel, Coyle is not averse to "borrowing" large chunks of rock culture, but where the Oasis man can metamorphose a well-worn riff into something new, Coyle sometimes struggles with retreads. On the Tailgunner album, Slade's classic How Does it Feel is disguised as their own song. Live, Coming Back Home struggles to be more than Coyle singing Bowie's Quicksand over an Oasis anthem. The fearsome Zeppelin stomps of Undercover and Blow Up display riffs the size of Knebworth, but Tailgunner need a few more like that if they're to progress beyond being a noisy Oasis-related curio.

Tailgunner play the Square, Harlow (01279 305000), tomorrow, then tour.

webTitle: Leak points to US approval for Time Warner/AOL deal

fields.headline: Leak points to US approval for Time Warner/AOL deal
fields.standfirst:
Special report: Time Warner/AOL merger
Net news
Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: American regulators seem likely to give the green light to Time Warner's $350bn merger with AOL, brushing aside objections from competitors such as Walt Disney.
fields.body:
American regulators seem likely to give the green light to Time Warner's $350bn merger with AOL, brushing aside objections from competitors such as Walt Disney.

The news will come as a boost to the two media companies, which are getting a much rougher ride from the European commission.

A leaked document from the US federal communications commission, which is scrutinising the deal's competition implications, has revealed a draft recommendation for the tie-up to go ahead.

The only condition is that the groups make legally binding their promise to open up their cable television networks to other internet access providers.

It is expected that accessing the internet through televisions will become much more common over the next few years. Regulators are keen to ensure that cable television companies do not act as "gate keepers", preventing other access providers from reaching customers.

Insiders cautioned that the document was merely an "early snapshot" of the FCC's view, and more serious sanctions remained possible.

An FCC spokeswoman said: "We are still at the preliminary stages of analysing this merger."

Walt Disney has been among the opponents of the deal - it is worried that the merged company would have greater power over the distribution of its programming on cable television networks. The deal is the biggest in American corporate history - it will create the world's fourth largest company with 100m subscribers.

Time Warner and AOL are now likely to concentrate on putting their case to the European commission - which has indicated that it will block the deal without significant concessions being made.

The commission is concerned that the combined company would dominate music publishing - particularly because of its joint venture with EMI.

There is also anxiety in Europe about AOL's alliance with the German group Bertelsmann in Europe and Australia. EMI said yesterday that it had offered sufficient concessions to satisfy the commission. It is believed to have agreed to dispose of four publishing catalogues and record labels in France, Denmark, Greece and Spain.

An EMI spokesman said the company's pledges addressed concerns "without materially harming the viability of the deal or removing the commercial rationale".

webTitle: Poor start at the Young Vic

fields.headline: Poor start at the Young Vic
fields.trailText:
Julius Caesar
Young Vic, London
Rating: *
fields.body:
David Lan starts his tenure of the Young Vic with a spectacular duck. But he need not despair. Peter Hall and Trevor Nunn began at the Royal Shakespeare Company and the National Theatre with dreadful productions. Julius Caesar is a play that defeats most directors. And there are promising things to come in Lan's opening season, including shows from Peter Brook and Richard Jones.

Lan sees Julius Caesar as a "hideous dream": a nightmarish study of momentous events. Thus he starts with a chain of fragmented images. The ritual application of war-paint; bare-bottomed guys under a shower; a spotlit figure in an upper chamber. But the evening is half over before we begin to understand the significance of this prefatory montage. That the painted icon is Caesar himself; that the showering nudes are the conspirators cleansing themselves of blood; and that the upper area is a place reserved for dreams, prophecies and ghostly apparitions.

It is true that Julius Caesar is a play filled with portents, exhalations and Macbeth-like nocturnal fears. But it is also a study of political action and character, and it is here that Lan's production is found cruelly wanting. Neither in Stephen Brimson Lewis's set, with its central tilted ramp and water-surrounded duckboards, nor in the pick'n'mix costumes is there any suggestion of a particular society or period of time. As a result it becomes impossible to tell whether Dorian Healy's besuited Caesar is a benign ruler or potential despot deserving retribution.

Language and character are constantly subordinated to atmosphere: speeches are chopped up, frenzied music intrudes at odd moments and during the conspirators' night-meeting we are distracted by a writhing figure who turns out to be the dreaming Calpurnia. Political motivation is also replaced by behaviourist detail. Marcus D'Amico's Cassius is simply a preening posturer who buffs his nails while trying to tempt Brutus into murder. And Robert Cavanah's Mark Antony slobbers over Caesar's corpse, lying incidentally in a pool of water, suggesting he is more ardent necrophile than manipulative rhetorician.

Only one performance transcends the miasmic muddle. Lloyd Owen as Brutus reveals an incisive voice and presence and brings out the character's priggish self-regard; not only is he wrong in every single tactical decision he makes but in saying "why I that did love Caesar when I struck him" he displays a nauseating hypocrisy. Some see Brutus as an embryo Hamlet: Owen brings out his poker-backed vanity. And he is alone in bringing sharpness and definition to a production that fails to tell the story clearly and that butchers Shakespeare's scenic and verbal rhythms to create a Roman nightmare.

Until October 28. Box office: 020-7928 6363.

webTitle: US watchdog hunts down day trader, 15

fields.headline: US watchdog hunts down day trader, 15
fields.standfirst:
Money Unlimited
Net news
Special report: e-finance
fields.trailText: A 15-year-old American schoolboy has been accused of making $285,000 (£202,000) by manipulating internet chatrooms in order to "pump and dump" shares.
fields.body:
A 15-year-old American schoolboy has been accused of making $285,000 (£202,000) by manipulating internet chatrooms in order to "pump and dump" shares.

Jonathan Lebed, of New Jersey, has agreed to surrender the money to the securities and exchange commission, after becoming the youngest person ever to be accused of breaking share dealing rules.

The SEC discovered that at least 11 times, Lebed bought shares in obscure, thinly traded companies, and within hours sent "numerous false and/or misleading unsolicited email messages touting the stock he just purchased".

After watching the prices rise, he rapidly sold his shares, pocketing the proceeds.

Described by his lawyer as "a normal teenager who likes sport, music and hanging out with his friends", Lebed learned about the market by watching business television channels. He settled with the regulator without admitting to any wrongdoing.

His father defended him, describing him as "a good kid", and pointing out that hundreds of thousands of day traders were doing the same thing: "So they pick on a kid."

The case raised fresh concerns about the power of the internet in affecting share prices. However, there was sympathy from his fellow traders. On one of Lebed's favourite sites, Silicon Investor, a trader named Carl remarked: "He seemed more mature than the majority of people I see on here."

Another, Jim S, remembered getting into "childish" arguments with Lebed but attributed this to "the general immaturity of a lot of other investors", adding: "They only made him pay on 11 of 27 possible counts. That leaves 16, and probably a lot of dough left in his coffers."

Lebed's chosen investments were generally unknown names such as Man Sang Holdings, Just Toys, Football USA and West Coast Entertainment.

The SEC was alerted to his activities because his trades often accounted for a third or half of the daily volume in these stocks.

There was sympathy from one anonymous day trader, who sent a message declaring: "The kid who rigged the penny stocks should by given an honorary degree at Harvard.

"The guilty people are the brokers who dealt with a minor - not to mention the people who believed everything he said."

webTitle: Covent Garden's opera for the hard-of-hearing

fields.headline: Covent Garden's opera for the hard-of-hearing
fields.trailText:
Billy Budd
Royal Opera House, London
Rating:****
fields.body:
In its revival of Francesca Zambello's production of Britten's Billy Budd, the Royal Opera House has assembled a world-class trio of singers in the opera's three main roles. The relationships between Simon Keenlyside's press-ganged sailor Billy Budd, Kim Begley's Captain Vere, and Eric Halfvarson's master-at-arms Claggart, are the emotional and dramatic core of Britten's investigation of innocence, corruption and redemption on board the warship Indomitable in 1797.

Halfvarson has a magnificently malevolent presence from his very first entrance. The laser-sharp focus and intensity of his voice carries Claggart inexorably to the climactic moment of his murder at the hands of the doomed, stammering Billy. Halfvarson's performance makes Claggart's essential evil stem from a virulent self-loathing. His Claggart manipulates the crew with inescapable force.

This interpretation is the antithesis of Keenlyside's Billy Budd. The rounded tone of Keenlyside's voice and his natural athleticism show Billy's extroversion and simple-minded goodness; he is both vulnerable and strong-willed. During the first act, Keenlyside turns Billy into a holy fool - a well-loved member of the crew, incapable of believing that anyone could bear him malice.

Claggart's first act solo demonstrates the depths of his appalling desire for Billy's death. But Halfvarson creates a Claggart who is more than a cipher for evil. The passion of his performance allows a glimpse of Claggart's depraved humanity; he reveals the roots of Claggart's wrong-doing in an acceptance of a chillingly ineluctable fate - his accidental death at the hands of Billy. And Billy becomes self-aware through a similar acknowledgement of his inevitable hanging in his final solo scene.

Caught between Billy and Claggart is Kim Begley's Vere. Begley captures both Vere's reflective intelligence, and his tortured agonising between his feelings for Billy and his duty as a captain. And the whole opera is about a negotiation between private emotions and social responsibility. The success of this production is the way it seamlessly moves from the individual worlds of Billy, Claggart and Vere to the public domain of the crew. Alison Chitty's sets elegantly link Vere's lonely authority with the lusty community of Britten's sailors, among whom Alan Opie's po-faced pedant Mr Redburn and Stephen Richardson's Mr Flint are especially memorable.

But perhaps the most important character in the work is the sea, represented in Britten's rich orchestration. Richard Hickox and the Royal Opera Orchestra play the score with symphonic scale and breadth, embodying the elemental power of the opera's emotional and natural forces, and binding together the human confusions at the heart of the story. Sadly there was also needless, non-human confusion in the form of the Opera House's decision to provide surtitles - an insult to the cast's faultless enunciation of EM Forster's libretto.

Until October 3. Box office: 020-7304 4000.

fields.headline: Warming to incubators
fields.standfirst:
Net news
Money Unlimited
Special report: e-finance
fields.trailText: Incubators - companies that invest in and provide operational support to early stage internet and technology companies - have been out of favour with investors since the dot.com shake-out in the spring.
fields.body:
Incubators - companies that invest in and provide operational support to early stage internet and technology companies - have been out of favour with investors since the dot.com shake-out in the spring.

But Schroder Salomon Smith Barney says there is growing evidence that successful incubators can be expected to give investors the high returns that successful start-ups offer.

In Wild Wild West, a glossy, 154-page report published yesterday, SSSB picked out NewMedia Spark, down 2.5p to 64.5p, Brainspark, off 6p at 94.5p, and Inflexion, up 3p to 87.5p, as its favoured plays.

In the absence of revenue or meaningful revenue streams, SSSB says, investors should be judging incubators by what it calls "valuation events" - external private funding rounds, initial public offerings or trade sales of portfolio companies.

fields.headline: Rambert's world premiere
fields.trailText:
Rambert Dance Company
Lowry, Salford
Rating: ****
fields.body:
Making their first appearance at the Lowry, the UK's best-known contemporary dance company offered a mixed bill that included a world premiere of 7DS. Choreographed by Didy Veldman (whose Carmen for the Northen Ballet Theatre toured earlier this year), 7DS - seven deadly sins - opens with a solitary female dancer standing in Edenic pastures, with the forbidden fruit balanced on her head. She is joined by four other women, each sporting a blackcurrant-coloured wig cut in a fashionable bob. Add vivid streetwise slacks and dresses, all glamorous practicality, and the dancers could be from the latest Gap advert; that trendy, clinically modern feel is emphasised by a stage bordered on three sides by tall blinds. These allow a disturbance of shadows, a play of disembodied hands, and moments of voyeurism as the dancers take turns to peep at the others cavorting through their sins.

To a soundtrack of electronic music, samples from Master of the Universe, giggles, sighs and belches, the women indulge themselves in pleasure; their fast, sharp movements give way to a langorously striding delight and then a violent, pacing anger of truncated gestures. There is much posture and play, and humour when they gorge themselves. When the sexual stakes are raised, skirts are hitched, tops lifted over heads, a finger is sucked - in innocence or licentiousness? fields.headline: Keown's late double-take rescues Arsenal
fields.standfirst: Wiltord 45, Keown 85, 90 | Bakharev 26, Vorobey 29
fields.trailText: Arsenal found an unlikely goalscoring saviour last night when Martin Keown scored twice in the last six minutes, the second in injury-time, to complete a comeback from two goals down to beat Shakhtar Donetsk.
fields.body:
Arsenal found an unlikely goalscoring saviour last night when Martin Keown scored twice in the last six minutes, the second in injury-time, to complete a comeback from two goals down to beat Shakhtar Donetsk.

There had been a sense of expectation among the Arsenal fans, not only because they felt Shakhtar would be easily defeated but also because this was the first Champions League match played at Highbury after two unsuccessful seasons at Wembley.

The 1-0 win in Prague last week had put the Gunners in a strong position to progress beyond the first group stage and with their players said to be on a £9,000-a-man win bonus per match in this competition they had every incentive to go for the jugular immediately against a Shakhtar team beaten 3-0 by Lazio in Ukraine last week.

They began impressively, looking too powerful and pacy for a team who had battled through two qualifying rounds to reach this stage for the first time. Thierry Henry had the ball in the net inside three minutes only to be flagged offside, harshly replays suggested, as he burst on to Nwanwko Kanu's pass.

With Patrick Vieira winning tackles and spraying passes from midfield, and Kanu teasing with his skills in attack, it was virtual one-way traffic. Yuri Virt did well to save at his near post when Kanu shot from a tight angle and then he stopped an Henry effort.

It was a sign of the task facing a young Shakhtar team, five of whose players were 23 or under, that their experienced captain Sergei Popov was booked for a late, groin-high challenge on Vieira.

Robert Pires should have given Arsenal the lead in the 13th minute. Arsène Wenger expects his summer signing to get 10 goals a season, as he has in France for the past five years, and this was a fine opportunity for his first. But, played through by Henry's cute pass, he could only hit the goalkeeper's legs and if there was a danger to Arsenal it seemed to lie in poor finishing, a problem all season, or complacency.

Hennadei Zubov offered a warning against the latter, volleying wide after Keown and Silvinho had dithered, but Arsenal were soon back on the offensive. At times they slalomed or jinked past opponents as if they barely existed, and when Vieira fed the shaven-headed Fredrik Ljungberg, Virt had to be quick to block the shot.

Shakhtar hail from the mining region of eastern Ukraine and Virt could have done with a hard hat as the shots rained in. Not long after Kanu had sent an effort wide, Henry rattled the bar with a free-kick from 25 yards before the game turned amazingly as Shakhtar scored twice inside four minutes just before the half-hour.

The first had a huge element of fortune. David Seaman seemed to have Alexei Bakharev's free-kick covered but the ball took a big deflection off Pires and flew into the opposite corner to the delight of the small but noisy pocket of orange-clad visiting fans.

Barely had that claxon-hooting bunch got over the first goal when the second arrived. Sergei Atelkin sent a clever reverse pass between Keown and Oleg Luzhny, playing in place of the injured Tony Adams, and the 21-year-old Ukraine striker Andrei Vorobey neatly shot across Seaman and into the corner for his 11th goal of the season.

Suddenly Shakhtar found a new determination and were a threat on the counter-attack as Arsenal took time to find their rhythm again. But the game turned their way just before half-time.

First Popov was dismissed after a second booking for checking Vieira as the midfielder tried to burst through on goal. And then Arsenal were awarded a penalty when Sylvain Wiltord, a substitute for Pires, was clattered by Mykhaylo Starostyak as he tried to reach a cross by Dixon. Henry's spot-kick was saved but Wiltord put in the rebound.

Arsenal's worried supporters must have expected their team to begin the second half with a welter of attacks. And after briefly struggling as Shakhtar put up to 10 men behind the ball, the chances began to arrive.

A brilliant display of close control by Kanu which took him past three players ended with a low shot that fizzed just wide of the far post. Then Henry had an effort saved be fore meeting Silvinho's powerful left-wing cross and sending a back-flick narrowly wide.

The Frenchman's aim was no better when he met a Wiltord centre at the near post and flicked it wide of the far one when he might have done better. Barely had Virt recovered from that when he was flinging himself to block from Wiltord.

As the levels of frustration at Highbury rose, and with Shakhtar defending in numbers, the introduction of Dennis Bergkamp brought the number of Arsenal strikers to four and represented a last throw of the dice.

It seemed Arsenal would pay for several missed chances against a Donetsk side reduced to 10 men just before half-time. But with time running out, Keown first chested in a corner by Bergkamp and then scored from close range from a Kanu cross. Embarrassment avoided then, but only just.

Arsenal (4-4-2): Seaman; Dixon, Luzhny, Keown, Silvinho; Ljungberg (Bergkamp, 66min), Grimandi, Vieira, Pires (Wiltord, 34); Kanu, Henry.

Shakhtar Donetsk (4-4-2): Virt; Starostyak, Popov, Gleveckas, Shevchuk; Zubov, Tymoschuk, Bakharev (Bielik, 70), Abramov (Kryventsov, 58); Vorobey, Atelkin (Kovalov, 77).

Referee: H Strampe (Germany).

fields.headline: Rangers survive Monaco siege
fields.standfirst: Van Bronckhorst 8
fields.trailText: Rangers took a commanding lead in their group after a mature display that suggested this may be the year they provide a serious threat in the Europe's premier club competition.
fields.body:
The recent evidence that Rangers, under Dick Advocaat, may at last be ready to pose a threat in the Champions League suffered no damage from this latest outing. Rangers imposed themselves in the principality last night with a buoyant first half and some stuffy defending after the break, which took them to six points from their opening two games and a commanding lead at the top of Group D.

The maturity of Rangers' play was astonishing. In the opening half, after Giovanni van Bronckhorst had given them the early lead, they broke Monaco's will with astute possession football.

After the interval, admittedly, Monaco and Marco Simone in particular were fired into life, but Stefan Klos remained unflappable while missiles rained down on him.

All this unfolded inside one of European football's ultimate architectural indulgences. The 3,000 Rangers supporters who descended on the Stade Louis II might have felt like time-travellers as, beneath the arena's tall, imperial columns, the normal Monegasque calm was shattered by bawdy Glaswegian chanting.

Advocaat came to Monaco and gambled. The most adept striker on Rangers' books, Michael Mols, has been out for a year with injury and still suffers swelling around his right knee whenever he plays.

He does, however, possess the knack of being able to guard the ball at his feet despite no end of defensive buffeting, a quality that enhances any team's prospects in the Champions League. Advocaat succumbed and threw Mols in.

The other surprise was his decision to play Kerimoglu Tugay, normally a midfielder, as Rangers' sweeper. Tugay has failed to shine at Ibrox since Graeme Souness negotiated his path from Galatasaray, but in recent games he has increasingly shown glimpses of his cleverness. Last night, confronting Monaco's Shabani Nonda and Marco Simone, Tugay excelled in his unfamiliar role.

Nonetheless, Advocaat's wildest hopes could hardly have envisaged the start his team grabbed here.

From the opening there was something bright and eager about Rangers' approach, and after seven minutes they achieved the equivalent of punching Monaco in the gut. Van Bronckhorst was 25 yards out when his lashing left-foot shot rose barely two feet off the ground, snaking a venomous trail past a startled Stephane Porato's left post.

Not suprisingly, the goal injected some urgency into Monaco. But they did not truly threaten Klos's goal until the 41st minute, when Martin Djetou's deflected shot flew dangerously wide of the upright.

Rangers, though, and Lorenzo Amoruso in particular, could be grateful for not having conceded a penalty six minutes earlier, when the Italian clearly and recklessly upended Nonda in the box.

After the break, the game unwound with a raging energy. By the law of football Rangers, having crafted their first-half lead, faced an inexorable Monaco onslaught. But Klos stood firm, bravely blocking Rafael Marquez's shot from eight yards as the visitors started to impose themselves, and the rugged Amoruso also remained resolute against Nonda's surging runs.

Mols, inevitably, did not last the match. The Dutch striker hobbled away after 57 minutes and was replaced by Neil McCann, a player bought by Advocaat in a rare and heartfelt appreciation of Scottish talent.

McCann, however, had little say in the remainder of this game, which was dominated by Simone's twisting, tormenting runs and the avalanche of attacks sweeping down on Klos's goal.

As Monaco grew increasingly desperate, the match threatened to take on an ugly complexion. When Ian Ferguson was harshly chopped down by Ludo Giuly, Rangers prodded the ball out of play, whereupon Monaco refused to give the ball back and swept up the field. It took Simone, moments later at the corner flag in a show of fair play, to give the visitors back possession.

Monaco (4-3-3): Porato; Irles, Rodriguez, Marquez, Abidal; Bonnal, Djetou, Riise; Nonda, Giuly, Simone.

Rangers (3-4-3): Klos; Konterman, Tugay, Amoruso; Reyna, Ferguson, Van Bronkchorst, Numan; Johnston, Mols, De Boer.

Referee: A Ouzounov (Bulgaria).

webTitle: Darling hails milestone in reduction of child poverty

fields.headline: Darling hails milestone in reduction of child poverty
fields.trailText: The government will today claim to have passed a milestone in the reduction of child poverty with figures showing a sharp drop in the number of children who are victims of adult unemployment.
fields.body:
The government will today claim to have passed a milestone in the reduction of child poverty with figures showing a sharp drop in the number of children who are victims of adult unemployment.

Alistair Darling, the social security secretary, will seek to distract attention from evidence of increased pensioner poverty by announcing that the number of children in homes where nobody is in work has fallen by more than 250,000 since the general election.

His department's annual audit of poverty and social exclusion will show that the proportion of children in homes with no working adults was 17.9% in 1997 - more than double the figure for France, Germany and Italy. But by this spring, the UK figure had fallen to 15.8%. Most of the fall came in the last 12 months.

"This means that over a quarter of a million children are now benefiting from improvements in family living standards that a job brings," Mr Darling will say.

He will attribute the change to the strength of the economy, introduction of the working families tax credit and other measures making it more worthwhile for parents to seek employment.

But the figures show the government still has a mountain to climb to achieve its objective of lifting 1.2m children out of poverty by the election, as a step towards eradicating child poverty within 20 years.

Martin Barnes, director of the Child Poverty Action Group, said the fall in numbers of children in workless households was welcome, but not surprising. "If they could not achieve an improvement on that measure, given the strength of the economy and the pattern of falling unemployment, things would be pretty bad. They are still some way off showing they can deliver their pledges," he said.

The report will show that the number of pensioners living in poverty rose by 100,000 between 1996-97 and 1998-99. The proportion in households with incomes below half the national average rose from 22% to 23% in Labour's first year in office and remained steady in the next 12 months.

Mr Darling said the figures were taken before introduction of the enhanced minimum income guarantee for pensioners in April 1999. This was already helping 1.6m pensioner households by raising their income above the poverty threshold. And a recent campaign to encourage pensioners to claim the benefits to which they are entitled attracted 385,000 responses.

"These figures highlight the scale of the problem inherited by this government that took years to build up and will take some time to turn around. They explain why the government has made tackling pensioner poverty its first priority," Mr Darling said.

Under the minimum income guarantee, a single pensioner aged between 60 and 74 with a state pension of £67.50 a week gets his or her income increased to £78.45. For those aged 75 to 79 the level rises to £80.85 and over 80 it is £86.05.

Pensioner couples, receiving a weekly pension of £107.90, have their incomes raised to £121.95 (60-74); £125.35 (75-79); and £131.05 (80-plus).

Help the Aged said the policy of targeting state benefits to the poorest was not working. Older people believed they had earned the right to a decent basic pension and felt stigmatised by benefits. "The very poorest pensioners are always the least likely to claim the benefits they are entitled to and fall through the safety net," said Tessa Harding, the charity's head of policy.

webTitle: Viennese waltz for Foxes after Uefa rejects Red Star appeal

fields.headline: Viennese waltz for Foxes after Uefa rejects Red Star appeal
fields.trailText: Leicester City will play the second leg of their first-round tie against Red Star Belgrade not in troubled Yugoslavia but in Vienna.
fields.body:
Leicester City's chances of prolonging their interest in the Uefa Cup improved markedly yesterday when they were told they would play the second leg of their first-round tie against Red Star Belgrade not in troubled Yugoslavia but in Vienna.

After more than 48 hours of negotiation, debate, argument and rancour, Uefa announced that it had dismissed Red Star's appeal against the deci sion to move the game away from Belgrade because the safety of Leicester's staff and supporters could not be guaranteed at a time of political and social unrest.

The game will now be staged next Thursday night at the home of Rapid Vienna, leaving the Leicester hierarchy - and the club's travel agents - with the complex logistical problems of organising, at very short notice, flights and accommodation for the official party and for those supporters who want to see their team try to build upon the 1-1 draw achieved in the first leg at Filbert Street last week.

Red Star, now known as Crvena Zvezda, had nominated the Macedonian capital Skopje - where an assistant referee was threatened by a gunman after a European tie this month - as their favoured venue for the game if, as happened yesterday, Uefa rejected their appeal against the change of venue. Vienna was the second choice.

"To be honest, I don't think that Red Star will be overjoyed with this outcome, but after taking everything into consideration we do believe that Vienna is the right and proper choice of venue," said Mike Lee, Uefa's director of communication.

"That is now the end of the matter. Red Star did not agree with Leicester's initial objection to the game being played in Belgrade but their appeal, after due consideration, was rejected by us."

Leicester's chairman John Elsom was fulsome in his praise of Uefa's handling of the affair. "By moving this game to Vienna, all the concerns which my club's players will have had will have been removed," he said. "We are all very pleased with this outcome and I must thank Uefa for the way this whole matter has been handled."

The club's manager Peter Taylor said: "I am pleased the venue for the game has now been settled. Once Sunday's game is out of the way things will be clear and we can plan for the second leg."

Rapid's Gerhard-Hanappi Stadium holds 19,300. Leicester have been allocated 4,000 tickets and, although they do not expect to sell them all, they are just grateful that they will have some backing in Austria.
fields.bodyText: Leicester City's chances of prolonging their interest in the Uefa Cup improved markedly yesterday when they were told they would play the second leg of their first-round tie against Red Star Belgrade not in troubled Yugoslavia but in Vienna. After more than 48 hours of negotiation, debate, argument and rancour, Uefa announced that it had dismissed Red Star's appeal against the deci sion to move the game away from Belgrade because the safety of Leicester's staff and supporters could not be guaranteed at a time of political and social unrest. The game will now be staged next Thursday night at the home of Rapid Vienna, leaving the Leicester hierarchy - and the club's travel agents - with the complex logistical problems of organising, at very short notice, flights and accommodation for the official party and for those supporters who want to see their team try to build upon the 1-1 draw achieved in the first leg at Filbert Street last week. Vienna was the second choice. "To be honest, I don't think that Red Star will be overjoyed with this outcome, but after taking everything into consideration we do believe that Vienna is the right and proper choice of venue," said Mike Lee, Uefa's director of communication. "That is now the end of the matter. Red Star did not agree with Leicester's initial objection to the game being played in Belgrade but their appeal, after due consideration, was rejected by us." webTitle: Claudio Ranieri knocks Chelsea into shape

fields.headline: Woe betide the Chelsea slackers
fields.standfirst: Claudio Ranieri is bent on stiffening Chelsea's spine.  Jon Brodkin watched him in action on the training ground
fields.trailText: Claudio Ranieri is bent on stiffening Chelsea's spine. Jon Brodkin watched him in action on the training ground
fields.body:
For a man being unveiled as Chelsea's eighth manager in 15 years Claudio Ranieri was remarkably relaxed yesterday. He smiled so often it was easy to imagine he had accepted the job without consulting the Premiership table or noticing his predecessors' heads hanging on the wall of Ken Bates' house.

But then Ranieri's last employer, Jesus Gil of Atletico Madrid, makes Bates look like a man yet to discover the P45. And why worry when you have done stints at Napoli and Fiorentina? "In Italy," Ranieri quipped, "there are eight coaches a season."

The entourage the 48-year-old has brought with him means Chelsea are employing about as many coaches now. Not long after Ranieri had sauntered off the training pitch with his two new assistants clutching cones and a cardboard box it became clear an Italian passport could be one of the few things he shares with the deposed Gianluca Vialli.

The contrast his sharp suit provided with Vialli's schoolboy jumpers was just the start. Whereas Vialli was happy to field a team without a single Englishman, Ranieri believes the title cannot be won without a backbone of English players. Vialli may have changed his side more often than some people change their socks but rotation is not in the new head coach's limited English vocabulary.

"If a player is in good form he will be in the team," Ranieri said, flanked by an interpreter and Chelsea's managing director Colin Hutchinson. "It doesn't seem right to me to drop a player when he is playing well. That is the general idea.

"It is logical that if a team plays the same 11, 12, 13 players they know how to play with each other by memory. If the team changes the players won't be able to find each other with their passes so well."

What Ranieri made of the room he was speaking in, at the training ground that Chelsea share with Imperial College, was anyone's guess. With a dartboard in one corner, a bar offering London Pride shandy for £1.40 and pictures of old rugby teams adorning the walls, it was hardly what he might associate with title pretenders.

A signed Roberto di Matteo shirt was one of the few clues to Chelsea's existence. But of course Ranieri does not pay heed to superficial stuff. Behind the easygoing manner lurks a determined, passionate disciplinarian. To him names and reputations are meaningless, as he showed by casting off Romario at Valencia.

He will demand real commitment and determination from Chelsea, and woe betide any slackers. In the games he watched against St Gallen and Leicester he found spirit and unity lacking. He goes to Old Trafford on Saturday looking at more than the result.

"In terms of quality we are probably not behind Manchester United," he said, "but in the spirit and determination of the team we are. Victory isn't important. I want to see how hard my players will fight.

"I want the fans to be proud of a team that fights until the last minute to achieve victory. I don't look at how famous players' names are. I have said this to all the players from the youth team to the reserves to the first team."

Young English players such as Jon Harley and John Terry could be forgiven for a few London Pride shandies given Ranieri's determination to use local talent. "It is the same in Italy and Spain," he said. "The backbone has to be from the country in which you are playing."

Which is not to suggest Ranieri will be rushing to sign anyone with a St George's cross on their underpants. "I will evaluate very carefully what I have in the squad and what English players there are to be bought," he said. "If there are [good enough] English players at Chelsea I will take them on."

Only three Englishmen - Dennis Wise, who retains the captaincy, Graeme le Saux and Jody Morris - were among the 10-strong group of outfield players Ranieri trained before engaging the whole squad in high-tempo three-a-sides.

The quick, one-touch passing he took them through told of a fast counter-attacking style. Ranieri's awkward shouts of "go", "better", "quality" and "stay here Wisey" explained why Di Matteo was translating and the coach will take English lessons along with his new right-hand men, his assistant Salvatore Antenucci and the goalkeeping coach Giorgio Pellizzano.

Ranieri stressed that Vialli's assistants Ray Wilkins and Graham Rix will be kept on, although "they won't be able to do exactly the same jobs they have been doing". Wilkins will be helping with translation for a start, and although Ranieri is linked with two of his former Atletico players, the Portugal midfielder Hugo Leal and Argentina's Santiago Solari, he sounds in no rush.

"I want to have a close look at what I have before uselessly spending money," he said. "A manager has to look carefully at how to react in a difficult moment and this is clearly a difficult moment."

A league position of 17th tells of that and Ranieri's ultimate aim is clear: "I have won cups [with Fiorentina and Valencia] and never a championship," he said. "I also want to win a championship."

Much of what he has seen and heard gives him hope. Morale has been low, he admits, but he sees ambition to match his own and heard only good from Vialli when they chatted a few days ago.

"He told me a lot and spoke very highly of everything: the team, the structure, everybody. He is an exceptional man, not only a great player but a good person. I don't know if he made mistakes, I don't know what the problems were, but it is difficult to be one day a team-mate and the next day a manager."

Ranieri comes without such baggage and his players know what to expect. "I am very gentle," he said, "as long as people do what I say. But if they don't .." Chelsea's underachievers have been warned.

fields.headline: Rovers lose interest in Berkovic
fields.trailText: Blackburn Rovers have pulled out of negotiations to buy the Israel striker Eyal Berkovic following demands by Celtic for a package worth a total of £6m.
fields.body:
Blackburn Rovers have pulled out of negotiations to buy the Israel striker Eyal Berkovic following demands by Celtic for a package worth a total of £6m.

Blackburn were prepared to offer their Scotland defender Christian Dailly in exchange but Celtic wanted an extra £2m and refused Blackburn's request to pay the extra sum at the end of the season if they win promotion.

Graeme Souness, the Blackburn manager who signed the 28-year-old Berkovic for Southampton in 1996, said: "We will not be pursuing that. We have had a change of direction and there are other irons in the fire."

Dailly could move to Newcastle United, who have been watching him in recent weeks.

One deal which is going through at Ewood Park is that of the 23-year-old Cameroon defender Lucien Mettomo, who is due to complete his £4.6m move from St Etienne.

fields.headline: Sara blows up a storm
fields.trailText: Dundee 3 - 0 Dundee Utd
fields.body:
The Argentine striker Juan Sara scored a sensational second-half hat-trick as Dundee took the honours in the 107th city derby to inflict more misery on Dundee United.

Alex Smith's bottom-of-the-table side came to Dens Park looking for their first league win of the season and it could have been so much different as Mvondo Atangana and Craig Easton both saw efforts come back off the crossbar.

But after the restart Sara provided a stunning treble to make his tally seven for the season and the visitors' troubles were compounded when they had Jason De Vos dismissed for a challenge on Fabian Caballero.

Not to be outdone Dundee also had somebody sent off when the player-manager Ivano Bonetti's brother Dario was sent from the dug-out for his comments after the dismissal.

fields.headline: No play-off revenge for unlucky Gills
fields.trailText: Man City 1 - 1 Gillingham
fields.body:
Joe Royle still enjoys an evening in with his chairman David Bernstein watching the video of their team's play-off final victory over Gillingham in May 1999. The tape of the latest meeting between the clubs is doubtless destined for less favourable treatment.

With a nice sense of the dramatic, Gillingham captain Paul Smith atoned for missing the first penalty in the memorable Wembley shoot-out, by putting his team in front. George Weah's late 12-yard strike, from a deflected clearance by keeper Vince Bartram, earned City a draw their play scarcely merited.

The stakes were certainly a lot lower than for the teams' last meeting 16 months ago, a fact reflected in a lacklustre start. Mark Kennedy's early cross was deflected away by keeper Vince Bartram, one-handed and at full stretch, before George Weah collected Jeff Whitley's pass, only to place it well over from 20 yards.

Weah may have come to Maine Road for any number of reasons, but a second round Worthington Cup tie with Gillingham was probably not high among them.

Nor was the service of a quality to prick the interest of the former world footballer of the year or his partner Paulo Wanchope. Weah eventually tried to do it all himself, powering through, with defenders bouncing off him, only to fire hopelessly off target.

That aside, long-range shots from Kennedy and Ian Bishop, and Shaun Wright-Phillips's instinctive snap shot over the bar were as close as City looked to scoring.

Instead, Gillingham, firm at the back with bodies quick behind the ball, could have added to the unproductive home form that has seen City win just one of their three league games at Maine Road.

Nicky Southall slipped the ball through for Carl Asaba to shoot over after Asaba had sent an earlier effort wide. An Andy Hessenthaler corner was helped on by Barry Ashby, Paul Ritchie clearing from beneath his own crossbar.

City continued to toil after the restart and fell behind to one of Gillingham's promising breaks. Alfie Haaland was forced into a desperation block to deny a 61st minute shot from Hessenthaler but from the resulting corner the Gillingham player-manager found the head of Chris Hope to devastating effect. Nick Weaver performed a reflex save but, in the scramble that ensued, Paul Smith reacted first, forcing the ball over the line from close range.

After Weah had been denied by Vince Batram, Roylesent on Paul Dickov, the scorer of that vital second goal at Wembley, to replace Wright-Phillips. Whether an act of symbolic romanticism or tactical urgency, it summed up City's unease.

fields.headline: Future's bright for Elisabeth Murdoch
fields.standfirst: By leaving Sky, Elisabeth Murdoch has broken her father's spell, says Maggie Hyde, the Media Medium.
fields.trailText: By leaving Sky, Elisabeth Murdoch has broken her father's spell, says Maggie Hyde, the Media Medium.
fields.body:
After her departure from BSkyB, her recent appointment on the board of Future Network and promises of a new production company when her baby has arrived, how are things shaping up for Elisabeth Murdoch? And what place will she have in her father's empire?

Born on August 22 1968, she is a Leo with her sun on the royal star Regulus, and like all Leos, she has to be boss. Her four-year stint at BSkyB coincided with forceful Mars crossing her Sun. As MD, this was her chance to show her Leo leadership skills, but it was marred by crossed swords with consecutive CEOs.

Her horoscope shows a quieter phase as her Sun progresses into Libra, the sign of partnership, and partner Matthew Freud must have a lot to do with this. Her non-executive position at Future Network (April 22 1999) is a catch for this company, with its Sagittarian Ascendant plugging into the current media revolution initiated by the Jupiter-Pluto opposition. But Elisabeth has no obvious astrological connection here, and Future Network is unlikely to be a primary vehicle for her.

With a strong Leo-Virgo combination in her horoscope, everything Elisabeth does is well planned. Her hopes for her own production company are expressed in true Leo style. "I would like to be my own boss, I would like to pick my own team ... do my own thing, pursue my own opportunities, create my own culture and control my destiny".

Not knowing her birthtime, but based on the planets for her day of birth, her horoscope shows networking but little extrovert activity in the next two years. It isn't until June 2003 that it reflects her creative aspirations. Venus makes wonderful connections then to her Leo Sun, and we may at last see a major project that is truly hers.

So what of her place in the Murdoch empire? She is a different spirit to her father. In contrast to his fishy Pisces, Elisabeth has no water, and no air either. With mainly opposition contacts between their charts, they have conflicting goals and attitudes, and she must find it impossible to pin him down. Her Venus and Pluto oppose his Sun and Mercury, hinting at the Persephone myth. The beautiful daughter Persephone was pulled down into the underworld (Pluto/Hades), and she lost sight of the sky.

Elisabeth's loss of Sky is the point of no return for her, too. She has broken her father's spell and shaken off the burden of being Murdoch's daughter, leaving the field clear for her brothers. When she resurfaces, it must be in her own light.

Email the Media Medium at: maggie@companyguide.co.uk

webTitle: Bright Station in legal row over Boo

fields.headline: Bright Station in legal wrangle with Boo liquidator
fields.trailText: Bright Station, the internet company that bought Boo.com's technology assets, is embroiled in a legal row with the company's liquidator.
fields.body:
Bright Station, the internet company that bought Boo.com's technology assets, is embroiled in a legal row with the company's liquidator.

Bright Station is suing accountancy firm KPMG over alleged comments made about the value of the software, which can translate web transactions into multiple languages and currencies. The technology cost £35m to develop but was bought by Bright Station for £250,000.

An industry source said: "There were very few companies who could assess the true value and potential of Boo's technology, and Bright Station sees itself as one of those companies. KPMG are upset because they sold equipment worth £35m for £250,000."

A KPMG spokesperson dismissed Bright Station's complaints, saying the case had no merit and should be struck out of court. Bright Station would not comment.

The Boo software has been integrated into Bright Station's Sparza e-commerce solution, which chief executive Dan Wagner has described as "the potential jewel in the crown of the company." Bright Station's other subsidiaries include the WebTop search engine programme and the SmartLogiK knowledge management solution.

fields.headline: Rabble soother's surprise ovation
fields.trailText: The Liberal Democrat conference agenda announced "Speech by the Rt Hon Alan Beith MP". Normally this would not provoke great excitment - a demonstration of quick drying paint might cause more adrenalin to spurt - and indeed the hall was less than full.
fields.body:
The Liberal Democrat conference agenda announced "Speech by the Rt Hon Alan Beith MP". Normally this would not provoke great excitment - a demonstration of quick drying paint might cause more adrenalin to spurt - and indeed the hall was less than full.

Mr Beith is a amiable and quietly spoken man, who happens to be deputy leader of the party. Now and again he stands for leader, but no-one takes this very seriously. He has a slightly puzzled air, like an accountant who has been mooned by a busload of schoolgirls. Geese occasionally say "boo" to him.

Before Peter Sutcliffe's arrest, Clement Freud, then a Liberal MP, used to insist that Mr Beith was the Yorkshire Ripper, a drollery which worked only because it would be hard to imagine anyone who looked or behaved less like a homicidal maniac.

I myself had a fantasy that mild mannered Alan Beith would sometimes disappear into a phone booth and emerge as Super Pad, able to throttle his opponents with piano wire, but I have seen him in the same room as Sir Paddy too many times for that to be possible.

In a sometimes waspish profile in the Directory of Liberal Biography, Michael Meadowcroft hints at a more Machiavellian cast of mind than most of us have been able to perceive. In the past couple of years he has suffered two personal tragedies. Old political reference books show that, apart from wearing different spectacles, his appearance has scarcely changed in the 27 years he has been an MP.

As a speaker, Mr Beith might best be described as a rabble soother. So it was a pleasant surprise when he produced a rattling speech, full of pungent points, some genuine passion, and some good jokes. ("Did you come to the conference by train? I did - and I was three and a half hours late. They say Richard Branson isn't experienced at running a lottery; he already runs one, and it's called Virgin Trains.")

He said how outrageous it was that parliament was not even sitting during the fuel crisis. " Not even sitting because of our archaic parliamentary calendar which closes the place down for three months of the year.

"Westminster could do nothing, and the public saw parliament as powerless and irrelevant." Sincerity is a hard thing to fake, even in a political speech, and Mr Beith was clearly and genuinely outraged.

He said that he found his constituents universally disillusioned with the government. "They would like to stick the whole cabinet in the Big Brother house, so they could vote out one every week... though they might draw the line at seeing John Prescott in the shower."

But he was just as angry with the fuel protesters and "the anarchy in which a picket decides whether you get the fuel to take your wife to hospital, or for a nurse to visit your grandmother".

As for the Tories, he reserved a special and venemous contempt for them. Many people had felt excluded by 18 years of Tory rule. "William Hague's rhetoric suggests an even worse kind of exclusiveness. Now it's asylum seekers and Asian doctors singled out for opprobrium."

With a fierce warning that politics was in danger of becoming irrelevant to people's lives, he sat down.

The audience looked faintly numb. They had just been stirred by a Beith speech. They were as startled as they might have done if he had performed a striptease on the bar with Jackie Ballard. But after a few moments they realised their duty and, yes, a little late in the day, Alan Beith, of all people, won a standing ovation from the conference.

Normally this would not provoke great excitment - a demonstration of quick drying paint might cause more adrenalin to spurt - and indeed the hall was less than full. Mr Beith is a amiable and quietly spoken man, who happens to be deputy leader of the party. Now and again he stands for leader, but no-one takes this very seriously. He has a slightly puzzled air, like an accountant who has been mooned by a busload of schoolgirls. Geese occasionally say "boo" to him. Before Peter Sutcliffe's arrest, Clement Freud, then a Liberal MP, used to insist that Mr Beith was the Yorkshire Ripper, a drollery which worked only because it would be hard to imagine anyone who looked or behaved less like a homicidal maniac. fields.headline: MI6
fields.standfirst: All you are allowed to know about the fulcrum of espionage, paranoia, conspiracy theories, and things that go bang in the night
fields.trailText: All you are allowed to know about the fulcrum of espionage, paranoia, conspiracy theories, and things that go bang in the night.
fields.body:
1. There seems to have been a bit of a security cock-up at the headquarters of MI6, the Secret Intelligence Service, the very existence of which was flatly denied until a few years ago.

2. Now we all know it exists, at Vauxhall Cross near Waterloo on the south bank of the Times. You can't miss it: it's a tall cream and green job, with a rather big hole in the eighth floor, caused apparently by a rocket.

3. To be fair, domestic security is not MI6's job. That's the work of MI5, the Security Service, as SIS boss Richard Dearlove will no doubt be saying right now through gritted teeth.

4. When the last government outed the intelligence services, many observers expected some of officialdom's obsession with secrecy to evaporate.

5. Wrong. Open government, accountability and such concepts are the establishment's equivalent of breaking wind in church. As a prime example of their compulsive tendencies, they're trying to suppress the entirely sensation-free memoirs of Dame Stella Rimington, the former director of MI5.

6. They are also, rather more vigorously, pursuing naughty boys Richard Tomlinson and David Shayler, whistle-blowers for MIs 6 and 5 respectively.

7. Here's a curiosity: type "Richard Tomlinson" and " David Shayler" into any search engine and you get a torrent of good stuff, including the list of alleged SIS agents which no responsible site would dream of publishing though it's been knocking about since Len Deighton was a lad.

8. Not that we would descend into paranoid schlock. Oh no. In any case, it is much too crowded down there.

9. It's even possible that whoever fired the missile into the heart of Britain's senior security service, might have been acting in revenge for Princess Diana. For every net-nutter seems convinced that MI6 was behind the Paris crash.

10. Even the garrulous Tomlinson seems to think his old colleagues had a hand in it.

fields.headline: ITN resurrects News at Ten
fields.trailText: ITV is going head to head with the BBC by moving its flagship news bulletin back to 10pm.
fields.body:
ITV is going head to head with the BBC by moving its flagship news bulletin back to 10pm.

The ITV news will return to its long-standing slot as part of a package of measures to be introduced in the new year, ITN confirmed today.

The move follows the BBC's announcement last month of plans to move its Nine O'Clock News into the vacant 10pm slot.

ITV was due to take the Independent Television Commission to court next week in an attenpt to obtain a judicial review of the ITC's decision to move the network's flagship bulletin to an earlier time than the current 11pm slot.

But today's 11th-hour settlement has ensured that programme will return at 10pm, even if it is not in the same format as the original News At Ten.

The programme will now be 20 minutes long and will screen at 10pm from Monday to Thursday. The new name and announcers have not yet been announced.

Friday night's bulletin will follow the weekend night news schedule and ITV will be allowed to broadcast the news later on one other weeknight to allow longer programmes.

David Liddiment, ITV's director of programmes, described the compromise as an "imaginative solution". "ITV retains the ability to adapt to changing viewer demands, remain commercially competitive and sustain investment in programming, whilst improving news accessibility for audiences," he said.

"Films, feature length drama and live sport, uninterrupted by news, will remain a key feature of the ITV schedule thanks to the flexibility we have secured."

ITN has faced public outrage - plus statutory pressure from the ITC - since it began airing the news at the later time of 11pm late last year.

The channel moved the news to free the 9pm to 11pm slot for prime time viewing, but the move prompted a ratings dive.

The ITC has insisted on ITV moving the news forward, insisting most viewers were tucked up in bed before the 11pm broadcast.

The ITC chairman, Sir Robin Biggam, said: "ITV has a public service obligation to deliver national and international news to viewers. About 60% of the population still don't have access to multi-channel television, so they rely on terrestrial services to get their news and information."

Today the new arrangement received mixed reactions from politicians.

The chairman of the Commons culture committee, Labour MP Gerald Kaufman, said it called into question the competence of the ITC as an effective regulator. "It is deplorable to say we are getting back News at Ten when it may not be News at Ten at all and when it will only be 20 minutes," he said.

"I think the ITC has shown itself to be too weak. This does not restore the kind of confidence in the ITC that would make one confident of its continued existence. Compromises rarely work and I think this is an unhappy ending to an unhappy episode."

But the shadow culture secretary, Peter Ainsworth, welcomed the announcement as a "sensible compromise".

ITV has agreed to clearly signpost any schedule changes to viewers in advance, so that the public are well aware of the times of all bulletins.

There will be no changes to ITV's Evening News bulletin at 6.30pm on weekdays. The late night regional news bulletin will remain unchanged at 11.20pm.

CNN.com Europe, CNN's first standalone European new media venture, launches today, backed by £4m advertising campaign.

The new site, europe.cnn.com, is produced and edited by a team of 30 journalists from CNN's new European Interactive headquarters in London.

webTitle: Kennedy offers a haven for the discontented

fields.headline: Kennedy offers a haven for the discontented
fields.standfirst: In his closing conference speech, Charles Kennedy invited those unhappy with the two major parties to support the Liberal Democrats in pursuing the "people's priorities". Julian Glover in Bournemouth hears delegates' reactions
fields.trailText: In his closing conference speech, Charles Kennedy invited those unhappy with the two major parties to support the Liberal Democrats in pursuing the "people's priorities". Julian Glover in Bournemouth hears delegates' reactions.
fields.body:
Not the best speech in the world, but enough to see him to the end of a successful party gathering: that seemed to be the verdict of delegates on Charles Kennedy's closing address to this year's Liberal Democrat conference.

They liked his delivery: measured, sometimes passionate, and rarely overblown. They also warmed to his unusually personal attack on the Tory leader, William Hague, as a man "who jumps in with both feet, in the wrong place, at the wrong time and for the wrong reasons".

Kennedy clearly hates William Hague; it's personal, and not just political. "William Hague is not the leader of a serious political party. That's the serious point," Kennedy said.

Nonetheless, some delegates were left feeling uneasy by the speech's limited policy content.

Accustomed to being addressed by Sir Paddy Ashdown, who believed the point of a conference speech was to say lots of new things, firmly, Liberal Democrats are going to have to get used to a leader who speaks to achieve a less passionate and detailed effect.

The ultimate aim of all leaders is the same, of course: to win more votes for their party. This year Kennedy tried to get them by addressing an audience beyond the faithful in the hall.

He asked Conservatives disillusioned by William Hague's rightwingery to switch allegiance. "You have friends in the Liberal Democrats. You have a home. Come to us."

He also appealed to people who voted in Labour in 1997 in the hope of getting better public services to turn to the Liberal Democrats, too.

This attempt to gather in the discontented is a wise ploy, but it was not helped by Kennedy's decision to overlook the petrol crisis. Promising to deliver the "people's priorities", Kennedy did not discuss what appears to be their most immediate priority - cheaper petrol.

Perhaps that was sensible. This has been a week free of controversy, a source of strength for the Liberal Democrats given that their rivals are in tumult.

Kennedy did nothing that risked upsetting that. Instead, he thumped out a simple theme: "Britain needs the Liberal Democrats", and went some way towards justifying it.

Whether that will be enough for his party to gain votes and seats at the next election, as Kennedy promised it would do, remains to be discovered. To an extent, it depends on what Tony Blair and William Hague say to their party conferences over the next fortnight.

fields.headline: Tinker, tailor, cossetted spy
fields.trailText: As MI6 tidies up after the missile attack, Westminster correspondent David Hencke looks at what lies behind the flash façade of the spies' HQ.
fields.body:
The secret and dirty world of spies has made a rare outing following the surprise missile attack on the MI6 headquarters.

The highly expensive MI6 headquarters at Vauxhall Cross has always been a subject of mystery, intrigue, double dealing and certainly an extravagent waste of public money.

The huge headquarters - which the government recouped some cash for by allowing it to be used as the backdrop for the latest James Bond movie - ran spectacularly over budget, with the spies demanding all sorts of expensive whizz-kid gadgetry.

They then tried to cover up the huge bill by demanding that the cost should be kept secret - and succeeded in delaying the disclosure for some five years.

The pampered spies at MI5 and MI6 have a very cosy relationship with Parliament - which has had only a modicum of control over what they do.

Membership of the Parliamentary committee that oversees the spies is by invitation from the Prime Minister.

It rarely meets in public and most of the details in its reports are censored to protect the services from too much scrutiny. State secrecy is used to cover up incompetence.

Until their moves to expensively renovated headquarters on both sides of the Thames - the spies enjoyed almost total protection - even the addresses of the headquarters were a state secret.

Of course everybody knew where the old buildings were and who were the key people running it. Now we are allowed to know both. But everybody wants to know a lot more about spies.

Now with the Shayler case due to come to court, MI6 face allegations about waste, incompetence and conspiracy coming out into the open.

Was the MI6 building used to plot the murder of Colonel Gadafy - which the spies deny. Did the Real IRA target the room where spying activity continued against this breakaway group?

What other activities are they up to? Why did they close off huge swathes of London round the building yesterday? But no doubt the security services will ensure that as little as possible is answered.

Special report: the Shayler case

webTitle: No increase, No green light, and No signing

fields.headline: No increase, No green light, and No signing
fields.trailText: (NOT QUITE) RAISING THE STAKES
fields.body:
(NOT QUITE) RAISING THE STAKES

If at first you don't succeed, try, try, try again. That's the lesson David O'Leary O'Leeds drummed into his childish charges after they humiliated themselves against Barcelona and Ipswich. And look what it did for them - they trounced European giants Milan by one freakish own goal to nil, turning their forelock-tugging manager into The Incredible Boasting Man in one fell swoop. Buoyed by this success, O'Leeds has apparently taken his own advice - and made, made, made another bid for West Ham defender Rio Ferdinand.

But even though Leeds upped their initial £15m bid by a whopping 0 pounds, Hammers boss Harry Redknapp still isn't biting. "They won't give up, will they?" claimed Redknapp on his website (www.gorblimeytrousers.co.uk). "They know how great a player he is and they know just what a great signing he would be for them." Not that he wasn't sorely tempted by the size of the 'new' offer. "At times, I think about how many players I could bring in with the money from it, but I am desperate not to lose Rio because it would be a real blow if he left us."

The temptation-shunning Redknapp went on to express his surprise at Leeds' tight tactics. "It seems a bit strange it is the same offer on the table," his website article (www.councilflat.com) continued. "Maybe they think if they keep trying they will get some joy. Or maybe they are receiving some encouragement from elsewhere, although I know it wouldn't come from Rio because he has told me how happy he is here." Although Leeds denied making the new bid - "there has been no new bid" - we can't see their wily Irish manager giving up on Rio yet. After all, he knows that where there's a will, there's a will.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

ADVERTISEMENT

Free minidish and digibox from Sky. You pay for installation. Plus you can choose to subscribe to Sky digital - the home of sport.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

SCOT-CHED

Cast your mind back just 24 hours to when MI6 was safe as houses and Martin Keown wasn't one of the most feared strikers in Europe. You may recall a certain Allan McDonald, Celtic's still-not-left-yet chief executive, claiming the proposed Atlantic League could be up and running within two years if, as he expected, Uefa gave the green light to the plan. Sadly, it appears that Uefa don't share his optimism and, in fact, are a bit annoyed about McDonald shouting his mouth off.

"We will reflect what the clubs have said to the executive committee, but suggestions that the green light is about to be given are simply wrong," said Uefa's communications director Mike Lee today. "The integrity of domestic competitions and the current European club set-up is vital to the future of the whole of European football. You cannot look at these issues in isolation. We understand the concerns raised by the clubs but their proposed solution raises more questions than it answers." Oops.

It's unlike Uefa to spurn an obvious money-spinner, but they do insist that they will be willing to listen to any other kooky plans the Scots or the Scandos have to offer. Not wanting to wait around, the Fiver has a few suggestions of its own to throw into the ring. Like allowing Ajax to subtly pretend to be Kilmarnock every Saturday, or depriving the Scottish Premier League of all integrity by catching it in bed with a buxom model. Or, even, telling Allan McDonald to keep his mouth shut until after a decision has been made.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

QUOTE OF THE DAY

"I could tell they were scared. I could see it in their eyes. They were waiting for the end" - Thierry Henry on Shakhtar Donetsk. He must presumably have seen these eyes while they were watching him scuff another chance past the far post.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

ROVERS RETURN HOME

It's all go at Ewood Park. Not content with simply inventing a football club, Graeme Souness, the future manager of Edinburgh United, has set about having a hand in all today's transfer news. Now, for those without memories as elephantine as the Fiver's, it might be worth reminding that Blackburn used to be quite a big club, and signing lots of players for exorbitant prices was their speciality. But Souness has adapted that policy for a modern age, and taken up not signing players for loads of money instead.

First on the list is Lucien Mettomo, a Cameroon under-21 international who plays for St Etienne. Taking his inexperience into account, a sensible valuation of the centre-back appeared to be £2.3m. So Rovers doubled it and, according to the club, Mettomo would have signed today if he had not failed a medical for unspecified reasons. "Our medical staff are now in dialogue with their counterparts in St Etienne over Lucien's full medical history," an elusive Blackburn statement read today. "We don't expect any further developments before the weekend and in the meantime Lucien has returned home to France."

All of which fits nicely with nasty rumours that Mettomo was never actually in England in the first place. Far less contentious, however, is the news that Souness also won't be signing Eyal Berkovic. Rovers have regularly been linked with the Israeli international whose star has steadily waned since he followed Souness out of Southampton in 1997. But today Souness admitted: "We will not be pursuing [Berkovic]. We have had a change in direction and have other irons in the fire." Which could be a handy reference to the fact that striker Kaba Diawara looks likely to join West Ham ('irons', you see) after being released from his loan spell at Rovers. That said, it could mean that Souness is about to buy Paul Stewart again. Who knows?

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

THE RUMOUR MILL

Chelsea have made an £8.5m bid for Ajax midfielder Jesper Gronkjaer, according to reports. But the 23-year-old Danish midfielder has turned down the move as he wants to stay in Amsterdam for the foreseeable future.

Simon Colosimo, the Australian right-back whose career was threatened last year by an Andy Cole tackle, could face the Manchester United striker again: he's the subject of interest from West Ham, Middlesbrough and Sunderland. Colosimo would cost in the region of £1m.

Several clubs are interested in Liverpool defender Steve Staunton, according to Teamtalk. Tranmere and Wimbledon head a list that also includes Aston Villa and Coventry.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

NEWS IN BRIEF

Manchester United defender Jaap Stam is likely to bring forward an operation on a niggling Achilles injury. Stam had planned to go under the knife in November after the first phase of Big Cup, but the injury is proving too troublesome. A three-month lay-off looks on the cards.

Wolves have signed Stockport's 25-year-old midfielder Tony Dinning for £600,000, subject to a medical. Dinning could go straight into Colin Lee's side to face Norwich on Sunday.

Gerard Wiekens and Kevin Horlock have been offered new contracts by Manchester City.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

TONIGHT'S TV AND RADIO

ITV: World Football (2.25am) No live Uefa Cup football this Thursday.

Channel 5: Jonathan Pearce's Football Night (12.05am) Which means there's a distinct shortage of footer on the box.

Dutch Football (12.35am) The torrent has been reduced to a drip, if you will.

Argentinian Football (2.20am) I mean, who do these broadcasters think they are?

Major League Soccer (4am) Getting us hooked on sport and then denying us our fix it's nothing short of cruel.

Sky Sports 1: Fifa TV (7pm, 11.30pm) What, for example, are ONdigital up to, the evil doers?

Spanish Football (8pm, 12midnight) They don't bother showing anything, as far as we can tell. At least we think they don't. If only they sent us an email clearly detailing their forthcoming football coverage.

You're On Sky Sports! (10pm, 2.30am) And as for u>direct sports, well, don't get us started.

Sky Sports 2: Football League Review (5.30pm, 6.30pm SS1, 11pm SS1) None of them care, we tell you! None of them!!!

fields.bodyText: (NOT QUITE) RAISING THE STAKES If at first you don't succeed, try, try, try again. That's the lesson David O'Leary O'Leeds drummed into his childish charges after they humiliated themselves against Barcelona and Ipswich. And look what it did for them - they trounced European giants Milan by one freakish own goal to nil, turning their forelock-tugging manager into The Incredible Boasting Man in one fell swoop. Buoyed by this success, O'Leeds has apparently taken his own advice - and made, made, made another bid for West Ham defender Rio Ferdinand. But even though Leeds upped their initial £15m bid by a whopping 0 pounds, Hammers boss Harry Redknapp still isn't biting. "They won't give up, will they?" claimed Redknapp on his website (www.gorblimeytrousers.co.uk). "They know how great a player he is and they know just what a great signing he would be for them." Not that he wasn't sorely tempted by the size of the 'new' offer. "At times, I think about how many players I could bring in with the money from it, but I am desperate not to lose Rio because it would be a real blow if he left us." The temptation-shunning Redknapp went on to express his surprise at Leeds' tight tactics. "It seems a bit strange it is the same offer on the table," his website article (www.councilflat.com) continued. "Maybe they think if they keep trying they will get some joy. Or maybe they are receiving some encouragement from elsewhere, although I know it wouldn't come from Rio because he has told me how happy he is here." Although Leeds denied making the new bid - "there has been no new bid" - we can't see their wily Irish manager giving up on Rio yet. After all, he knows that where there's a will, there's a will. * * * * * * * * * * * * * ADVERTISEMENT Free minidish and digibox from Sky. You pay for installation. Plus you can choose to subscribe to Sky digital - the home of sport. * * * * * * * * * * * * * SCOT-CHED Cast your mind back just 24 hours to when MI6 was safe as houses and Martin Keown wasn't one of the most feared strikers in Europe. You may recall a certain Allan McDonald, Celtic's still-not-left-yet chief executive, claiming the proposed Atlantic League could be up and running within two years if, as he expected, Uefa gave the green light to the plan. Sadly, it appears that Uefa don't share his optimism and, in fact, are a bit annoyed about McDonald shouting his mouth off. "We will reflect what the clubs have said to the executive committee, but suggestions that the green light is about to be given are simply wrong," said Uefa's communications director Mike Lee today. "The integrity of domestic competitions and the current European club set-up is vital to the future of the whole of European football. You cannot look at these issues in isolation. We understand the concerns raised by the clubs but their proposed solution raises more questions than it answers." Oops. It's unlike Uefa to spurn an obvious money-spinner, but they do insist that they will be willing to listen to any other kooky plans the Scots or the Scandos have to offer. Not wanting to wait around, the Fiver has a few suggestions of its own to throw into the ring. Like allowing Ajax to subtly pretend to be Kilmarnock every Saturday, or depriving the Scottish Premier League of all integrity by catching it in bed with a buxom model. Or, even, telling Allan McDonald to keep his mouth shut until after a decision has been made. * * * * * * * * * * * * * QUOTE OF THE DAY "I could tell they were scared. I could see it in their eyes. They were waiting for the end" - Thierry Henry on Shakhtar Donetsk.
