Not content with simply inventing a football club, Graeme Souness, the future manager of Edinburgh United, has set about having a hand in all today's transfer news. Now, for those without memories as elephantine as the Fiver's, it might be worth reminding that Blackburn used to be quite a big club, and signing lots of players for exorbitant prices was their speciality. But Souness has adapted that policy for a modern age, and taken up not signing players for loads of money instead. First on the list is Lucien Mettomo, a Cameroon under-21 international who plays for St Etienne. Taking his inexperience into account, a sensible valuation of the centre-back appeared to be £2.3m. So Rovers doubled it and, according to the club, Mettomo would have signed today if he had not failed a medical for unspecified reasons. "Our medical staff are now in dialogue with their counterparts in St Etienne over Lucien's full medical history," an elusive Blackburn statement read today. "We don't expect any further developments before the weekend and in the meantime Lucien has returned home to France." All of which fits nicely with nasty rumours that Mettomo was never actually in England in the first place. Far less contentious, however, is the news that Souness also won't be signing Eyal Berkovic. Rovers have regularly been linked with the Israeli international whose star has steadily waned since he followed Souness out of Southampton in 1997. But today Souness admitted: "We will not be pursuing [Berkovic]. We have had a change in direction and have other irons in the fire." That said, it could mean that Souness is about to buy Paul Stewart again. Who knows? * * * * * * * * * * * * * THE RUMOUR MILL Chelsea have made an £8.5m bid for Ajax midfielder Jesper Gronkjaer, according to reports. But the 23-year-old Danish midfielder has turned down the move as he wants to stay in Amsterdam for the foreseeable future. Simon Colosimo, the Australian right-back whose career was threatened last year by an Andy Cole tackle, could face the Manchester United striker again: he's the subject of interest from West Ham, Middlesbrough and Sunderland. Colosimo would cost in the region of £1m. Several clubs are interested in Liverpool defender Steve Staunton, according to Teamtalk. Tranmere and Wimbledon head a list that also includes Aston Villa and Coventry. * * * * * * * * * * * * * NEWS IN BRIEF Manchester United defender Jaap Stam is likely to bring forward an operation on a niggling Achilles injury. Stam had planned to go under the knife in November after the first phase of Big Cup, but the injury is proving too troublesome. A three-month lay-off looks on the cards. Wolves have signed Stockport's 25-year-old midfielder Tony Dinning for £600,000, subject to a medical. Dinning could go straight into Colin Lee's side to face Norwich on Sunday. Gerard Wiekens and Kevin Horlock have been offered new contracts by Manchester City. * * * * * * * * * * * * * TONIGHT'S TV AND RADIO ITV: World Football (2.25am) No live Uefa Cup football this Thursday. fields.headline: Rapist convicted in historic case
fields.trailText: A man accused of rape for the eighth time was jailed for life at the Old Bailey today, in a case that made legal history.
fields.body:
Nicholas Edwards, described as a Jekyll and Hyde character, was convicted of the date rape of 23-year-old Miss D following a landmark ruling by the House of Lords allowing, for the first time, other women to appear in court and also accuse him of past rapes.

Police said that he was a dangerous man who had learnt to manipulate the legal system. Without the other women's evidence, the chances of convicting him would have been "less than average".

Edwards, 39, had been cleared at previous trials of raping most of the women and it was the first time a defendant's previous acquittals had been produced during a trial.

Judge Leonard Gerber told the jury: "You have been party to the making of legal history."

The jury was told it need not just take Miss D's word that she had not consented to sex with Edwards.

Five other women gave evidence, claiming they had been forced into sex - and then Edwards had claimed they were willing partners.

Edwards, from Sydenham, south London, had denied raping Miss D and protested it was "unfair" that the jury was told about his previous court appearances.

Edwards, who boasted he had 2,000 lovers since the age of 12 when he fathered a child, was first accused of rape in 1981. He was convicted of rape twice and cleared of attacking women five times. The various juries were not told of the previous accusations.

In the latest case, Miss D said she was raped twice when Edwards tricked her into going to his room after they had been at a south London wine bar in August, 1998.

Police believe there are more victims who have been afraid to come forward. Two women have contacted police since the beginning of the trial.

Detectives said that Edwards was a serial rapist who calculated what the women would tell police - and "tailored" his defence to answer their allegations in court.

It was always his word against each woman's. But when Edwards was accused for the eighth time, the Crown Prosecution Service decided to call his bluff and produce the other accusers in court.

The case had been taken to the highest court in the land after Old Bailey Judge Leonard Gerber denied the prosecution's application to produce the previous accusers.

His judgement was upheld in the Court of Appeal but the Law Lords ruled the evidence could be produced on the basis the defendant was not placed in double jeopardy of being prosecuted again for the same crimes.

David Parry, prosecuting, said there were "striking similarities" between the crimes, which gave rise to "exceptional circumstances" in which previous accusers could give evidence.

After the verdict, Detective Sergeant Paul Astvury said Edwards was a "very dangerous" man.

He added: "He is very much a threat to women. He is like Dr Jekyll and Mr Hyde - very charming until he turns into a rapist, then reverts back."

He praised the women for their "bravery and courage" in giving evidence against Edwards.

Miss S, one of the women who gave evidence, said outside court: "Justice has been done."

fields.headline: Cybershopping
fields.standfirst:
Pets

Shopping Unlimited
fields.trailText: Pets
fields.body:
A virtual pet might not be as much fun as the furry type, but shopping for them online certainly beats the real life experience.

www.petplanet.co.uk has everything you'd want from a pet portal: advice on pet issues, discounts, and access to some silly niche and designer lines. The pet obsessive can nibble on Claudia's Canine Cuisine (gourmet doggy treats that are also fit for human consumption), do their bit for the environment with biodegradable cat litters (£2.49), or go completely over the top with the dog bandanas and "supergay" dog bowls.

Those wanting to adopt can take advantage of the rehoming service. A number of the larger pet rescue centres, including the RSPCA and NCDL, post images and descriptions of pets in need of a home on a database that users can search to locate a pet in their area.

www.bluepet.co.uk caters for the conscientious pet owner, with a range of "healthy and natural" products for cats and dogs. If your pets are susceptible to allergies, fads or arejust fussy, you can indulge them here with a selection of organic foods, or bysearching for gm-, wheat- and soya- free products. There are special treatssuch as the Catviar - a "gourmet all natural fish-flavoured cat treat" - at £4.75 a throw and a range of similarly luxurious accessories, The ponyskin Jaguar collar in Italian leather, priced at £31.75, is a fine example. The edit-orial strikes the occasional pessimistic note, offering advice on how to treat "scalds and burns due to fire, hot fat, boiling water and acid," but there is a good selection of articles by a veterinary homeopath, and aromatherapy for when a dog's life becomes too much.

If, however, you think you could do better yourself, try running your own pet website. Among other animal themed businesses for sale at www.businessesforsale.com, you will find www.pets4you.com, a Californian-based website up for grabs at $1.6m (£1m) - and that includes the pet breeder!

fields.headline: How much can you pay for...
fields.standfirst: An ice-bucket
fields.trailText: An ice-bucket
fields.body:
Nine months on, most of us have started to lose our enthusiasm for all things millennial. While spending large sums of money on weighty silver ornaments seemed appropriate at the dawn of 2000, just a few months later such souvenirs seem, well, so last century.

But one would hope this is not the case for those who buy their silver knick-knacks from Scottish jeweller and luxury goods store, Hamilton and Inches. Having drawn their inspiration from "the past which affirms the future", their limited edition Millennium Collection comprises the Quaich (the "shallow cup" of the Gaels, symbolising friendship and hospitality for the Scottish nation), the millennium clock, a selection of jewellery and an ice-bucket, with the rather grandiose title of Millennium Champagne Cooler.

Not for any old bottle of bubbly, this "magnificently heavy" cooler, with its unique design and cast handles featuring millennial devices (whatever those might be), weighs a whopping 100oz troy, and, at £6,450, has a price tag to match.

A challenge for the light- fingered and the short-of-cash, order yours on 0131-225 4898.

fields.headline: Selling from the grave
fields.standfirst: Using dead celebrities has always been popular in advertising, but a recent case involving an image of Che Guevara has exposed the pitfalls.  Belinda Archer  reports
fields.trailText: Using dead celebrities has always been popular in advertising, but a recent case involving an image of Che Guevara has exposed the pitfalls.
fields.body:
Last week, the photographer who took the famous 1960 shot of the Cuban revolutionary Che Guevara won a landmark case to assert copyright over the snap and claim royalties for its usage. The case had been triggered by the use of the picture in a press ad for a spicy brand of Smirnoff vodka. This had been overprinted with a hammer and sickle motif, with the sickle substituted by a chilli pepper. Alberto Diaz Gutierrez was upset because he felt that the chilli trivialised the historical significance of his photo and its subject, and was awarded a "substantial" payment by Lowe Lintas, the London agency which had created the ad.

But admen have always liked to use celebrities - especially dead ones - in their advertisements. BA is currently running a 60-second ad which stars a parade of classic figures trooping through the airport lounge. These include Winston Churchill, Mahatma Gandhi and John Lennon, all of whom, says the airline, chose to fly with BA at some stage during their lives.

One2One has also recently mounted several TV ads starring, among others, Ian Wright having a "one to one" with Dr Martin Luther King, and Kate Moss chatting to Elvis. Classic black and white shots of Audrey Hepburn appear regularly in association with various leading jewellery manufacturers, while Albert Einstein has been used to plug British Gas and numerous other spuriously scientific products.

Given the potential difficulties, as highlighted by the Che Guevara lawsuit, why do advertisers use dead personalities? And why are consumers so attracted by these endorsements from beyond the grave?

Peter Souter, executive creative director of Abbott Mead Vickers, the UK's biggest advertising agency, says: "Using celebrities firstly gets your ad noticed, and secondly acts as a shorthand for communication. But if you want to use a big Hollywood star you normally can't get them until they are past their best. The good thing with a dead star is that they are not spoilt. Steve McQueen never got to the stage where he made a bad film, hence he will always be a beautiful, cool young man."

Charlie Crighton, account director for Ford at Young & Rubicam, also cites the general appeal of famous personalities: "There is an aspirational nature to celebrities. They automatically have an elevated position, but they can also suddenly achieve cult or legend status when they are dead in a way that they weren't when alive."

Deciding on which personality to use is the key. Simply bunging any celebrity, dead or alive, into a com mercial alongside a given product is not enough - there has to be a relevance and a neat fit that consumers can appreciate. The cost of using celebrities who have passed away can be high, and not necessarily a cheaper option than using living ones.

Bartle Bogle Hegarty, the agency behind the One2One commercials, claims that securing permission to use Luther King and Elvis was almost prohibitively expensive. "It's not about saving money at all," said John O'Keeffe, BBH executive creative director. "It can be as costly, if not more so, than using living personalities, but it can pay massive dividends."

Money aside, the advertiser then has to set about seeking permission. Y&R went through long, drawn-out negotiations with McQueen's estate and with Warner Brothers, which made Bullitt, before gaining the right to use the classic footage in its commercial. Similarly, M&C Saatchi, the agency which created the BA "roll of honour"ad, jumped through many hoops to secure its stars.

Richard Alford, a group account director at M&C, explains: "The clearances were a lot of work and took over three months to tie up. In the UK, you are allowed to use images of dead people willy-nilly, but we ethically decided to seek full clearance from the estates and trusts for each celebrity we featured. We offered all the estates money, which in fact they gave to charity." But as Keith Mathieson, a partner at the leading media law firm Reynolds Porter Chamberlain explains, there are advantages and disadvantages when using dead celebrities.

"You cannot defame the dead in the UK, so effectively it is easier to use images of dead people than living people," he says. "However, you do have to find out if anyone owns the copyright of an image, then seek permission. If you use it without permission, you are taking a risk because you are potentially infringing copyright."

This is what Lowe Lintas failed to do with its Smirnoff ad. But agencies have to be wary of using overseas stars: while there is little besides infringement of copyright that can stop the image of a dead UK star being used, elsewhere people's images are more jealously guarded. In fact, there is a veritable industry in the US set up to protect, if not capitalise upon, the commercial use of dead celebrities' images both at home and abroad.

But despite the lengthy processes and the possible minefields, many companies and their ad agencies believe using dead celebrities pays off - and customer responses would seem to bear that out. So successful was the Ford Puma ad starring McQueen, for instance, that by the end of 1997 sales of the Puma had achieved a 52% share of the coupe market. Six months after the ad first aired, there was a four-month waiting list.

Indeed, the whole business of licensing celebrities, both dead and alive, is one of the hottest growth areas in marketing and has already become a £6bn industry. Next month there will be a dedicated show, Brand Licensing London 2000, at which licensers will be putting thousands of brands, characters and images up for sale to ad agencies, sales promotions agencies and marketing consultants. Everyone from John Lennon to Bing Crosby and Marlene Dietrich will be flogged for potential "brand extension".

Leysa Kay, the event's director, says: "This area of marketing has really taken off. The show is in its second year, and it is now four times bigger than in 1999, largely because folk are beginning to realise the potential of cashing in on selling famous people's images. The consumer trend is to buy branded products, whether that be Michael Owen's name on a computer game or a recognised, dead celebrity in the product's associated advertising."

So whatever next? The Che Guevara lawsuit might have highlighted the potential pitfalls - and the scepticism with which the public should treat these ghostly seals of approval - but so long as advertisers tread warily, it looks like this particular marketing tactic is here to stay.

The Che Guevara lawsuit might have highlighted the potential pitfalls - and the scepticism with which the public should treat these ghostly seals of approval - but so long as advertisers tread warily, it looks like this particular marketing tactic is here to stay.

fields.headline: TheStreet looks for allies
fields.trailText: September 21: TheStreet.com said yesterday it was "evaluating opportunities" to link with other financial news providers after warning that its summer relaunch had flopped. By Andrew Clark.
fields.body:
TheStreet.com said yesterday it was "evaluating opportunities" to link with other financial news providers after warning that its summer relaunch had flopped.

The online information company admitted advertising revenue had been "disappointing". Deals to distribute its news to other websites had been delayed due to "technical factors". Its shares dived 20% in early trading to just under $5.

Chief executive Tom Clarke said: "We are evaluating business opportunities out there. There are a lot of players in this business. Consolidation is a natural evolution."

Known for its quirky take on Wall Street events, TheStreet.com has a loyal following among private investors. In an attempt to widen its appeal, the firm abolished charges for access to its signature website over the summer.

Mr Clarke conceded that the response had been "a shade below expectations" in terms of page impressions.

The number of "unique users" - individuals visiting the site at least once - has fallen slightly in the third quarter.

Under its new business model, TheStreet.com relies more heavily on advertisers for revenue.

Mr Clarke said: "The whole advertising market has been sluggish. I don't think it's unique to us."

It was "evident" that companies were spending more of their advertising budgets on-line but: "They're still determining what projects work and what don't."

TheStreet.com competes for attention with an ever-growing list of financial sites, many of which are backed by the firepower of large media organisations. Leading sites include FT.com, Bloomberg and CNN.

TheStreet.com had hoped to increase its profile by distributing its content to other websites. This has been a slow process. Mr Clarke said: "When you're dealing with other companies, their priori ties sometimes don't tie in with yours."

He insisted that the business as a whole was "still on track" despite the setbacks. The company's British offshoot, TheStreet.co.uk, was "doing great and exceeding all our expectations".

TheStreet.com was founded by Jim Cramer, a former hedge fund manager. Under the slogan "Ignore us at your own risk", it specialises in delivering news in an in-your-face style.

In a statement, TheStreet.com reiterated its commitment to achieving positive cashflow by the second half of next year.

The group has a cash pile of more than $88m.27

fields.headline: Spanish councillor killed in Catalonia
fields.trailText: A Spanish politician has been shot dead in a terrorist attack in a coastal town north of Barcelona.
fields.body:
A Spanish politician has been shot dead in a terrorist attack in a coastal town north of Barcelona.

Town councillor Jose Luis Ruiz Casado was walking near his home in Sant Adria de Besos, at 8am local time (6am GMT) today, when he was shot in the back and head.

The 42-year-old married father of two died immediately. He was one of two Popular party members in the Catalan town.

Witnesses saw two people fleeing the scene just after the shooting, in a Renault car with Barcelona licence plates. Police found the vehicle ablaze nearby minutes later.

A police officer at the scene confirmed the authorities were linking the murder to the Basque separatist group Eta, who have claimed responsibility for 11 killings across Spain this year, including Popular party members.

French and Spanish police have recently conducted a major crackdown on the terrorist group. French officers arrested 16 people accused of belonging to the group last weekend, including Ignacio Gracia Arregui, who Spanish authorities believe to be the leader of Eta's military wing. Spanish police arrested 20 accused Eta members throughout Spain a week ago.

Eta has killed nearly 800 people in its 32-year campaign for a Basque homeland straddling northern Spain and south-western France.

webTitle: City says no to asylum seekers

fields.headline: City says no to asylum seekers
fields.standfirst:
Council alleges £174,000 debt

Special report: refugees in Britain
fields.trailText: No more asylum seekers will be accepted by Liverpool city council because it says the Home Office owes it £174,000.
fields.body:
No more asylum seekers will be accepted by Liverpool city council because it says the Home Office owes it £174,000.

Councillors allege they have been left with a debt of £96,000 for housing the asylum seekers between December 1999 and March this year, before official dispersal arrangements came into effect.

The Liberal Democrat-controlled council has incurred a further £78,000 loss because it set aside accommodation, but did not receive the number of asylum seekers it had been told by the government to expect.

Richard Kemp, a member of the city council, said it was a farcical situation. "To make matters worse, they have ignored our repeated requests to place asylum seekers through the council. Instead they have put 1,000 directly into private hands and unsatisfactory conditions and we have been left to pick up the pieces."

He said the council was the first northern authority to come to the rescue of the Home Office and overloaded councils in the south, to offer to house asylum seekers.

"Official arrangements had not been agreed at that stage, but everything we did was on the firm understanding that our costs would be covered," he said.

The people of Liverpool had proved their willingness to accept asylum seekers, often when no one else would. Mr Kemp said they could not afford to bear the brunt of unfulfilled obligations from the Home Office.

"Clearly, the government and Liverpool city council have a different definition about what satisfactory accommodation means," he added.

But the leader of the Labour group on the city council said he was deeply concerned by the refusal to accept any more asylum seekers. Gideon Ben -Tovim dissociated himself from Mr Kemp's comments.

He said the council had a moral, humanitarian obligation to give shelter to refugees and asylum seekers.

Fazil Kawani, communications director of the Refugee Council, said his body had always maintained that asylum seekers should be accommodated through local authorities, as they were best placed to house them in suitable locations and to help them gain access to local services.

He said local authorities were also in a good position to raise public awareness of the reasons why refugees flee persecution and require protection in Britain, and to help to develop good community relations between the host population and refugees.

The Refugee Council is urging the government to create conditions in which local authorities can take part in the new support arrangements and to ensure that their costs are fully met.

However, a Home Office spokesman said Liverpool city council had exceeded the amount it could claim back for asylum seekers.

The limit had been set at £140 a week for single people and £240 a week for families. But between December 6 last year and March 31 this year, Liverpool had exceeded this limit by £200,000, by claiming £225 a week for single asylum seekers and £309 for families.

"The Home Office has asked the audit commission to investigate why there is a range of costs to support asylum seekers," he said.

"We always made clear that councils would not be reimbursed if they exceeded those limits, and the majority lived within the set costs."

fields.headline: Channel 4 comes out of divorce on top
fields.trailText: Channel 4's divorce documentary, Break Up, pipped BBC2's Modern Times Sperm Wars last night by 600,000 viewers, reports Jessica Hodgson.
fields.body:
Last night's doc wars between Channel 4 and BBC2 saw some tough competition at 9pm. Channel 4's divorce documentary, Break Up, proved that viewers still have a taste for the fly-on-the-wall, pipping BBC2's Modern Times Sperm Wars last night by 600,000 viewers, with a 2m (9% share) compared with 1.4m (6% share), in spite of the intriguing title.

Tonight with Trevor McDonald stormed ahead, proving its success last week in the middle of the fuel crisis was more than a flash in the pan. This week it got a more modest but nevertheless respectable 5.9m viewers, 36% of audience share at 10.15pm.

ITV had a fairly respectable night all round. Last night's Big Match at 7.30pm, Arsenal v Ukrainian side Shakhtar Donetsk, notched up 7m viewers, a 33% share, better than Tuesday night's Leeds v AC Milan game, which drew 4.8m and 28%. The Tuesday night match was probably not helped by the Beeb's scheduling of the brand new sitcom, My Family.

Last night the prospect of Rolf Harris going native in Animal Hospital in Oz at 8pm on BBC1 failed to generate the same degree of interest, yielding a healthy but not staggering 6.4m or 29%.

ITV's Big Match gave a good lead-in to Coronation Street at 9.45pm, which ramped up 10m viewers and a 48% share as viewers tuned in to catch up on Hayley and Roy's adoption plans.

Meanwhile, Rambo 3 on Channel 5 got 12% at 10pm with nearly 2m viewers.

fields.headline: Merger in mind
fields.standfirst:
Advertising industry rides wave of global consolidation

In the wake of a raft of mergers and consolidations, Omnicom and True North have resumed talks over a possible link-up. Claire Cozens reports on the latest movements in the industry and asks who will be next?
fields.trailText: In the wake of a raft of mergers and consolidations, Omnicom and True North have resumed talks over a possible link-up. Claire Cozens reports on the latest movements in the industry and asks who will be next?
fields.body:
The news that Omnicom and True North have resumed talks over a possible merger will come as a surprise to no-one. When DaimlerChrysler, which spends more than $1bn on advertising through the two companies, said it wanted to cut down to just one major agency it must have seemed the logical thing to do.

Whereas once clients sought to prevent their agencies from consolidating, now they seem to be positively encouraging it. DaimlerChrysler has welcomed the move, saying it wants to encourage anything the pitching agencies can do to improve efficiency - ie drive down the cost of running its advertising business.

But what is surprising is that the decision to begin talks appears to be a direct consequence of the review. It is a mark of the power wielded by a major global client that agencies will react so quickly and so dramatically. DaimlerChrysler says "jump" and the agencies say, "how high?".

Traditionally, clients have insisted on strict agency demarcations, with their rivals being handled by advertising agencies as far away as possible from their own. This has meant lots of independent agencies handling a diverse range of clients. But the increasingly global nature of business means fewer, bigger clients who want to be able to call on their advertising agency to fulfil pretty much all their marketing needs, anywhere in the world - and that means the ad agencies need to get bigger and more powerful.

Procter & Gamble has for a long time had a reputation as the most protective of clients. It is a measure of the power of the world's biggest advertiser that Saatchi & Saatchi was forced to demerge from Cordiant Communications in 1997 because its status as a P&G roster agency meant Bates Worldwide, Cordiant's other agency network, could not pitch for any other household product advertisers.

More recently, though, P&G has wielded its authority to persuade agencies to go the other way. Realising that it was no longer served by the leaders of the advertising industry, P&G told its agencies - Leo Burnett, D'Arcy, Saatchi & Saatchi and Grey - that it would welcome any moves to consolidate. It was not long before D'Arcy and Leo Burnett had obliged by linking up with the Japanese agency Dentsu to form Bcom3.

Then earlier this year TBWA teamed up with Hakuhodo of Japan to form a joint venture that will serve the two companies' joint Nissan client. And there is still considerable scope for further consolidation. The $64,000 question is, who will be next?

fields.headline: Overwhelming majority backs TV regulation
fields.trailText: Television should continue to be regulated in the digital age, according to a new Broadcasting Standards Commission report. By Jessica Hodgson.
fields.body:
Television should continue to be regulated in the digital age, according to a new Broadcasting Standards Commission report.

The report by the TV watchdog showed that 92% of people questioned supported the regulation of television, while 82% thought radio should be regulated. Of those who voted in favour, 61% gave as their main reason the protection of children and vulnerable groups.

But respondents were less clear on the best way to achieve regulation. A third of respondents did not know who regulates TV and radio. But 39% believed a future regulatory body should operate independently of broadcasters.

The study, Regulation - the Changing Perspective, is part of a series of reports by the BSC and the other major TV regulator, the Independent Television Commission, in the run-up to the white paper on the future of broadcasting and communications.

Both regulators, along with the telecommunications regulator Oftel, face rationalisation in the anticipated overhaul of the regulatory system.

fields.headline: Fujimori quits amid scandals
fields.trailText: President Alberto Fujimori's surprise announcement last weekend that he would step down and call fresh elections followed signs that he was losing the support of the powerful military in the fallout from two major corruption scandals involving Peru's notorious intelligence service.
fields.body:
President Alberto Fujimori's surprise announcement last weekend that he would step down and call fresh elections followed signs that he was losing the support of the powerful military in the fallout from two major corruption scandals involving Peru's notorious intelligence service.

Mr Fujimori's decision, announced in a national address, stunned the country and left Peru's opposition scrambling to build a united front. Officials said the election was likely to be held within six months, and Vice-President Francisco Tudela said that Mr Fujimori "has the full intention of staying in power during that time". For their part, opposition leaders demanded that Mr Fujimori step down immediately in favour of a transition government.

Last Saturday's announcement was a breathtaking reversal for Mr Fujimori, Latin America's longest-serving elected leader, who had weathered severe criticism since winning an unprecedented third five-year term in May elections widely described as unfair.

International pressure had been mounting on him to agree to democratic reforms, including firing Vladimiro Montesinos, the architect of Peru's ruthless intelligence service, who has been Mr Fujimori's most important aide since his rise from obscure academic to president in 1990.

Demands to deal decisively with Mr Montesinos reached a climax after a videotape was made public last week showing the intelligence chief handing a $15,000 bribe to an opposition congressman to back Mr Fujimori.

With pressure growing on Mr Fujimori to act, several key regional leaders of Peru's military refused to attend a meeting called by the president last Saturday to gauge his support within the armed forces, but it was unclear whether the military chiefs withdrew their support for Mr Fujimori out of loyalty to Mr Montesinos or in an effort to hasten his, and Mr Fujimori's, departure.

In a sign that elements of the military were opposed to Mr Montesinos, Fernando Olivera - head of the opposition Independent Moralising Front - who obtained the damaging videotape, said that it had "come from a civilian source with links to a discontented segment of the military".

Mr Olivera said he has obtained other tapes from intelligence sources that show footage of Mr Montesinos bribing businessmen, journalists, politicians and even some military officers to support Mr Fujimori.

On Tuesday Mr Montesinos was reported to be holed up at a Peruvian military base as opposition politicians demanded his arrest.

"The military obviously played a key role," said Francisco Loayza, an intelligence adviser to Mr Fujimori in the early days of his first administration. "As far as I can tell... they began withdrawing support as the scandal around Mr Montesinos grew. Mr Fujimori saw what he built begin to come apart, and decided it was not possible to continue governing."

In his address Mr Fujimori said that he was dismantling the National Intelligence Service. The organisation had been instrumental in destroying the leadership of two leftist guerrilla groups during the early 1990s - by means that human rights groups said included torture, executions, and intimidation and persecution of many innocent Peruvians.

Mr Fujimori's announcement set off spontaneous celebrations across Peru, including in the capital's main plaza opposite the presidential palace, where flag-waving revelers converged.

Mr Fujimori's decision was hailed by the United States, which has had an uneasy relationship with the president, supporting his hard line on drug traffickers, but opposing his moves against democracy.

A White House statement said: "We welcome the bold step taken by President Fujimori. The actions announced... are clearly aimed at resolving the political polarisation facing Peru [and]... represent a good beginning to such an endeavour."

Mr Fujimori's decision was an unexpected windfall for Alejandro Toledo, who pulled out of the second round of balloting for the presidency in May. He said he still does not believe Mr Fujimori will give up power so easily, but he called the decision "a great step toward democracy for Peru".

Mr Toledo also officially declared his candidacy to succeed Mr Fujimori. "I plan to be president; I am ready to be president; I will be president," he said.

fields.headline: Portillo snubs Newsnight
fields.trailText: Shadow chancellor Michael Portillo declined to appear on Newsnight last night amid reports of a Conservative boycott of the Newsnight and Today programmes, writes Jessica Hodgson.
fields.body:
Shadow chancellor Michael Portillo declined to appear on Newsnight last night amid reports of a Conservative boycott of the BBC's Newsnight and Today programmes.

Mr Portillo decided against appearing on the BBC1 current affairs flagship despite giving interviews on other news channels during the day. The Sunday Times reported last week that William Hague was ordering Tory spokesmen to boycott the Today programme.

However, Newsnight presenter Jeremy Paxman said: "We don't seem to have had problems getting Tories on."

The Tories have claimed recently that BBC news programmes were biased in favour of the government. Sources at BBC news believe that Today and Newsnight, in particular, have been singled out for criticism.

webTitle: M&B to open New York office

fields.headline: M&B to open New York office
fields.trailText: 2.45pm: Michaelides & Bednash is set to launch an office in New York next month, writes Jade Garrett.
fields.body:

fields.headline: Portillo pulls out of Newsnight amid 'Tory boycott' rumours
fields.trailText: Shadow chancellor Michael Portillo pulled out of last night's Newsnight, despite appearing on a number of television news programmes yesterday, according to sources at the programme.
fields.body:
Shadow chancellor Michael Portillo pulled out of last night's Newsnight, despite appearing on a number of television news programmes yesterday, according to sources at the programme.

The move follows press reports that William Hague had ordered Tory MPs to boycott the Today programme last week. Today and Newsnight have come under attack in recent months by Tory politicians who claim the BBC is biased in favour of the Labour party.

Presenter Jeremy Paxman confirmed that Portillo had refused to go on the programme. But he played down the possibility that the move was part of a Tory strategy to boycott it, saying: "We don't seem to have had particular problems getting Tories on."

Last week the Daily Mail launched a bruising attack on new BBC political editor Andrew Marr, accusing him of pro-Blair bias in his handling of the fuel crisis.

fields.headline: News at Ten to return
fields.standfirst:
Minister urges BBC to rethink news move
Comment by Matt Wells
fields.trailText: ITV has bowed to pressure from the Independent Television Commission and the government by agreeing to reinstate its News at Ten bulletin. By Jessica Hodgson.
fields.body:
ITV has bowed to pressure from the Independent Television Commission and the government by agreeing to reinstate its News at Ten bulletin.

From January 1, ITV will show a 20-minute news bulletin at 10pm from Monday to Thursday. This will be extended in the run-up to the general election.

In a statement, ITV's director of programmes, David Liddiment, said: "This is an imaginative solution on both sides, which reflects the beginning of a new relationship between ITV and the ITC.

"ITV retains the ability to adapt to changing viewer demands, remain commercially competitive and sustain investment in programming, whilst improving news accessibility for viewers."

The move represents a crushing defeat for ITV Network Centre, which lobbied the ITC for years to persuade it to allow ITV to move the news bulletin, clearing its schedule for higher ratings programmes.

But the ITC will allow ITV concessions, including an additional 2.5 minutes of advertising in peak time.

The late regional news on ITV will continue to go out at 11.20pm, and ITV promises this bulletin will be preceded by programmes delivering "a strong audience inheritence". There will be no changes to the Early Evening news bulletin at 6.30 on weekdays. In the run-up to the general election News at Ten will be extended by 30 minutes.

Earlier this year, the ITC ruled that news audiences had declined significantly as a result of moving the bulletin. Following unsuccessful negotiations, the commission ordered the network to reinstate the bulletin.

ITV prepared to take legal action, but at this year's Edinburgh Television Festival, ITV chiefs indicated that they would be prepared to negotiate with the ITC to find a solution.

fields.headline: PPA mulls new distribution system
fields.trailText: The Periodical Publishers Association is this morning outlining proposals for a new UK-wide magazine distribution system.
fields.body:
The Periodical Publishers Association is this morning outlining proposals for a new UK-wide magazine distribution system.

The distribution system for magazines has come under scrutiny during recent months after a long-running dispute between publishing companies and Tesco, which has threatened to de-list magazines for failing to sign up with its preferred national distributor, WH Smith.

Publishers have argued that the system favoured by Tesco and WH Smith will make it less economical for magazines and newspapers to be distributed through small outlets and will lead to reduced distribution options.

Newspaper publishers suffered distribution problems during last week's fuel crisis.

fields.headline: PPA moves to defuse distribution row
fields.standfirst: PPA mulls new distribution system.
fields.trailText: The PPA today outlined proposals for a solution to the ongoing dispute between publishers and retailers over magazine distribution, reports Jessica Hodgson.
fields.body:
The Periodical Publishers Association today outlined proposals for a solution to the ongoing dispute between publishers and retailers over magazine distribution.

The proposals, called Blueprint, have been drawn up by the PPA in response to moves by Tesco to push all magazine distribution through a national network operated by WH Smith. Tesco claims that the current magazine distribution system is outdated and costly.

Magazine publishers claim this system would make it inefficient for some 20,000 smaller local retailers to sell magazines, forcing them to stop selling some magazines. They warn that this could lead to a reduction of consumer choice and, ultimately, a threat to press freedom.

Last summer a dispute between Tesco and publisher Gruner + Jahr, now owned by the National Magazine Company, led to Tesco threatening to stop carrying certain G+J titles unless the publisher signed up to its proposals, leading to accusations of bullyboy tactics.

The PPA and local retailers want to hold onto the current system of distribution through local wholesale networks, but supplement it with a new "central publications unit", which feeds information with accounts, auditing and reporting capability. The Blueprint proposals also recommend a more flexible system of sales replenishment from a central point.

The PPA is seeking approval from publishers, distributors and retailers. WH Smith and Tesco have agreed to work with the PPA on Blueprint, but have yet to signal their approval of the project.

webTitle: Lycos Europe snaps up Spray Network

fields.headline: Lycos Europe pips T-Online to the post for Spray Network
fields.trailText: Internet portal Lycos Europe has snapped up Sweden's Spray Network for E674m (£404m) in a cash and shares deal, writes Dan Milmo.
fields.body:
Internet portal Lycos Europe has trumped German rival T-Online by snapping up Sweden's Spray Network for E674m (£404m) in a cash and shares deal.

Lycos Europe, a joint venture between US portal Lycos and German media group Bertelsmann, said it would carry out more acquisitions in a fast-consolidating sector.

The combination of Spray and Lycos Europe creates a portal with nearly 1bn page views per month, 19m unique visitors and coverage of 12 countries.

The move is frustrating for T-Online, which was rumoured to be interested in Spray but has been hobbled by management clashes with parent company Deutsche Telekom. Analysts say the next three months will see a burst of M&A activity in the European ISP market and the erosion of T-Online's market leader position could leave it on the sidelines.

Attention will now turn to Freeserve of the UK, which is 80% owned by high street retailer Dixons, and is an obvious acquisition target for any company wishing to enter the UK market. Likely suitors include Wannadoo of France, Tiscali of Italy, T-Online and Terra, which is the partner of Lycos Europe.

webTitle: Huey Lewis: The man from uncool

fields.headline: The man from uncool
fields.standfirst: In the 80s, Huey Lewis was the mullet-haired poster boy for bland American pop. He made it hip to be square, but now, with a new film in the pipeline, he's so out of fashion he might even be in.  Clark Collis reports
fields.trailText: In the 80s, Huey Lewis was the mullet-haired poster boy for bland American pop. He made it hip to be square, but now, with a new film in the pipeline, he's so out of fashion he might even be in.
fields.body:
As you might expect from a movie about karaoke starring Gwyneth Paltrow and directed by her dad, Bruce, Duets has already generated its fair share of pre-release stories. Undoubtedly the weirdest tale, however, concerns the man who plays Paltrow's on-screen father. "Huey very quickly became my musical manager and advice-giver," la Paltrow claims. "He would say, 'You have to make a record', and I'd say, 'I'm just happy to sing with you.'"

The "Huey" in question, as will become clear when the film opens here on November 17, is none another than arse-chinned 80s rocker Huey Lewis, and there will be many readers who need no more evidence than Gwyneth's gush to assume that the actress badly needs a spell in the rubber room. Lewis, after all, is the man who told an entire generation of MTV drones that it was "hip to be square" - advice that, under laboratory conditions, has proven to be completely erroneous. Moreover, despite enjoying massive success during the 80s with his band The News, the singer now seems to be entering his second decade in the Where Are They Now? file.

There are some of us, however, who believe that HLATN are not just the all-singing, all-gurning pub-rock gonks that they might appear at first glance, but rather writers and performers of genuine calibre. One commentator, for example, has called the band's third album, Sports, "a flawless masterpiece. Every song has the potential to be a huge hit, and most of them were. What to say to Sports dissenters in the long run? Nine million people can't be wrong."

Admittedly, the "commentator" in question is Patrick Bateman, the nailgun-toting, mass-murdering yuppie hero of Bret Easton Ellis's American Psycho, and by no means the man one would automatically turn to for musical advice (he is also a big fan of Genesis - although not, in his defence, of their early work). Yet the fact that Ellis spends no less than eight pages extolling the virtues of Lewis and co - Whitney Houston only gets four - rams home quite what grand fromages they used to be.

Then again, Huey was never exactly your underachieving type. Born Hugh Anthony Cregg III (his stage moniker, originally Huey Louie, comes from two of Donald Duck's nephews), the young singer scored a perfect 800 on his maths SAT, securing him a place at Cornell University. But his father persuaded Lewis to take a year off, which he spent hitch-hiking around Europe.

While waiting for rides he taught himself to play the harmonica and, by the end of his stay, was being paid to perform gigs at $150 a pop. From there on it was predictable that Lewis's engineering course would take second place to his burgeoning musical career as frontman for a student band called Slippery Elm. Unsurprisingly, they never got anywhere - would you buy a record by a band called Slippery Elm? - but his next group, Clover, caught the ear of visiting Brit Nick Lowe, who suggested that their good-time pub rock might find a more sympathetic ear in mid-70s Blighty. As it happens, Lowe was wrong in this assessment and Clover's records bombed despite members of the band backing Elvis Costello on his debut album.

Such a setback didn't deter Huey, though, who simply formed a new group, the News. After their eponymous debut album sank without trace, it looked as if this latest incarnation might also go the way of Clover and Slippery Elm, but the band's second record, Picture This, sold more than 500,000 copies.

It was Sports, though, that made them megastars. Released in 1983, the album's no-nonsense, kick-ass rock enraptured an American nation growing weary of fey Brit invaders like Culture Club and Duran Duran. The success of Sports - which stayed in the US charts for a mind-boggling 158 weeks - was matched by their next album, Fore!, thanks in large part to their Back To The Future tie-in single The Power Of Love.

The Spielberg-produced movie also featured a cameo from Huey as a teacher, paving the way for appearances in such films as Short Cuts and Sphere. And while his musical career foundered in the wake of 1988's bizarrely reggae-fied Small World album, his acting career has taken on a new lease of life. In fact, critics who have seen Duets are already hailing his performance as the best thing in what seems a pretty bad job, with one reviewer urging readers to "savour the timbre of his voice and the planes of his face".

But Huey's relationship with Tinseltown has not always been a happy one. When Mary Harron's big-screen version of American Psycho came out, for example, Huey refused permission for the accompanying soundtrack to contain Hip To Be Square, promoting all manner of headlines inferring that Lewis was indeed more square than hip (Lewis's manager claimed the issue was contractual rather than censorial).

In between his acting gigs, meanwhile, the singer has continued playing the musical kind, and is currently awaiting feedback on an album sampler that's been sent to leading record company executives. One can only pray that some West Coast firm has the sense to pick it up and prove that Bateman was right about Huey being indeed "a vocalist, musician and writer who just can't be topped".

webTitle: Derek Malcolm on  Jean Renoir's Boudu Saved from Drowning

fields.headline: Jean Renoir: Boudu Saved from Drowning
fields.trailText: Renoir was a master who seemed incapable of making a bad film but was modest enough to admit his own flaws. His total lack of cynicism or even pessimism is what attracts people to his films today. That and the kind of fluency of utterance that makes you totally unaware of his film-making technique, which always manages not only to show you what goes on within the frame but also to suggest the world beyond it
fields.body:
Everyone has his reasons, Jean Renoir used to say, and his generosity of spirit is what elevates his films so high in the estimation of successive generations of film-goers. Just occasionally, however, one has to ask whether Hitler had his reasons too. "If every way of life can be defended," the critic Robin Wood has commented, "then nothing need be changed."

Renoir, however, did not become the father-figure of the French New Wave for his human warmth and moderation. And it was Boudu Saved from Drowning rather than the more famous La Grande Illusion and The Rules of the Game, great classics though they are, that convinced the young new-wave bloods that here was a man who deserved to be followed.

Boudu (Michel Simon) is a terminally scruffy tramp who is saved from drowning in the Seine by an antiquarian bookseller (Charles Granval). Apparently, the man was fed up with life and intending suicide. And now he insists that his rescuer must take responsibility for him.

Brought back to the bookseller's bourgeois household, he behaves exactly as nature rather than propriety demands. The family are shocked but patronisingly amused at first, even when Boudu spits on the antiquarian's beloved editions of Balzac. He does so not out of spite but simply because you spit when you want to spit. But when Boudu seduces first the wife and then the maid, we begin to understand that the two worlds of the middle class and the outsider are colliding with fateful results.

Eventually, the tramp, who has never kissed anybody before except his dog, marries the pretty maid but, accidently this time and probably the worse for drink, falls in the river after the ceremony. Suddenly discovering his liberty again, he is off to pastures new.

The film was based on a play in which Boudu finally accepts his responsibilities. But Renoir wanted a joyful paean to freedom and anarchy, to be contrasted with the plodding pursuit of material comforts the bookseller's family is engaged in. And so the film looks even more appropriate now than it ever did, right down to the military bugle sounding as Boudu beds the bookseller's wife.

What the New Wavers liked, apart from the subversive nature of the material, and what may seem to us old hat by now, is that everything was shot on location in Paris and its quays; the book seller's stuffy household and the then-beautiful suburban countryside are evoked with great eloquence and skill. And if Renoir seems to like everybody, especially Boudu, can one really cavil?

Simon, given as much freedom as possible by his director, manages to seem charming even when behaving like a complete slob. And here a few doubts surface in this delicious film. For instance, how threatening is Boudu in reality? And should we be laughing when he virtually rapes the bookseller's wife? The scene is played as farce and so works all right. But could it be played as such now? Renoir, however, was a master who seemed incapable of making a bad film but was modest enough to admit his own flaws. His total lack of cynicism or even pessimism is what attracts people to his films today. That and the kind of fluency of utterance that makes you totally unaware of his film-making technique, which always manages not only to show you what goes on within the frame but also to suggest the world beyond it.

Renoir is considered one of the greatest film-makers of all time, largely because he could so clearly convey his humanity and warmth through his films. But he wasn't simply loveable. Like his painter father, he expressed far more than at first meets the eye.

 There is a bfi/ICA's two-day special on the director, on September 29 and 30. Pasolini's Salò: To the Limit will bring together figures from the arts - including artist Jake Chapman, writers Jenny Diski, Gary Indiana and Neil Bartlett, and former BBFC head James Ferman - to discuss this controversial movie. A two-week run of Salò begins on October 20. Tickets: 020-7930 3647.

webTitle: United star chokes on Smokey Beckham flavour

fields.headline: United star chokes on Smokey Beckham flavour
fields.trailText: David Beckham is fighting to prevent his name being used to sell a brand of crisps, it emerged today.
fields.body:
David Beckham is fighting to prevent his name being used to sell a brand of crisps, it emerged today.

While Gary Lineker and Michael Owen have happily endorsed Walker's Crisps flavours Salt & Lineker and Cheese & Owen, the Manchester United star is objecting to an attempt to register Smokey Beckham as a trademark.

Jerome Martin of Sidcup fought off competition to register the name with the UK Patent Office, reaching the first stage in his application in April 1999 and advertising the application on May 31 2000, a bid that was opposed by Beckham's lawyers earlier this month.

A spokeswoman for Walker's Crisps said the company received over 6,000 letters following the 1998 World Cup suggesting it create a Smokey Beckham flavour. She added that the Leicester-based firm had no plans to use the name.

The bid will be judged by a chief trademark officer to see who owns the potentially highly lucrative trademark.

Jerome Martin of Sidcup fought off competition to register the name with the UK Patent Office, reaching the first stage in his application in April 1999 and advertising the application on May 31 2000, a bid that was opposed by Beckham's lawyers earlier this month. A spokeswoman for Walker's Crisps said the company received over 6,000 letters following the 1998 World Cup suggesting it create a Smokey Beckham flavour. She added that the Leicester-based firm had no plans to use the name. The bid will be judged by a chief trademark officer to see who owns the potentially highly lucrative trademark.

webTitle: How the web helped me write a novel

fields.headline: How the web helped me write a novel
fields.standfirst: Would-be Great British Novelist  Adam Evans  finds technical support and encouragement from other writers on the world wide web
fields.trailText: Would-be Great British Novelist Adam Evans finds technical support and encouragement from other writers on the world wide web
fields.body:
I was having a quiet drink with an old friend the other day when he told me, very proudly, that he had just finished his first novel. This was completely out of character - he had never displayed any interest in writing before - and, with mounting amazement, I asked him what it was about.

"Oh, it was the first Harry Potter book; it really was excellent. I don't know why I haven't tried reading books before," he said.

After insisting he buy the next round for cracking such an awful Queen Mum gag (weak and terribly old but loved by an insane segment of the population purely because of this), I looked back at the feelings that rushed through my head when I thought he really had completed his first novel.

Topping the winner's rostrum was undoubtedly amazement but there, in second and third place looking disappointed as amazement's national anthem played, were envy and depression. Envy because I have never managed to finish a novel and depression because I am worried I never will. This dismal duo could well sound familiar to you; many people dream of writing a novel but few actually finish one, and fewer still get it published, become millionaires and bask forever in the glow of literary appreciation.

My biggest problems, the same as many thousands of people, are that I find it hard to get started and am overly critical of the words I do manage to write. In search of a solution to these, I turned to the web.

One of the first sites I came across was www.inkspot.com, which describes itself as an "award-winning resource and community for writers of all ages and levels of experience". This actually is not too far off; there are plenty of helpful articles on different aspects of writing, a discussion forum and masses of links to other online resources.

Reading the articles and joining in the discussions helped me to get a better perspective on my writing. Although I knew in theory that the first draft of a book does not have to be perfect, the truth of it was brought home to me only by chatting to people who had gone through the process.

If you are unsure about what you are doing, getting on to the right discussion forum can really help. Inkspot also offers a free bi-weekly email newsletter, called Inklings, which keeps you in touch with new articles and features on the site.

I found another discussion forum at http://jp.onelist.com/community/1writers. There are a few people there who like to discuss novel writing but there are many more who are just interested in writing bad poetry, so be careful.

A much more down to earth and practical site can be found at www.manistee.com/~lkraus/workshop/. The rather tortuous web address leads to the Internet Writing Workshop, which aspires to create an environment where works in progress can be passed around and critiqued, and to provide a support group where writing can be discussed in depth.

Unlike Inkspot, this is a seriously active community. Membership is restricted to people who regularly participate in criticising other members' works, apart from the general discussion group where generic topics such as How can I overcome writer's block? are discussed.

I joined the Novels List, which - surprisingly enough - is for the submission and critiques of novel-length fiction. Books are posted to the list in bite-sized chunks, so you can criticise them in manageable parts.

The fact that you have to do a certain amount of criticism each month, or face expulsion from the group, means that you really do start to learn from the process.

The chance to read and identify parts of other peoples' writing that are poor, indifferent or excellent is incredibly useful when it comes to analysing my own work. I can look at a section and easily see where I've gone wrong because I've seen the same mistake in someone else's prose.

Critters is another online critiquing workshop, at www.critique.org/users/critters. Confined to serious science fiction, fantasy and horror writers, it operates a similar system to the Internet Writing Workshop. It boasts more than a thousand members, each providing a critique per week. If you have finished a novel, there is a special section for getting the entire thing criticised quickly, rather than piece by piece.

Stepping back into the literary mainstream for a moment, www.purefiction.co.uk is the only British site that is really worth visiting. Soon to be relaunched, the old site nonetheless has plenty of articles on the business of novel writing, from plotting a thriller to choosing a central character and jump-starting your creativity. This is all useful but the danger of reading about writing a novel, rather than actually writing it, is omnipresent.

The most valuable sites are those that link you to other writers, so you can share ideas and criticisms. For me, this has meant increased determination and self-confidence. I am still nowhere near the end of my book, but my writing output has increased and I no longer fiddle with every word as I go along.

Expect to be buying my quirky, modern British novel, Dog On Roof, from your local bookshop in spring 2002.

fields.headline: Shayler faces third charge
fields.trailText:
Former MI5 intelligence officer David Shayler was charged with a third count of breaking the Official Secrets Act today, when he made his second appearance before magistrates.
Special report: the Shayler case
fields.body:
Former MI5 intelligence officer David Shayler was charged with a third count of breaking the Official Secrets Act today, when he made his second appearance before magistrates.

Mr Shayler was charged with passing on material obtained through telephone-tapping - an offence against section 4 of the Official Secrets Act - when he appeared at Bow Street Magistrates' court in central London.

Mr Shayler, 34, is already charged with two offences under the Official Secrets Act in relation to information which formed the basis of an article in the Mail on Sunday newspaper.

The article said that security chiefs at MI5, where Mr Shayler previously worked, had kept files on prominent Labour politicians, including Northern Ireland secretary Peter Mandelson and home secretary Jack Straw, who was branded a communist sympathiser.

Mr Shayler fled to France before the article was published but returned voluntarily last month.

The former MI5 man, accompanied by partnerAnnie Machon, spoke only to confirm his name and address during the 10-minute hearing. Solicitor John Wadham of civil rights group Liberty said that his client would plead not guilty.

Outside the court Mr Shayler joked that he was surprised that he had not also been charged with last night's missile attack on MI6, adding: "I don't have an alibi either, I was out drinking."

He also criticised the police, saying: "There are a lot of criminals around, I am the only one charged with anything and I am only writing newspaper articles rather than killing people."

Mr Wadham, who tried repeatedly to hurry his client away from waiting journalists, said that they had not expected the third charge, but insisted that it would make it easier for Mr Shayler to fight his case.

Mr Shayler has said that, when his case goes to trial, he will claim protection under European human rights legislation, which becomes part of English law on October 2.

webTitle: MI6 missile attack: Irish dissidents suspected

fields.headline: MI6 missile attack: Irish dissidents suspected
fields.trailText: One of the heads of Britain's anti-terrorist squad today called on the community of London to band together to fight the growing threat of terrorism in the capital, after what appeared to be a rocket-propelled grenade was launched at MI6's headquarters last night.
fields.body:
One of the heads of Britain's anti-terrorist squad today called on the community of London to band together to fight the growing threat of terrorism in the capital, after what appeared to be a rocket-propelled grenade was launched at MI6's headquarters last night.

In a public appeal this morning, deputy assistant commissioner of the anti-terrorist branch Alan Fry called on Londoners to be vigilant to avoid a repeat of the attack, amid fears that dissident Irish republicans are starting a new terror campaign on the British mainland.

He said: "We know the community can defeat terrorism - we have proved that in the past - and once again we ask the community, we ask the people of London, we ask any visitors in the vicinity, to think about anything they saw, anything they thought was suspicious and to make it known to the police. We can defeat this."

The squad has set up a special telephone hotline on which members of the public can leave any information about the attack at MI6. Mr Fry also urged Londoners to use the traditional 999 emergency call if they spotted any suspicious packages or activity in other parts of the city.

He confirmed that anti-terrorist experts, police exhibits officers and crime specialists were currently in the building, looking for evidence of the type of weapon used. A number of theories already suggest it may have been a rocket-propelled grenade.

Mr Fry said other teams were combing the area up to 500 metres around the building, including the nearby rail tracks, in an effort to discover where the weapon was launched from. He said this process would take "many hours", but any conclusions would be made public as soon as possible.

Dissident Irish republicans are thought to be behind the explosion. Terrorism expert Mike Yardley said if the device used was, as suspected, a rocket-propelled grenade, it was one Irish terrorists are known to use.

There was no coded warning of the kind that usually precedes dissident republican bombings, because it was a "different kind" of attack, Mr Yardley said. "This was an attack late at night and it would seem it was an attack designed not to create casualties, it was an attack for effect. This was different to a static bombing campaign."

The Real IRA have been held responsible for most recent mainland attacks. The organisation declared a ceasefire after the August 1998 Omagh bombing, which killed 29 people. But it has been linked to a series of attacks this year - at least two of them in London: at Hammersmith Bridge in June and a west London underground line in July.

The group was formed after a split in late 1997 from the Provisional IRA because of fierce opposition to the peace process strategy of the Sinn Fein leadership of Gerry Adams and Martin McGuinness.

The IRA's quartermaster general, one of the top bomb-makers and in charge of all the secret arms dumps, was among those who walked away to form the group. Two years after Omagh, the group's numbers are increasing at a worrying level, according to security chiefs in Northern Ireland.

Staff arrived back at work at the MI6 building late this morning and train services, disrupted during this morning's rush hour, slowly began to return to normal. Mainline routes at Waterloo were back up-and-running at 11am and Eurostar was expected to follow at noon.

Mr Fry said his officers were working towards having all rail services back in operation before this evening's rush hour. He hoped to have all roads surrounding the building open by late afternoon.

MI6, also known as the Secret Intelligence Service, is situated on the south bank of the Thames waterfront, near Battersea. The flamboyant building was featured in the most recent James Bond movie The World is Not Enough - when it was the target of a terrorist bomb.

Call 0800 789 321 with any information

webTitle: Camelot wins reprieve over lottery bid

fields.headline: Camelot wins reprieve over lottery bid
fields.trailText:
Camelot today won its High Court battle to be allowed to bid for the next lottery licence.

Special report: the lottery
fields.body:
Camelot today won its high court battle to be allowed to bid for the next lottery licence.

Mr Justice Richards ruled the lottery commission's decision to negotiate only with Virgin boss Sir Richard Branson was unlawful and should be quashed.

Mr Justice Richards said: "The commission, while intending to be fair, has decided a procedure that results in conspicuous unfairness to Camelot - such unfairness as to render the decision unlawful."

The ruling means that Camelot, as well as Sir Richard's People's Lottery, will now be entitled to fine-tune its bid for a second seven-year licence to run the national lottery.

Dianne Thompson, the chief executive designate of Camelot, said her company and its 800 staff were "delighted".

She added: "Camelot was found to have been treated so unfairly that the commissioners were judged to have behaved not only illegally, but also irrationally, almost to the point of an abuse of power - and that's quite some indictment. It is clear that the best way to secure a truly competitive process is to run a race with more than one competitor and to allow that race to finish.

"We seek fair and equal treatment and we are delighted we must now be given the opportunity to have our proposals properly and fairly evaluated."

At the end of August, the lottery commission said neither Camelot nor Sir Richard's People's Lottery were fit to win the licence as their bids stood.

The People's Lottery was given an extra month to allay outstanding misgivings - Camelot was not. Camelot, the current operator of the lottery, sought the judicial review after complaining that the commission's decision was "bizarre and grossly unfair".

Camelot also alleged the commission had been given the People's Lottery coaching on what it would need to do to win the competition.

QC David Pannick, acting for Camelot, told Mr Justice Richards: "It will not help the legal process to describe the decision as grossly or manifestly unfair but that is what it is. We can find no precedent for such behaviour.

"This is as if at the end of the football World Cup final the score is 0-0 and the match has to be decided by a penalty shoot-out, but the ref decides only one team should be able to take the penalties."

Jonathan Crow, representing the commission, had a metaphor of his own to defend the decision taken.

"This was an evaluation process more like an architectural competition for a new building. One was very nearly there, the other wasn't."

The People's Lottery has indicated it will not be appealing against the ruling.

webTitle: West Ham turn down another Leeds bid for Ferdinand

fields.headline: West Ham turn down another Leeds bid for Ferdinand
fields.trailText: Leeds have made another £15m bid for West Ham defender Rio Ferdinand - only two weeks after they had an identical offer turned down by the Hammers.
fields.body:
Leeds have made another £15m bid for West Ham defender Rio Ferdinand - only two weeks after they had an identical offer turned down by the Hammers.

But Harry Redknapp, who revealed the news this morning on his personal website, told David O'Leary the England international is not for sale - although he was tempted by the offer.

"They won't give up, will they?" said Redknapp. "Leeds have come in with another massive offer for Rio - £15m. That is an incredible amount of money.

"Everyone knows how much I rate him. He is a great defender and could easily end up the best in Europe if he continues along the path he is going.

"But Leeds just won't give up, they know how great a player he is and they know just what a great signing he would be for them.

"It seems a bit strange as to why Leeds have come in with another offer just days after their original bid was turned down. It is the same offer on the table and I am not sure why they have come in for him - maybe they think if they keep trying they will get some joy.

"Or maybe they are receiving some encouragement from elsewhere, although I know it wouldn't come from Rio, because he has told me how happy he is here. It has been coming through an agent, and they just keep coming back time after time." Redknapp considered accepting Leeds' bid in order to boost his squad, who sit bottom of the Premiership and have only won once this season - a narrow 1-0 win in the Worthington Cup over Second Division Walsall.

Redknapp said: "Obviously it is difficult to turn down that sort of money for a player, especially with transfers set to be quashed.

"Let me tell you, I would be lying if I said if I said it hadn't crossed my mind to sell him for that kind of money and bring a few players into the squad that would strengthen it even more.

"At times, I think about how many players I could bring in with the money from it, but I am desperate not to lose Rio, because it would be a real blow if he left us."

"Or maybe they are receiving some encouragement from elsewhere, although I know it wouldn't come from Rio, because he has told me how happy he is here. It has been coming through an agent, and they just keep coming back time after time." Redknapp considered accepting Leeds' bid in order to boost his squad, who sit bottom of the Premiership and have only won once this season - a narrow 1-0 win in the Worthington Cup over Second Division Walsall. Redknapp said: "Obviously it is difficult to turn down that sort of money for a player, especially with transfers set to be quashed. "Let me tell you, I would be lying if I said if I said it hadn't crossed my mind to sell him for that kind of money and bring a few players into the squad that would strengthen it even more. "At times, I think about how many players I could bring in with the money from it, but I am desperate not to lose Rio, because it would be a real blow if he left us."

fields.headline: Advertising Effectiveness Awards shortlist unveiled
fields.trailText: The IPA has announced the shortlist of winners for its 2000 Advertising Effectiveness Awards, writes Jade Garrett.
fields.body:
The Institute of Practitioners in Advertising has announced the shortlist of winners for its 2000 Advertising Effectiveness Awards.

Thirty-three papers have been shortlisted from 52 entries from the UK and six from overseas.

"Managers everywhere need to demonstrate accountability," said Tim Broadbent, chairman of the IPA selection panel. "The IPA Awards are invaluable, not only in showing the commercial benefits of advertising in these specific cases but also in showing evaluative methods and techniques that can be used by everyone."

fields.headline: Felicia Jackson
fields.standfirst: netimperative.com
fields.trailText: Chief executive of netimperative.com and former editor of New Media Investor
fields.body:
Felicia Jackson is co-founder and chief executive of netimperative.com, a content, community and commerce site for internet industry professionals.

Seed round fundraiser for the company, she led the business through its much publicised liquidation, and then its relaunch with a consortium of new investors. During this period the service remained fully operational.

Before founding netimperative.com, Ms Jackson was the editor of New Media Investor, one of the UK's leading investment magazines on the e-economy in the UK internet industry. She writes regularly for business journals on the internet and advises the Department of Trade and Industry and start-ups.

fields.headline: Campaign round-up
fields.trailText: Latest news from trade title Campaign.
fields.body:
The Leo Burnett Group has begun a search for a successor to Roger Haupt, its chief executive. Haupt, who is also the chief executive of Bcom3, will now concentrate on running the holding company. The contenders include Stephen Gatfield, the former chief executive of Leo Burnett in London who is the existing regional managing director of the agency's Asia Pacific region and Linda Wolf, the chief executive of the board of directors at Leo Burnett USA.

Campaign magazine has signed up Stuart Elliott, a columnist with the New York Times. He will write a weekly column on advertising and media issues in America.

Euro RSCG Wnek Gosper has been handed Alberto Culver's $40 million (£27m) international advertising account for the haircare brand V05 without a pitch. The business moves from M&C Saatchi which won the account four months ago.

Lyndy Payne, Caroline Marland and Wendy Braverman are set to launch a company that will provide mentors for senior managers in the ad business. Potential Squared will launch in January 2001.

St Lukes is setting up a joint venture called Klondike to advise clients on digital media strategy. Clients already include Sky, Saab and Yac.com. The new company will be jointly owned by St Lukes and the staff of the new company which is founded by three partners.

Bates UK is looking for a new chief executive following a management organisation.
