fields.headline: Dear Anna
fields.standfirst: The Guardian's consumer champion fights your corner
fields.trailText: The Guardian's consumer champion fights your corner.
fields.body:
Toeing the line

We've done our best to spare you but all the while the pile has been mounting and now there's no getting away from it: the bugbear that burdens you all most is your mobile phone. If you're not trapped in a punitive contract your funds are being siphoned off into unknown pockets, your statements are registering calls you never made, or you're being hounded for line rental you never owed.

Trevor Aylward of London is among those who have found that the zeal with which companies lure your custom can turn into a suffocating affection from which it's difficult to break free. He wrote three times over three months to disconnect his line after losing his handset, but BT Cellnet claimed to have heard nothing and continued helping itself to line rental. Only when Aylward cancelled his direct debit was it roused from its slumber. Its response was to chase him for £67.60 for yet more unwanted line rental.

BT Cellnet insists it has no record of the three letters but blames itself for not taking action earlier to find out why. As a "gesture of goodwill" it has waived the £67 charge that Aylesford maintains he never owed in the first place and, ominously, has told him to ignore any bullying from its debt recovery agency.

Contract killers

Elizabeth Selby wrote to terminate her contract with RSL last autumn and received a letter in November confirming that her "enquiry" would be actioned within 10 working days. She cancelled her direct debit and assumed that the account was closed. In January RSL demanded to know how she proposed paying her bills and she reminded them of the cancellation. In February she was told that her line would be disconnected at the end of the month and in May she heard that the account was now closed but she owed them £46 in line rental. Selby pointed out the account should have been closed in December and any subsequent charges were RSL's mistake, but received no reply.

"It was an oversight," pleads RSL. "A staff member who no longer works here only actioned half the request ... It is unacceptable lack of attention to detail." Selby's account has now been cleared and her £15 disconnection fee waived in contrition.

Put the receiver down

Vira Bhaskar of Cambridge was offered a free trial of a mobile phone by the late lamented telesales firm 1st Line. He rang to terminate the deal within the specified 14-day period and was told his free trial had been extended to two months. A month later 1st Line went into receivership and Bhaskar found himself being billed for line rental by Cellular Ops. As the latter requires a 30-day cancellation notice he'll have to pay another month's rental before he can be shot of the phone.

"As 1st Line was our dealer and not our agent we are not liable for any concessions, offers or incentives offered by them," shrugs Cellular Operations. It points out that customers can write to 1st Line's receivers, Grant Thornton, but, it adds ominously, "due to the massive debt left owing by 1st Line it is highly unlikely that any claims will be met".

How to hang up

Both Sue Allan and Jeremy Minton eventually managed to break free from their respective service providers but say that the process was a nightmare with the companies insisting they'd not received any written communications or failing to act on those they did get. "The trading standards officer I phoned said that the only certain way of cancelling was to send your letter by registered post," says Allan. Oftel advises customers to keep copies of all letters of cancellation and will lend an ear to those who can't resolve their problem with their service provider.

Hold on to your SIM

When Andy Grandmottet-Shaw's mobile broke down it was dispatched to One2One for repair. Three weeks after it was received back she was sent a bill for £875 worth of international calls, made while the phone was out of her possession. One2One promised to look into it and the result was a second bill for the same amount. Weeks on, however, everyone at One2One had a different story to tell.

After Consumer jogs its memory One2One says it is waiving all charges. "If customers send phones back to be repaired they must take their SIM card out, otherwise it's like sending off your handbag with all your credit cards inside," warns a spokeswoman.

Whose line is it anyway?

Meanwhile Rebecca Dowman was wondering why One2One was charging her £300 for calls made on a phone with a number she doesn't possess. After several days of trying to contact customer services she was assured the error would be rectified, but the demands kept on coming. One2One insisted she report the "fraud" to the police, although the problem was evidently due to an account mix up. The police, unsurprisingly, declined to intervene and Dowman resumed her efforts with One2One. The response was a new bill for £398.36.

One2One declares that the number on which the calls are being made is non-existent, but that somebody's using it. "Ms Dowman was charged due to an administrative error and we've referred it to our fraud office," says a spokeswoman. "She won't be receiving any more bills."

More broken promises

Back to BT Cellnet, which deemed Julie McGovern's damaged handset irreparable and ordered her a new phone with a different number. Alas, it continued to debit monthly line rental for the disused phone as well as its replacement. BT declared itself unable to refund her but said that, in recompense, it would reactivate her old number and dispatch a new handset free to her partner, Sam Goldie. All Goldie would have to pay would be call charges. But when the phone arrived, Goldie found himself billed for line rental so he sent it back. BT promised to investigate but instead unleashed its debt collection agency which harrassed Goldie into paying £62. Since then he's heard nothing.

"An admin error was compounded by further errors, which is unacceptable," says BT Cellnet. It has now refunded Goldie and McGovern the disputed payments for both phones.

Thieves make a call

At least there's comfort in company. Hilary Mandleberg's handbag was stolen last January and the thieves used her bank details to open half a dozen One2One accounts. She was told to send the ensuing bills to the fraud department, but the demands continued to flood in. By May she was being threatened by a debt collection agency, yet One2One assured her the problem had been dealt with. Then another agency began harassing her over two more accounts that were supposed to have been cancelled and she has heard nothing more from One2One.

"It's a terrible mess and it has taken some time to plough through it," admits a spokesman who promises that the matter is now "sorted". But despite four reminder calls the promised explanation was never sent and Consumer's messages were not replied to. Sound familiar?

Write to us at119 Farringdon Road, London EC1R 3ER, phone us on 020-7713 4731, send a fax on 020-7239 9933 or email us at consumer@theguardian.com.

webTitle: Ad agencies bid for homeless campaign

fields.headline: Four-way pitch for homeless campaign
fields.trailText: Four agencies have been shortlisted to pitch for a campaign aimed at reducing homelessness across Britain, writes Jade Garrett.
fields.body:
The Department of Transport, Environment & the Regions, has shortlisted four agencies to pitch for a campaign aimed at reducing homelessness across Britain.

M&C Saatchi, WCRS, BMP DDB and the Leith Agency all pitched yesterday for the task and a decision is expected within the next couple of weeks.

The successful agency will create a national outdoor and print campaign, scheduled to break this winter. It will aim to break the cycle of homelessness and reduce the numbers of those sleeping rough at the coldest time of the year.

"This is an ongoing problem that is unfortunately being constantly topped up. Whoever picks up the account will work with homeless charities across the country to help prevent further increases in the number of homeless people," said a source at one of the pitching agencies.

webTitle: Playboy fashion models strut a different sort of stuff on the catwalk

fields.headline: Playboy fashion models strut a different sort of stuff on the catwalk
fields.trailText: Many people would prefer to see more than skin-and-bone models on the catwalk, but Betsey Johnson's show in New York last night was not necessarily the alternative they had in mind.
fields.body:
Many people would prefer to see more than skin-and-bone models on the catwalk, but Betsey Johnson's show in New York last night was not necessarily the alternative they had in mind.

Explaining that she wanted models who expressed the "sexy, girlish, voluptuous" nature of her clothes, Johnson brought on Playboy models and themed her collection around the playmate of the month centrefolds in Hugh Hefner's magazine.

As Miss April, Nicole Marie Lenz wore an "April showers" outfit of pink fur bikini with matching transparent mini raincoat and high heels, while as Miss June, Victoria Silvstedt wore a "bunny bride" costume of white satin swimsuit and cutaway train.

Any of the sequinned bra tops could have served as a hammock for Kate Moss and a friend.

The bunny theme ran through the collection, with white fluffy pom-poms on hotpants and sparkly pastel bunny ears with almost everything.

Usually, models strut with a haughty, high-stepping walk, pausing only to fix the photographers with a brief disdainful stare. The Playmates, on the other hand, bounced to the end of the catwalk in order to have more time to wink, lick their lips, pinch each other's bottoms and flash their knickers to the cameras.

In embracing the Playboy aesthetic, Johnson is hitch ing a ride with a trend that has burgeoned since the spring. The bunny pendants worn in this show have become a cult accessory since the Sex and the City actress Sarah Jessica Parker wore one on the TV show this year.

Tight T-shirts featuring the same logo have been bestsellers at London's hip Shop boutique in Soho this summer, while Stella McCartney featured a skeletal version of the bunny in a recent collection, although production was cancelled when Playboy complained of copyright infringement.

Most of Johnson's collection looks too cartoonish to yield commercial success, unless Hefner puts in a big order. But in the often po-faced world of New York fashion, it is sure to attract attention; and some of the milder elements, such as the Capri pants and the sundresses with sweetheart necklines, look very much in tune with the French Riviera chic emerging for next season.

In any case Johnson, an eccentric character on the fashion scene since 1964, seemed delighted with the show, turning a cartwheel as she came out to take her bow.

fields.headline: Gardam unveils Channel 4 commissioning revamp
fields.trailText: Tim Gardam, Channel 4's director of programmes, has announced a commissioning overhaul to concentrate on the educational and interactive arms of the station.
fields.body:
Tim Gardam, Channel 4's director of programmes, has announced a commissioning overhaul to concentrate on the educational and interactive arms of the station.

In an internal memo, Gardam said that the staff reshuffle reflected "the growing complexity of our multi-platform operations, notably the significant investment in 4Learning and the launch of E4."

Karen Brown, Channel 4's deputy director of programmes, will, as reported, take on the added title of managing director of 4Learning, while Peter Dale will become head of documentaries and Janice Hadlow head of history, arts & religion.

The changes take effect from October 1.

With the launch of E4, Channel 4's interactive entertainment platform, Kevin Lygo will be performing the double role of controller of E4 as well as head of entertainment. Andi Peters, the ex-Children's BBC presenter, will become executive producer for T4, the Sunday morning 9am to 1pm slot.

Gardam said: "These changes are designed to give greater autonomy and freedom to editors and commissioning editors to be creative in their programming and to put in place a management structure which can best help them achieve it."

fields.headline: New Media Age round-up
fields.trailText: Latest news from trade title New Media Age.
fields.body:
NMA's big story of the week was the ongoing debate about spam (see Tuesday's mediatheguardian.com) and how bad it is for the internet community.

Musicunsigned.com is to IPO on AIM on October 2 with a predicted value of £13m.

Management changes at new media agency Clockwork Web, which appears to have suspended its managing director Jeremy Spiller. NMA couldn't get confirmation of this, but suggested that Spiller's departure was down to expanding the service offering of the agency.

More problems for beleagured ISP Callnet, which recently ditched its Callnet 0800 unmetered service. Web design agency Virtual Viewing has served a 'statutory demand' for payment, adding to the writ issued by former public relations agency Mulberry PR and the threatened legal action from founders Paul and Aaron Goodman Simpson.

Insurance group Admiral has become the latest in a growing line of traditional companies to come up with silly brand names. Admiral has launched Elephant.co.uk, an online sales and quotes service, which is being backed by a £5m marketing push.

MagicSponge.com, the relaunch of footie site Carlingnet.com, picks up site of the week with 90 out of 100 points. Yours truly, MediaGuardian.co.uk is not far behind with 87 out of 100. Says Bryan Porter: "the site is clean and easily navigable, with a similar look and feel to guardianunlimited.co.uk.....like all Guardian online offerings, it's content-rich."

fields.headline: GM food protests
fields.trailText: After 28 Greenpeace activists, including former Labour minister Lord Melchett, were cleared over the destruction of a field of genetically modified maize, environmental groups says that government plans to increase GM trials are doomed. We the issues.
fields.body:
After 28 Greenpeace activists, including former Labour minister Lord Melchett, were cleared over the destruction of a field of genetically modified maize, environmental groups says that government plans to increase GM trials are doomed. Wendy Gracefield explains the issues.

What were the protesters in court for?
Lord Melchett is a former Labour minister, working farmer and head of Greenpeace UK. On 26 July last year, he and 27 others made a dawn raid on a six-acre GM maize crop being grown by three brothers for seed company Agrevo. They broke into remote Walnut Tree farm, near Lyng, Norfolk, shredded the crops with a lorry and cutting machine and started bagging them up. The volunteers, who were all wearing white decontamination suits, were quickly stopped by the vigilant farmers, who fought back by using their tractors as battering rams.

So why did Greenpeace object to the GM maize?
Greenpeace says genetically modified food destroys the environment and is bad for human health. In fact, the group argued that they had a legal excuse to uproot the crops because leaving them to flower and pollinate would have led to a greater crime - the contamination of other crops in the vicinity. Similar widespread objections means supermarkets are stepping up the sale of organic food. Protesters object to crop trials that could possibly spread genetically modified species to other crops that are currently GM free.

What is GM food anyway?
Farmers and growers have always used traditional methods of cross breeding to make their tomatoes sweeter, their trees sturdier and their plants hardier. In the past, genes were transferred between the same species, but new technology means they can be transferred within different species. In Britain, the Department of the Environment has agreed to 73 sites for GM trials this year. They include 12 spring-sown oilseed rape crops, 12 forage maize crops and 24 beet crops. Twenty-five sites are being planted with GM autumn-sown oilseed rape. Environmentalists worry that this will disturb the natural balance and have, as yet, unknown health consequences.

Why bother growing it then?
Scientists argue that genetically modified crops could be the key to richer wildlife and efficient food production. GM foods can be made to be very hardy, resistant to common diseases and faster growing. Sir John Beringer, the dean at Bristol University recently told a London science conference that.the presence of more songbirds on British farms would depend on encouraging the survival of more weeds and insects. Genetically modifying crops would help to do this.

Any other advantages?
Fruit and vegetables can be modified to improve our health. Scientists are now in the process of altering apples and strawberries into antibacterial treatments that would protect against tooth decay. An apple a day really might keep the dentist away. Tomatoes and bananas are also being tipped as a worldwide vaccine for hepatitis B. Scientists say that, if they are genetically altered to contain the vaccine, it would save millions of lives as hepatitis B is the precursor of liver cancer, the single biggest cause of cancer deaths.

What will happen to British grown GM crops now?
It is hard to tell what effect the court case will have on future GM development, but it is unlikely to stop it altogether. The Department of Environment has vowed to continue with its trials. It says that, if it were to stop the strictly controlled research, there would be widespread GM crop planting but there would be no scientific feedback. Meanwhile, Friends of the Earth claims the protesters' victory means other groups are legally able to destroy GM crops that are about to go to pollen. Lord Melchett warned that Greenpeace might take similar action in future. He said: "We don't have immediate plans, but, if the government don't do anything and the chemical companies don't stop planting these crops, we can't rule anything out."

webTitle: New authors replace old in Oxford Companion

fields.headline: Kathy Acker replaces Walter Scott in reference work
fields.trailText: ACKER, Kathy: worked as stripper and pornographic film star. UK publication of Blood and Guts in High School (1984) brought her a wide audience. Books include Pussy, King of the Pirates (1995), also recorded as a CD by the punk band the Mekons
fields.body:
ACKER, Kathy: worked as stripper and pornographic film star. UK publication of Blood and Guts in High School (1984) brought her a wide audience. Books include Pussy, King of the Pirates (1995), also recorded as a CD by the punk band the Mekons

This is one of the 600 new entries that yesterday unfurled a new, updated "map of literature" in the pages of the once sedate Oxford Companion to English Literature.

A revised edition of the 68-year-old reference book introduces a cacophonous new generation of turn-of-the century authors to stand alongside Shakespeare, Keats, Thomas Hardy, DH Lawrence and TS Eliot.

The new genres range from gay and lesbian literature, dirty realism, lads' literature (defined as "centring around sport, drinking and recreational sex") and Aga sagas to reggae, dub poetry and internet hypertext.

Individual authors newly admitted to the literary pantheon of a book used by scholars, students and readers all over the world include Nick Hornby, Germaine Greer (for "opening a new area of feminist debate"), the best-selling romantic novelist Catherine Cookson, the TV dramatist Alan Bleasdale, the novelist Will Self, the reggae poet Benjamin Zephaniah, the science fiction author Ray Bradbury, the polemical leftwing playwrights Steven Berkoff and Tariq Ali and the gay writer Edmund White.

Bradbury's debut is a measure of the book's catholicity of taste. His futurist stories, especially The Martian Chronicles, have been taught in schools for 40 years as models of their craft. But he was not previously thought "literary" enough to get into the Companion.

New entries among those whom critics do regard as literary include a crop of Anglo-Asian writers: Ruth Prawer Jahbvala, Anita Desai and Salman Rushdie.

Other arrivals are the poets Ruth Fainlight, Simon Armitage and Jo Shapcott and the author of the first world war Regeneration trilogy of novels, Pat Barker.

Classic authors, books or public figures who have been axed or pruned to make way for the new wave include some of Sir Walter Scott's once hugely popular novels, Florence Nightingale, and Mrs Beeton, the 19th-century mother of the cookery book. The editor, Margaret Drabble, said she had also left out a group of "19th-century theologians".

The influx of modern writers has happened because Ms Drabble, herself a novelist, dropped the rule of admitting only pre-1939 authors.

She writes in her preface: "Inevitably the names of younger writers will prove more controversial. But I hope the selection will give a broad sense of what was written at the turn of the millennium.

"My younger advisers see a different map of literature from the one with which my generation is familiar. But I hope the solid outline of the old remains clearly visible."

A spokeswoman for the publishers, Oxford University Press, said: "A whole new generation of writers is recognised. They can take their place alongside Shakespeare, Hardy, Lawrence and Eliot. The new edition recognises a whole new style of literature and new genres."
New authors replace old in Oxford Companion:

In

Kathy Acker (1947-1997) "Rejected plot and character in favour of autobiography, plagiarised material and disconnected dreamline sequence of explicit sexuality and violence"

Nick Hornby (1957- ) "Fever Pitch opened the floodgates, About a Boy (1998) confirmed his position as spokesman for a generation of emotionally bewildered young men"

Joanna Trollope (1943- ) Mentioned in the entry on Aga Saga, "a kind of fiction which dwells on middle-class or country life, though by no means all her work fits the generally comforting implications of the label"

Germaine Greer (1939- ) "Feminist, polemicist and critic, settled in Europe in 1964. The Female Eunuch (1970) opened a new area of feminist debate, The Whole Woman (1999) reconsiders the progress of feminism"

Out

Florence Nightingale (1820-1910) The "lady of the lamp", a heroine of Victorian society and reformers, she was described in the last Oxford Companion as "the founder of the modern nursing profession, famous for her services during the Crimea war and the reforms she brought about"

Sir Walter Scott (1771-1832) Founder of the historical novel, with "incalculable" influence. "Space has been saved by a judicious and tactful pruning of the many entries for the works of Sir Walter Scott", the editor, Margaret Drabble, writes

Mrs Beeton (1836-1865) Cherished in earlier companions for "her famous book on Household Management (1861), covering cookery and other branches of domestic science"

fields.headline: Obituary: Desmond Zwemmer
fields.standfirst: London and Britain's leading art bookseller and the man who made Zwemmer's in Charing Cross Road an institution
fields.trailText: Desmond, who has died aged 80, followed in his father's footsteps enthusiastically, working in Anton Zwemmer's bookshop and gallery and extending the publishing list, already distinguished by the presence of the very first book about Henry Moore and the first   translations of works on Picasso and Matisse.
fields.body:
In his prime, Desmond Zwemmer, six feet-four tall, wearing a widebrimmed black hat and dark overcoat well below the knees, could have been taken for a descendant of a prosperous Rembrandt merchant. An appropriate look, given that he was the elder son of a Dutchman who became London and Britain's leading art bookseller and the man who made Zwemmer's in Charing Cross Road an institution.

Desmond, who has died aged 80, followed in his father's footsteps enthusiastically, working in Anton Zwemmer's bookshop and gallery and extending the publishing list, already distinguished by the presence of the very first book about Henry Moore and the first translations of works on Picasso and Matisse.

Desmond was born and brought up in Herne Hill, south London, and educated locally. He spent a year at Besançon University, perfecting his French and becoming a Francophile, then went on to the Courtauld Institute to study for a degree in the history of art under Anthony Blunt. While there he manned his father's bookstall at the 1936 International Surrealist Exhibition at the New Burlington Galleries, and also went to Paris where he met Picasso and other artists.

In September 1939, with war imminent, he was across the Channel looking at Romanesque churches. Architecture was a lifelong passion: later he never travelled without the relevant volumes of Pevsner. War interrupted his studies, and in 1940 the gallery was closed and Desmond was called up. He spent what was described as "a quiet war" as an army officer on the North-West Frontier, in the Lebanon and, finally, in occupied Germany.

Back in Charing Cross Road, his time was divided between the bookshop, into which he introduced remainders, thus raising some highbrow eyebrows, and the gallery, where he became disenchanted by contemporary trends in art.

He was more drawn to publishing and so spent three months in Geneva working with his father's old friend, Albert Skira. Home again he began attending book sales to gain knowledge of the antiquarian market and also enrolled for a three-year course at the London College of Printing. The market for art books, as his father had found prewar, was narrow. Desmond went on the road to sell the list, with abysmal results.

But in time the market improved, thanks mainly to the efforts of Bela Horowitz, of Phaidon, Walter Neurath of Thames and Hudson and Paul Hamlyn (briefly a wartime employee at Zwemmer's). Desmond realised there was a need for a range of books on architecture and appointed Anthony Blunt and Ralph Wittkower to edit a widely acclaimed series. His father was delighted and declared it would make Desmond a "real" publisher compared to himself, who dealt mainly in buying foreign rights and in co-editions.

The company could now afford to indulge the younger Zwemmer's insistence on the highest standards of production, illustration and editing, because the retail side of business, managed by Desmond's younger brother, John, was prospering. "Publishing", historian Nigel Halliday was to record, "was a sideline not required to contribute to profits, although politely requested not to drain them either." Desmond understood: he was also a businessman.

Following Anton's retirement, Zwemmer's bought the Lund Humphries imprint and with it, John Taylor, whom Desmond had met at evening classes. The Gallery was closed and the main bookshop moved to its former site in Litchfield Street because of a development threat to Charing Cross Road.

In 1985 the Zwemmer brothers sold the family firm to Philip Wilson after Desmond had suffered a stroke. By then he had married for the second time. His new wife was Ann Beedell, a former social worker, who had opened a bookshop in Bristol. It amused Desmond who, at Zwemmer's, had tended to leave bookselling to brother John, to escape to Bristol at weekends and assist Ann on the floor of her shop. A few years on, when she sold it, she helped him in London, and accompanied him to the Frankfurt Book Fair, an annual event in which he revelled.

Desmond did not play a prominent role on the councils or committees of either the Publishers' Association or the Booksellers' Association and I cannot recall that he ever spoke in public. Yet he was most congenial company. He loved travelling, walking and gardening until the illness of his last years, which, at least, shielded him from the knowledge that Wilson had been forced to re-sell Zwemmer's, even though the name still remains on the shop fascia.

The monuments to Desmond's work are Nigel Halliday's impeccably produced history of Zwemmer's, More Than a Bookshop, a title taken from Henry Moore's accolade, and an archive which includes catalogues, correspondence and drawings, now happily secure at the Tate Gallery.

He is survived by Ann and a daughter from his first marriage.

webTitle: Arena bids for UK horseracing rights

fields.headline: Arena in £320m bid for TV rights to UK horseracing
fields.trailText: Racecourse owner Arena Leisure has bid a total of £320m for terrestrial and non-terrestrial broadcasting rights to all UK race meetings, writes Dan Milmo.
fields.body:
Racecourse owner Arena Leisure has bid a total of £320m for terrestrial and non-terrestrial broadcasting rights to all UK race meetings.

The offer was made to the Racecourse Association, which owns the UK's 59 racecourses, following the breakdown earlier this year of a joint bid from a consortium including Channel 4, the BBC and cable operator NTL.

Arena had originally offered £178m for the interactive media rights in July, which would open up opportunities in online betting. The company wants punters worldwide to be able to place bets while watching live horseracing on digital TV or the internet.

Martin Pope, chairman of Arena, said: "We feel confident that this revised offer, combined with our strategic vision for developing the media rights, will provide a secure, exciting and profitable future for British racing."

webTitle: Chancellor pressed MP to scrap memoirs

fields.headline: Chancellor pressed MP to scrap memoirs
fields.standfirst:
Former Treasury minister rebuffed plea to stay silent over his time in government but agreed to delay publication

Special report: New Labour in power
fields.trailText: Gordon Brown failed to persuade the former Treasury minister Geoffrey Robinson not to write his memoirs, although he feared the book would fuel the internal rows undermining Labour's authority.
fields.body:
Gordon Brown failed to persuade the former Treasury minister Geoffrey Robinson not to write his memoirs, although he feared the book would fuel the internal rows undermining Labour's authority.

The chancellor put pressure on the millionaire MP for Coventry North West to stay silent and abandon plans to publish his inside story of his time in government and the run-up to the last election.

Mr Robinson, a close friend of Mr Brown and a guest at his wedding celebrations on Monday night, refused but did agree to delay publication until after next week's conference at Brighton to avoid overshadowing the event.

The release next month of the former paymaster-general's book, The Unconventional Minister, is expected to include his side of the £373,000 home loan to Peter Mandelson, which cost both men their government posts.

Whitehall officials said the chancellor told the prime minister last week that the spate of books on the government was chipping away at its credibility, exposing rifts and concentrating public attention on personalities rather than policies.

Journalist Julia Langdon's biography of Mo Mowlam, written with the Cabinet Office minister's cooperation, gave details of the feuds between Labour's most popular figure and Mr Mandelson and Mr Brown as well as her rift with Mr Blair after she was removed from Northern Ireland.

Columnist Andrew Rawnsley's version of life in the government has led to Mr Blair and Mr Brown being accused of lying about the £1m donation which the Formula 1 magnate Bernie Ecclestone made to Labour.

Mr Blair was interviewed twice by Mr Rawnsley but advisers at No 10 denied he gave the author explosive information or criticised his colleagues. They said the prime minister defended the government's record and presented a picture of a relatively united team.

Mr Rawnsley also saw Mr Blair to check information. Alastair Campbell, the prime minister's press spokesman, and his assistant, Phillip Bassett, were present taking notes.

He interviewed Anji Hunter, the personal assistant to Mr Blair, and the head of the No 10 policy unit, David Miliband. He interviewed Mr Mandelson and his former special adviser, Benjamin Wegg-Prosser.

Former senior civil servants, including some in the Treasury, were interviewed. Mr Rawnsley has threatened to reveal sources if he is challenged in the courts or faces a full effort to damage his account.

The chancellor's private assessment will be seen as a tacit admission that it was a mistake to give his cooperation to a biography of him two years ago which claimed he still resented Mr Blair inheriting the Labour leadership.

Mr Robinson's book is due to be serialised in the Mail on Sunday, which is believed to have paid around £200,000.

Mr Robinson, who was forced to resign shortly before Christmas 1998 after the loan to Mr Mandelson was exposed, is understood to have given up hope of returning as a minister.

Mr Blair brought back Mr Mandelson within a year when he handed him Ms Mowlam's Northern Ireland portfolio and put him jointly in charge, with Mr Brown, of Labour's election planning.

The Northern Ireland secretary got his version of the loan into print in Donald Macintyre's recently updated biography and is said by associates to fear it could be challenged by Mr Robinson.

Downing Street shared Mr Brown's anxiety over Mr Robinson's book and Ms Hunter, a long term aide of the premier, was deputised to keep in close contact with Mr Robinson.

The Blair family holidayed in his Tuscan villa and Cannes flat before an offshore trust and £12m inheritance from the car dealer Joska Bourgeois were uncovered.

Mr Robinson has also been dogged by allegations about his business dealings and relationship with the former Mirror publisher Robert Maxwell. He was forced to apologise to the Commons for failing to register a directorship, though a police inquiry into fraud allegations at TransTec, the engineering company he formed and which collapsed last year, is understood to have found no evidence against Mr Robinson.

webTitle: Most Test runs without a century

fields.headline: Most Test runs without a century
fields.standfirst: Have you any cricketing queries? Email asksteven@guardian.co.uk with your query.
fields.trailText: Has anyone made more runs in Tests without scoring a century than Zimbabwe's Alistair Campbell? asks Dean Ilott from Mexico City
fields.body:
Has anyone made more runs in Tests without scoring a century than Zimbabwe's Alistair Campbell? asks Dean Ilott from Mexico City

Going into the current (second) Test against New Zealand Campbell had made 1938 runs in 44 matches, with a highest score of 99. Only two men have made more without ever reaching a hundred: Chetan Chauhan of India has the most, with 2084 in 40 Tests (highest score 97), and Deryck Murray of West Indies made 1993 in 62 Tests (HS 91). So Campbell needs another 147 runs to take the record - but I'm sure he'd rather make a century. The highest aggregates for the other Test countries are: England - John Emburey, 1713 runs; Australia - Shane Warne, 1613; South Africa - Shaun Pollock, 1531; New Zealand - Dipak Patel, 1200 (he was once run out for 99); Pakistan - Wasim Bari, 1366; Sri Lanka - Chandika Hathurusinghe, 1274.

If a bowler makes a caught-and-bowled is it counted as a normal catch or is it tallied separately? asks Umaar Adeeb

Yes, return catches are included in the overall tallies for fielders. The player with the most caught-and-bowleds in Tests is Derek Underwood, the England slow left-arm bowler of the 1960s and 70s, who managed 20 - I suppose this shows he was a faster-than-usual spinner who could vary his pace well and persuade the batsman to play too soon. Anil Kumble, the Indian wristspinner, currently has 18.

Where can I obtain a copy of the autobiography of BS Chandrasekhar? asks Ziobho from India

The only book I know of about "Chandra", India's high-stepping legspinner of the 1960s and '70s, was a slim paperback called "The Winning Hand", written by Rajan Bala and published in 1993. You can buy it online for £3.95 (plus postage) from Sportspages, the UK bookshop: click here to go to their website.

Which England and Surrey cricketer was nicknamed "The Colonel"? asks Tony Platt

This was Ken Barrington, the popular and prolific Surrey and England batsman of the 1960s. He earned his name from his jaunty, almost military, bearing. Barrington was usually a dour batsman - he was once dropped by England for scoring too slowly - but he had a mischievous sense of humour and managed to reach no fewer than four of his 20 Test centuries with a six. Barrington, whose final batting average (from 82 Tests) was a tremendous 58.67, was forced to retire in 1968 after he had a heart attack. He later became England's assistant manager/coach, and was working in that capacity when he suffered another, fatal, heart attack during England's Test series in the West Indies early in 1981.

Is it true that three pairs of brothers once played in the same Test team? asks Mike Dixon

Yes, this happened at Harare in 1997-98, when Andy and Grant Flower, Gavin and John Rennie, and Bryan and Paul Strang all played for Zimbabwe against New Zealand. Zimbabwe's side also included Guy Whittall, whose cousin Andy was the 12th man. The match was drawn.

Will a new Australian edition of "Wisden Cricketers' Almanack" be published later this year? asks Michael Neill

The third edition of the Australian Wisden - similar to the original but green has just gone to the printers. It will be published in Australia at the end of October, and should be available in England around the end of November. You should be able to order it through wisden.com: keep an eye on our homepage for details.

Which was the last football ground to stage a Test in England? asks Neil Walters

Unless you count The Oval (which hosted the FA Cup final in the 19th century), the only English football ground which has staged a cricket Test is Sheffield United's Bramall Lane, where the third Test of the 1902 Ashes series was played (Australia won by 143 runs). Yorkshire played one or two matches each season there until 1973, when an extra stand was built and the ground was given over entirely to football, but no more Tests were held there.

He might be Sir Garfield now, but I thought that throughout his illustrious playing career GS Sobers was known as "Gary". But these days everybody seems to spell his name with a double R. Is this right? asks David Sugarman from France

We got the answer from the horse's mouth: David Frith, the founding editor of "Wisden Cricket Monthly", once asked Sobers how he spelt his first name, and was told it had two Rs. So from then on WCM has always printed his name as Garry.

Can you tell me the date of next year's Test in Barbados? asks Jason Fage

Next year's Bridgetown Test is due to start on March 29. It will be the third game of what should be a fascinating five-match series between West Indies and South Africa. They have played only one previous Test in the Caribbean (in Bridgetown in 1991-92, when West Indies came from behind to win), although they have played a full series in South Africa - in 1998-99, when West Indies won 5-0.

Steven Lynch is managing editor of Wisden Cricket Monthly. To read his previous column, which reveals when Bangladesh join the big boys, click here

fields.headline: Web research giants merge
fields.trailText: The merger between internet research giants Media Metrix and Jupiter Communications has been completed, leading to the formation of a new company, Jupiter Media Metrix. by Dan Milmo.
fields.body:
The merger between internet research giants Media Metrix and Jupiter Communications has been completed, leading to the formation of a new company, Jupiter Media Metrix.

The business will be the global leader in new economy market intelligence, specialising in analysis, research, measurement and consultancy. It will have more that 1,900 clients, 750 employees and offices across the Americas, Asia Pacific, Europe (as Jupiter MMXI Europe) and the Middle East.

The business will be split into five new units, including Media Metrix, AdRelevance, Jupiter Research, Jupiter Events and Jupiter Media Metrix International.

"Jupiter Media Metrix is poised to redefine the landscape of internet information services," said Tod Johnson, Jupiter Media Metrix chairman and chief executive officer.

Jupiter Media Metrix will trade on Nasdaq as JMXI.

fields.headline: Broadcast round-up
fields.trailText: Latest news from trade title Broadcast.
fields.body:
Channel 4 is finalising carriage agreements with NTL and Telewest for its forthcoming digital entertainment channel E4 and is on target for a January launch. Channel 4 is also hoping to launch three new film channels before the end of the year. But the paper claims talks with Sky about a closer alliance, possibly involving an equity swap, have stalled. E4 head of programmes Andrew Newman has unveiled the first programming details.

BBC1 and BBC2 controllers Lorraine Heggessey and Jane Root are poised to make some staff cuts as part of an editorial shake-up.

A legal battle involving Anglia TV's Survival and Australian independent producer Prospero Productions has been settled in the High Court. Survival Anglia was ordered to pay £1,000 damages and legal costs up to 24 September 1999. The independent had accused Survival Anglia of unfairly changing programme credits to make it look as though the production was made by a Survival Anglia subsidiary, Catspaw Productions.

Former BBC head of music entertainment Trevor Dann is in negotiations with Emap Performance Network about a job which would involve developing the company's TV interests.

fields.trailText: Latest news from trade title Press Gazette.
fields.body:
Press Gazette leads on You magazine editor Dee Nolan's new job launching Time Warner's UK version of In Style, as reported here yesterday.

Also on the front page is a report of Greg Dyke's expenses-cutting at the BBC (see Media Monkey) and a report on systematic deception of sales figures by three Birmingham Post and Mail newspapers. The irregularities came to light when Trinity Mirror bought the midlands group two years ago.

Detailed guidelines on science and health reporting have been launched aimed at ending scare stories.

Rupert Mellor, editor of the Times Metro supplement has quit, unhappy at the emphasis on mainstream content in its forthcoming relaunch.

Ian MacGregor, editor of Associated's freebie, Metro, has been made editor of the Scottish Daily Mail. He replaces Ramsay Smith who is thought to be planning a PR venture with former Daily Record editor Martin Clarke - a terrifying thought.

In an exclusive interview with Jane Proctor, the former Tatler editor reveals that she was relieved to leave and stayed too long at the magazine.

The Diary confides that Rupert Murdoch must approve of Rebekah Wade's News of the World name and shame campaign for he invited her and showbiz boyfriend Ross Kemp to join him at the Olympics. Sadly Ross is busy.

Channel 5 will be the first broadcaster to use the death of Paula Yates to spice up its schedules by rushing out a documentary special on the life of the TV presenter.

webTitle: Cinema greats to be re-released by BFI

fields.headline: Back for breakfast
fields.standfirst: Cinema greats to be re-released
fields.trailText: Great stars of the past such as Audrey Hepburn and Marilyn Monroe are to return to cinema screens, thanks to a project reviving vintage cinema. Classics like the 1961 romance Breakfast at Tiffany's and the 1959 comedy Some Like it Hot will be shown by the British Film Institute in London.
fields.body:
Great stars of the past such as Audrey Hepburn and Marilyn Monroe are to return to cinema screens, thanks to a project reviving vintage cinema. Classics like the 1961 romance Breakfast at Tiffany's and the 1959 comedy Some Like it Hot will be shown by the British Film Institute in London.

The aim of the project, being launched by bfi and backed by the management consultants Andersen, is to bring popular old films to new audiences. It will run over two years, with eight classic films, reproduced from master copies, being re-released.

Jon Teckman, bfi director, said: "Film deteriorates over time, especially if heavily used. There are no usable copies of any of these films in our collections. [They] are regularly requested by audiences at the bfi National Film Theatre, as well as by screen bookers and festival programmers around the world."

The films to be released in the first year are: Some Like It Hot, directed by Billy Wilder and starring Monroe, Jack Lemmon and Tony Curtis; Breakfast at Tiffany's, directed by Blake Edwards; Alfie (1966), directed by Lewis Gilbert and starring Michael Caine; and Don't Look Now (1973), directed by Nic Roeg and starring Julie Christie and Donald Sutherland.

fields.headline: Management upheaval sours T-Online/Deutsche Telekom relations
fields.trailText: The stormy relationship between German internet portal T-Online and its parent company, Deutsche Telekom, deteriorated further yesterday, amid rumours of a mass management walkout.
fields.body:
The stormy relationship between German internet portal T-Online and its parent company, Deutsche Telekom, deteriorated further yesterday, amid rumours of a mass management walkout.

T-Online's marketing manager, Ralf Eck, resigned yesterday, giving credibility to German press reports that the entire management board would leave at the end of the month. Chief executive Wolfgang Keuntje resigned suddenly last month after reportedly clashing with Deutsche Telekom chief executive Ron Sommer over T-Online's international expansion strategy.

A Deutsche Telekom spokesperson said Eck will be replaced by Burkhard Grassman, who was in charge of market communications and advertising at the telecoms company. The spokesperson added that T-Online's international strategy was on the right track, desperate the management merry-go-round.

T-Online's six million subscribers make it Europe's largest internet service provider, but the majority of customers are from Germany, leading to disagreements with Deutsche Telekom over the strategy for establishing a pan-European presence. T-Online recently bought French internet service provider Club Internet and Spanish portal Yacom, but the UK market remains elusive following the collapse of negotiations with Freeserve in June.

Analysts said Deutsche Telekom appears to be unwilling to offer financial support for T-Online acquisitions, frustrating management ambitions.

"As far as I can see it, this company has been managed by Deutsche Telekom, and the T-Online management have not had the room to do their job, which is expanding into Europe," said one analyst.

The management upheaval dampens speculation that T-Online will make another bid for Freeserve, despite acting chief executive Detlev Buchal's recent comments that the company will continue to expand abroad.

T-Online shares yesterday hit an all-time low of E25.60 (1539p) on Frankfurt's Neuermarkt Nemax 50 index, against their April flotation price of E27 (1624p).

The management upheaval dampens speculation that T-Online will make another bid for Freeserve, despite acting chief executive Detlev Buchal's recent comments that the company will continue to expand abroad. T-Online shares yesterday hit an all-time low of E25.60 (1539p) on Frankfurt's Neuermarkt Nemax 50 index, against their April flotation price of E27 (1624p).

webTitle: Fallon and Soul toast UK Budweiser win

fields.headline: Fallon and Soul toast UK Budweiser win
fields.trailText: Fallon and Soul have picked up a slice of the £15m UK Budweiser business, writes Jade Garrett.
fields.body:
Fallon and Soul have both been awarded a place on the Budweiser roster and will work alongside its main UK agency, BMP DDB, sharing a significant slice of the £15m UK business.

Debut work from the new agencies is not likely to break until next year and will focus on communicating the quality of the beer.

"Budweiser are keen to expand their roster of agencies and we may well see four or five campaigns running together," said a source close to the business.

The Anheuser-Busch-owned brand is attempting to match the template used for Budweiser in the US by widening the number of agencies that it uses in the UK.

Soul confirmed their appointment to the roster but no one at Fallon was available for comment.

fields.headline: Artism pockets extra £2m for launch
fields.trailText: Artism, the business tool aimed at the creative community, has secured a further £2m in funding, taking its tally to £3.5m.
fields.body:
Artism, the business tool aimed at the creative community, has secured a further £2m in funding, taking its tally to £3.5m.

The service, which has Griff Rhys Jones on its consultative council, launches on September 28, aiming to provide a support service for creatives in the TV, radio, film, performing arts, music and advertising industries. Listings on the website, Artism.com, include CVs and audio and video clips.

The latest round of funding, which came mainly from Japanese investment giant Nomura, adds to the £500,000 of seed capital and £1m invested by April this year by a consortium of Geoff Squire, founder of Oracle Europe, former AFBD chairman Christopher Sharples and James Sheldon, CEO of Immersive Education.

Artism was set up in December last year by William Brocklebank and Lucy Hungerford, who between them have backgrounds in media, law and the Internet, and now comprises 40 staff.

Mr Brocklebank, managing director of Artism, said: "It's encouraging for everyone at Artism that we've attracted some key investors despite the obvious changes in financial conditions for new economy businesses."

fields.headline: Fulcrum hires Holgate to head documentaries
fields.trailText: Independent producer Fulcrum TV has recruited a head of documentaries and a head of factual entertainment in a new expansion drive, writes Jessica Hodgson.
fields.body:
Independent producer Fulcrum TV has recruited a head of documentaries and a head of factual entertainment in a new expansion drive.

Beth Holgate, who series produced Talking Cure, about the Tavistock Clinic, and Crossing the Lines for BBC2, joins as head of documentaries.

Jonathon Holmes, who was series producer on the Can You Live Without series earlier this year for Channel 4 and pioneered the Real Holiday Show, joins as head of factual entertainment.

Fulcrum is seeking to expand its output and position itself as a content provider for broadband with Holmes, who has just finished work for Lion TV on esc@pe, an interactive adventure show to be screened on BBC1.

Earlier this year the company opened a regional production base in Sheffield.

webTitle: Channel 4 abandons E4 venture talks with BSkyB

fields.headline: Channel 4 abandons E4 venture talks with BSkyB
fields.standfirst: Channel 4 abandons E4 venture talks with BSkyB
fields.trailText: Channel 4 abandons E4 venture talks with BSkyB, reports David Teather.
fields.body:
Channel 4 is understood to have shelved discussions with BSkyB that could have led to the satellite business taking a stake in its new pay-television channel, E4.

The broadcaster has set a launch date for E4 of mid-January, and is close to agreeing deals with cable companies NTL and Telewest to secure distribution as part of their basic packages of channels.

Talks are continuing to finalise terms with ONdigital and BSkyB to gain carriage on their respective platforms.

Channel 4 held talks with a wide range of potential investors in the new channel but the most detailed are believed to have been with BSkyB, Paramount and Warner Bros.

One insider at the company said the final decision on whether to proceed with an equity partner had not been finally taken, but added that it was now likely to be launched as a wholly owned Channel 4 enterprise. The company had a growing sense of confidence that E4 would be a success despite earlier fears that going it alone would be more risky.

In May, Channel 4 outlined plans to invest £100m in the launch of E4 which will be an entertainment-based station. It will be used as the platform for the first run of Friends and ER, the popular American shows which Channel 4 paid £120m for last year.

Industry pundits view E4 as a direct challenge to Rupert Murdoch's Sky One.

E4 will be Channel 4's second foray into pay-TV. It now claims to have signed up 400,000 customers to FilmFour, which launched in November 1998 and screens art house movies.

FilmFour lost £20m last year, which chief executive Michael Jackson has said was on target with projections. FilmFour is expected to break even in 2003.

The discussions with BSkyB over a stake in E4 are understood to have included an exclusivity element that would have forced Channel 4 to keep E4 back from the cable companies and ONdigital for an agreed period. In return BSkyB would have injected capital into the business and taken a shareholding. E4 is now virtually guaranteed of being available to the entire pay-TV market from day one.

Channel 4 remains keen to develop a pay-TV racing channel, although a deal with course owners is not yet final.

fields.headline: BBC Worldwide denies masthead programming by stealth
fields.trailText: BBC Worldwide's deputy chief executive has denied accusations that a tie-up between Project G and Live & Kicking represents masthead programming by stealth, says Jessica Hodgson.
fields.body:
BBC Worldwide's deputy chief executive has defended the corporation against accusations that a tie-up between soon-to-be-launched Project G and Live & Kicking represents masthead programming by stealth.

Project G, due to launch in October, will target the teenage market and incorporate a celebrity focus.

Peter Teague told MediaGuardian: "The BBC doesn't carry masthead programming. We will never have a programme or a programme segment called Eve or G. We work quite closely with our colleagues on the licence fee-funded part of the BBC and we have spun magazines off programmes before, but this is not the same."

He said the idea came from Chris Bellinger, programme producer for BBC children's entertainment programming, who devised the idea of enhancing Live & Kicking's celebrity segment, Electric Circus. Teague said: "We then looked to see if there was a magazine idea accompanying it. We believed there was and we acted on it."

But some observers say BBC Worldwide is abusing its access to licence fee-funded content to distort the market.

Teague denied Worldwide is daunted by the fact that some magazines in the teenage sector saw double-figure circulation falls in the last ABCs. He said: "If anything, this should remind us that there's room for a strong challenger in the market. It suggests that some of the other titles in the market aren't delivering the goods."

He acknowledged that much of the decline in the teenage market coincided with the passing of the Spice Girls' heyday. "There's no doubt that no group could create the level of excitement that the Spice Girls created. Top of the Pops magazine's sales veered between 350,000 and 500,000, based on the group's fortunes."

Teague also acknowledged the impact of giving away cover-mounted gifts on magazine sales: "I think everyone in the industry wants to get away from this practise." But he did not rule out cover-mounting on Project G.

fields.trailText: Emap Performance Network has confirmed it is to launch a masthead TV show based around its Q music magazine brand.

Emap Performance Network has confirmed it is to launch a masthead TV show based around its Q music magazine brand.

The show, called QTV, will adopt a similar format to Kiss TV and The Box, allowing viewers to select videos from a playlist.

Other features will include Q&A, based on the magazine's Cash for Questions section, where readers or viewers submit questions to a celebrity, and Q Rated, Q's reviews section.

fields.headline: What marketing is not
fields.standfirst: Marketing is not, repeat not about gurus, writes Mark Ritson.
fields.trailText: Marketing is not, repeat not about gurus, writes Mark Ritson.
fields.body:
Marketing is possibly the most widely misunderstood business topic in the managerial world today. If I had a Euro for every marketing manager who secretly harbours an enormous concern that they do not really know what marketing is, I would be a fat Eurocrat living the highlife from Brussels to Berlin.

The problem of marketing ignorance stems not from the difficulty of the topic. After all, marketing as a topic is about as simple as it gets. The problem is that to understand what a concept like marketing means is one thing, to actually apply the marketing principle to your day to day business life is an milkshake of an altogether different flavour.

So, in brief. The philosophy of marketing revolves around a single, strikingly obvious idea. That idea is that we find out what people want before we start making and selling it. Yes, I know it sounds simple. But the devil, in this case, is not in the details. Rather the devil inhabits the real world of market orientation. A world where managers can recite huge swathes of marketing textbooks with mantra like passion...and yet when push comes to shove, they will continue to completely ignore the voice of the consumer when they actually make strategic decisions.

How can we account for this glaring mismatch of theory and practice?

Many managers seem to mistake market orientation for marketing orientation. Yes, there is a difference. In the former case, managers ask the marketing department what they think and then they find out what the consumer thinks about their products and services. In the latter, the manager asks the marketing department what they think and they answer for the market. In doing so they demonstrate the presence of marketing gurus, possibly one of the most pernicious problems in the marketing world.

There are no gurus in marketing. To be a guru suggests you have immense knowledge, knowledge that can answer the strategic questions that a firm encounters. In marketing the last thing we need is a marketing guru who thinks he or she knows what the market wants. The fact that they work for the company producing the product means they are just about the last person on earth who is likely to know how the customer is thinking.

The minute you sign up to work for a company you have also signed away any remaining sense of customer orientation. You are no longer a consumer, you are a producer. Producer and consumer may see the same product before them but the personal significance of that product could not be more different. The customer sees toothpaste. The brand manager sees the toothpaste too. But while the consumer then sees fewer trips to the dentist, clean teeth and fresh breath, the brand manager sees her career, her company car, her future social standing and perhaps her pension plan.

When a manager/guru confidently describes what the customer wants they are actually simply describing what they assume/hope/imagine the customer wants. One of the most humbling experiences for managers is to ask them how they think the customer thinks and then take them out onto the street to actually find out. The results are always revelatory. Another is to point out, in a room filled with senior marketing managers from a leading high-street bank, that not a single person in the room (barring yours truly) has ever had to actually purchase a mortgage because the bank provided them as a perk.

At London Business School we train our marketing rookies to avoid this potential pothole by instilling in them a single, simple phrase that wards off marketing guruism. That phrase is: " I am a tool". We make them say it over and over until our lecture halls resonate to the sound of it.

Typically, our MBAs spend the summer in internships with big blue chip organisations and, equally typically, some of them are asked by their managers to take a look at the latest company advertising, packaging, branding, price levels. They have MBAs in marketing after all - who better to suggest a strategic direction. It is in these situations that our MBAs, or at least the ones who have been paying attention, raise their hand meekly and declare: "I am just a tool". A tool that connects market with manufacturer. A tool that avoids speaking for the market and instead goes out to the customer to get real, lived consumer perspective. A tool that then brings that information back into the organisation and uses it to influence decision making.

No gurus. The only gurus in marketing are fools. Its all about tools. Different tools of course for different jobs. Sometimes you need a very powerful tool. Sometimes a very cost efficient one. Sometimes one that gets the job done super fast. Sometimes one that uses quantitative data. Sometimes one that uses qualitative data. But always a tool.

So repeat after me. What am I?

 Mark Ritson is assistant professor of marketing at London Business School.

fields.headline: Bid-Up TV seeks agency for launch
fields.trailText: Bid-Up TV, the digital satellite TV and online auction site, is looking for an advertising and media agency to handle its national launch.
fields.body:
Bid-Up TV, the digital satellite TV and online auction site, is looking for an advertising and media agency to handle its national launch.

webTitle: EMI unveils first online publishing deal

fields.headline: EMI signs first online publishing deal
fields.trailText: 8am: EMI has revealed details of a wide-ranging partnership with Peoplesound.com - the first deal of its kind in Europe, reports Amy Vickers.
fields.body:
Not content to rest on its laurels while it awaits EU regulatory approval on its £14bn merger with Time Warner, EMI has revealed details of a wide-ranging partnership with Europe's largest free music download website Peoplesound.com - the first deal of its kind in Europe.

The three-year exclusive tie-up means that Peoplesound.com can tap into EMI's global administration for its own artists or pass the artist on to EMI to sign while sharing joint ownership of that artist. While the deal is a non-cash deal, details of how royalties will be split between the two companies are not available.

Peoplesound.com has developed a database-driven tool to recognise which artists are the most popular on its site, helping it to decide which artists to sign up for its own online music publishing division.

"Publishers are moving more and more into new media but they have to make sure they build businesses that are attractive to both consumers and artists," said Ernesto Schmitt, president of Peoplesound.com, adding that Farmclub.com (Universal Music's attempt to do online music publishing) wasn't working for precisely these reasons. He added that it was very significant that a major label was partnering with an MP3 website, effectively recognising that MP3 will play a big part in the future of the music industry.

Commenting on the partnership, Helen Snell, analyst at ABN Amro, said: "It sounds like a very sensible deal from EMI's point of view - there's nothing to be lost as it's merely tapping into a new A&R source and it saves on EMI's legwork. The benefit will be that EMI gets to test something in the marketplace before having to sign up the artists."

webTitle: GWR offloads Classic Gold licences to indie producer

fields.headline: GWR offloads Classic Gold licences to indie producer
fields.trailText: Independent radio producer UBC Media has bought the 12 GWR Classic Gold AM licences from GWR Group in a £2.1m all-share deal.
fields.body:
Independent radio producer UBC Media has bought the 12 GWR Classic Gold AM licences from GWR Group in a £2.1m all-share deal.

The acquisition will lead to the creation of a new company, Classic Gold Digital, which will be 80% owned by UBC and 20% owned by GWR. The deal gives the company access to a digital simulcast channel. UBC has secured carriage on seven digital multiplexes.

UBC, formerly known as Unique Broadcasting, made its name as producer of the Pepsi Network Chart. The company sees the acquisition of the Classic Gold brands as a way to position itself as a content provider for digital radio.

webTitle: Wrongful arrest makes The Bill a turn-off

fields.headline: Wrongful arrest makes The Bill a turn-off
fields.standfirst:
Special report: policing crime
MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: The Bill's storylines rarely win plaudits for authenticity, but the ITV cop show appears to be so realistic that a man whose wrongful arrest left him too traumatised to watch it won £7,750 damages yesterday.
fields.body:
The Bill's storylines rarely win plaudits for authenticity, but the ITV cop show appears to be so realistic that a man whose wrongful arrest left him too traumatised to watch it won £7,750 damages yesterday.

Paul Stevenson, who was arrested during a post-match fight at a pub frequented by football hooligans, was yesterday awarded £5,000 for false imprisonment and £2,750 aggravated damages. He claimed that the ordeal was so bad that anything involving the police brought back terrifying memories.

"Even when I switch on The Bill on telly it brings it all back," he told a judge at Nottingham county court.

Mr Stevenson, 31, was cleared of all charges. He claimed that he was hit with a baton and twice bitten by a police dog during the incident, after an England match during the Euro 96 tournament.

He admitted watching the match at the Ruby Tuesday's bar in Nottingham, which police described in court as a well-known meeting place for hooligans. But he insisted that he was only among the crowd during the violence because he had become separated from his girlfriend and was trying to find her.

Although his attempt to win damages for malicious prosecution was thrown out, a jury upheld his claims for injuries and false imprisonment.

Judge Oliver James said: "Mr Stevenson brought this case as a citizen who had never been in trouble with the police before. He came here to clear his name, and he has succeeded. Citizens being wrongly arrested is quite wrong, and damages should be awarded for it."

Mr Stevenson, a father of two, said outside the court: "This is a vindication of what I said had happened. I am obviously delighted. I was totally innocent, but it could happen to anyone. I just hope the police will step back and think what they are doing before they jump in feet-first."

A police spokesman said last night: "The jury found that the officers had not fabricated their accounts of the incident. The judge said it was apparent from the jury's findings that the officers had been mistaken, but that they had not been dishonest."

An ITV source said: "This case shows how realistic and dramatic The Bill's storylines are. Millions of viewers watch it, and we hope Mr Stevenson recovers enough to be able to come back to Britain's favourite police show."

fields.standfirst: Juan Tomás de Salas, who has died aged 62, was the driving force behind modern journalism in Spain.
fields.trailText: Juan Tomás de Salas, who has died aged 62, was the driving force behind modern journalism in Spain. He founded a score of publications, ranging from weekly and daily newspapers to a women's and a motoring magazine, all of which introduced a refreshingly novel way of presenting serious information. fields.body:
Juan Tomás de Salas, who has died aged 62, was the driving force behind modern journalism in Spain. He founded a score of publications, ranging from weekly and daily newspapers to a women's and a motoring magazine, all of which introduced a refreshingly novel way of presenting serious information. More significantly, his newspapers strongly contributed to the spread of democratic values, even during the last years of the Franco regime. It was an achievement certainly not without risk.

Born into a middle-class family in the central Spanish city of Valladolid, he studied at the Complutense University of Madrid and began his remarkable career by running an underground newsagency in opposition to Franco. The young law student also tried to oppose the repression of the time through the tiny Frente de Liberación Popular. He was nearly arrested in 1962 but escaped to the Columbian embassy in Madrid, where he was granted asylum. Eight months later he went into exile in Columbia.

In Bogota, De Salas became a columnist for the daily newspaper El Tiempo. Mexican author Carlos Fuentes wrote in the Spanish daily El Pais that De Salas was a pioneer, who spread his warmth and concern and his talent for modern journalism in Latin America. But above all, De Salas wanted to return to Spain.

He moved to Paris, the centre of opposition to the Franco dictatorship abroad and as close to Spain as he could be. There he continued his journalistic and political activities and translated Hugh Thomas's book on the Spanish civil war. Then, seven years after his escape, De Salas returned to Spain. He founded a publishing company, Inpulsa, determined to prepare public opinion in Spain for the return of democracy. When, two years later, the regime allowed him to publish his weekly Cambio 16, it was an immediate success, becoming a symbol of the opposition, and a banner of liberal, democratic values. From time to time, Cambio 16 (cambio means change in Spanish and 16 referred to the number of shareholders) was censored - there were heavy fines or the confiscation of entire editions - but this only added to the interest of its growing readership.

De Salas wanted his paper to be both "popular" and "serious". And he achieved it. His monthly, Historia 16, launched six months after Franco died, maintained the same standard, with expert contributions on historic events written for the general public.

De Salas' dream, the publication of a daily newspaper, had to wait a little longer. But within a year of Franco's death, Diario 16 conquered the streets with a specially composed song which became a hit. The lyrics expressed a desire for national reconciliation and a liberal and civilised new society.

For 17 years he directed Cambio 16, which developed into a keen and lively newspaper. Unfortunately its commercial success did not last. The economic crisis and its consequences, together with internal strife, led to its dissolution. De Salas was forced to resign - debts had risen to £30m - and Diario 16 was put up for sale in 1993.

A tall, heavily-built man, de Salas radiated a youthful enthusiasm and natural gusto for the good things of life. He is survived by his Canadian wife, Barbara.

Juan Tomas de Salas, journalist, born April 30 1938; died August 22 2000

ITV has bowed to pressure from the Independent Television Commission and the government and agreed to reinstate its News at Ten bulletin.

From January 1 next year, ITV will show a news bulletin at 10pm for 20 minutes from Monday to Thursday. This will be extended in the run-up to the general election.

fields.headline: Ailing euro hits US profits
fields.standfirst:
Corporate America says high dollar and oil price are affecting results

Special report: Economic and Monetary Union
fields.trailText: Corporate America says high dollar and oil price are affecting results
fields.body:
The ailing euro fell to a record low against the dollar yesterday amid mounting evidence that the currency's weakness is hitting the earnings of American corporations.

McDonalds, IBM, Gillette and other big American producers have all issued profit warnings in recent days and, for the first time in recent history, business organisations are loudly complaining to US officials that the combination of the strong dollar and high oil price are too much to bear.

Gillette warned the market that the 20% drop in the euro would hit its earnings. Al though sales have remained strong, the plunging euro diminishes the value of profits.

But analysts said it was doubtful the administration would succumb to pressure for co-ordinated intervention by G7 nations to drive the dollar down for fear that it could ignite inflation.

"We do not believe they are ready for joint intervention at this moment; in fact the weight of prejudice and opinion is strongly opposed to intervention," said one New York-based analyst.

After hovering for most of the day near the lifetime low of 84.40 cents set in overnight trading on Tuesday, the euro finally dipped below it to 84.37 before recovering. It was also under pressure against the yen, heading towards 90 yen in late afternoon trading. "The pattern is the same over the past few days: first a fall, then some consolidation before more falls later," said Paul Bednarczyk at 4CAST.

Signalling that the euro's weakness is likely to be high on the agenda at this weekend's G7 meeting in Prague, Horst Koehler, managing director of the IMF, said the euro was "heavily undervalued".

"In my view, it is also clear that interventions cannot be a taboo because it is part of the instruments that any central bank or government has available. But interventions, and this is our experience of the 1980s and 1990s, have to work, and this is the issue."

Analysts say that while the Japanese might be prepared to jointly buy euros with Euro pean governments to boost its value, the US remains wary of failure because of the political fall-out in an election year.

The economics of intervention are also not clear cut.

Although profit warnings from the US show the strength of the dollar is inflicting pain on industry, some of the euro's weakness is justified by the slow pace of structural reform in Euroland, according to the view from Washington.

The euro drew no comfort from data showing another record US trade deficit in July. Analysts say it is likely to come under further pressure if the Danish government loses next Thursday's referendum on EMU membership.

webTitle: French win concessions but Britain stands firm

fields.headline: French win concessions but Britain stands firm
fields.standfirst: Special report: the petrol war
fields.trailText: Britain last night refused to consider harmonising fuel tax across the EU but came under renewed pressure to cut duty at home as France announced more concessions.
fields.byline: Andrew Osborn  in Brussels and  Jon Henley in Paris
fields.body:
Britain last night refused to consider harmonising fuel tax across the EU but came under renewed pressure to cut duty at home as France announced more concessions.

The French prime minister, Lionel Jospin, said he would introduce new fuel tax compensation measures next month.

The unexpected announcement makes it even more difficult for Tony Blair to refuse to review fuel tax in the light of last week's protests.

There was little progress, however, at an emergency meeting of EU transport ministers in Luxembourg attended by the transport minister, Lord Macdonald.

The European commission was pushing for some kind of EU-wide fuel tax but Lord Macdonald was unwilling even to discuss the matter.

"This meeting is about transport policy and not taxation," he said before talks began.

The meeting was called by France at the height of the fuel protests but it looked unlikely last night that it would produce any kind of significant agreement and many ministers said they thought it had been convened too late.

The European commission has launched an inquiry to see whether concessions granted by Belgium, France, Italy and the Netherlands breach EU state aid rules.

If they do, tax breaks and payments of state aid to truckers and others across Europe in recent weeks will have to be cancelled and repayment demanded.
