webTitle: Ex-aide of duchess in hospital after arrest

fields.headline: Ex-aide of duchess in hospital after arrest
fields.trailText: A former aide to the Duchess of York, arrested after her partner was found stabbed to death, was in hospital last night after taking a drug overdose.
fields.body:
A former aide to the Duchess of York, arrested after her partner was found stabbed to death, was in hospital last night after taking a drug overdose.

Jane Andrews, 33, had been sought by police since Thomas Cressman, 40, was found dead at the couple's home in Fulham, south-west London.

Yesterday she was spotted by a police officer in Cornwall and arrested on suspicion of murder. Sergeant Alan Mobbs, spokesman for Devon and Cornwall police, said she was found "in a distressed state".

She is thought to have taken an overdose of the painkiller ibuprofen but was still conscious when found. Police took her to Derriford hospital in Plymouth, where she was undergoing medical tests. She is expected to remain in hospital for some time.

Mr Cressman's body was found when a colleague visited his house on Monday. A postmortem examination showed that he died of stab wounds.

Police forces nationwide were notified on Tuesday that Ms Andrews was being hunted by the Metropolitan police.

Her white Volkswagen Polo was seen by a uniformed officer on a routine patrol at 6.45am yesterday. It was parked in a layby on the A38 near Liskeard.

Detective Chief Inspector Jim Dickie said yesterday that police were keeping an open mind as to the circumstances of the death.

Ms Andrews and Mr Cressman, who had been together for two years, had been on holiday in Italy and France.

Ms Andrews was the duchess's aide for nine years until 1997. Recently she has been a sales assistant at Theo Fennell jewellers in Fulham Road, London.
Press Association

fields.headline: Japan offers vouchers for cyberdolts
fields.standfirst: Net news
fields.trailText: Japan is planning to hand out almost £2bn worth of IT vouchers to lure its internet-allergic population on to the web.
fields.body:
Japan is planning to hand out almost £2bn worth of IT vouchers to lure its internet-allergic population on to the web.

The giveaway is part of a plan to reinvent Japan as the world's leading internet nation, but critics say the scheme merely throws taxpayers' money into cyberspace.

Under the proposal, the government will distribute 6,000 yen (£40) vouchers to about 30m people over the age of 20 which will cover half the cost of a course on how to become cyber-savvy.

Despite its reputation as a technological giant, Japan has a great deal of ground to make up. Only 13% of the population uses the internet. The prime minister, Yoshiro Mori, who recently confused IT with "it", sent his first email in June.

webTitle: Laura Ashley lifts curtain on a return to profit

fields.headline: Laura Ashley lifts curtain on a return to profit
fields.trailText: Laura Ashley came bouncing back to profit in the first half of the year as the fashion group shrugged off its frilly, floral image and extended successfully its home furnishings range.
fields.body:
Laura Ashley came bouncing back to profit in the first half of the year as the fashion group shrugged off its frilly, floral image and extended successfully its home furnishings range.

Yesterday it said like-for-like sales across all of its businesses in the first seven weeks of the second half of the year were up 14% on the same period last time.

Trading conditions remained "variable and unpredictable", and the company plans to close 36 of its 105 shops in Sainsbury's Homebase stores, although few jobs will be lost.

Laura Ashley plans to build up its own range of stand-alone home furnishing stores that would compete with the likes of Marks & Spencer and John Lewis. The first opened two weeks ago in South Woodford, Essex, and others will follow in Nantwich, Cheshire, and Nottingham.

Laura Ashley reported a pre-tax profit of £1.7m to July 29, which was slightly better than market expectations and a huge turnaround from the £7m loss incurred last time.

The comeback was achieved on turnover of £118.1m, down from £123.6m, which included five months' contribution from its US business, sold last summer for a nominal $1.

Clothes sales in the first half of the year were level with those of 1999 but home furnishing sales were up 20% as the company extended the space allocated to paints and furniture in existing stores.

The group trades from 279 outlets of which 216 are in Britain and 63 in continental Europe.

Around 60% of the company's stores have now been refitted with a more contemporary look and the full programme is scheduled to be completed within 18 months.

No interim dividend was paid and that position will continue for the short term.

The company says it wants to get back "substantially" into the black before it rewards shareholders but it promised that it had left the difficulties of the 1990s behind it.

The second half of the year started strongly with a 16% increase in garment sales, after no upward movement in the first half. A spokeswoman said: "We are much more contemporary now."

The shares closed down 1.25p at 19.75p on profit-taking.

fields.headline: PC dies after taking heroin
fields.trailText: A young policeman has died after injecting himself with heroin in what is believed to have been a first time experiment.
fields.body:
A young policeman has died after injecting himself with heroin in what is believed to have been a first time experiment.

PC Paul Weir, who had been with Greater Manchester police for just under three years, was found dead on Monday night, next to a note with instructions on how to take drugs intravenously.

Officers found heroin and drug taking equipment next to the body of the 25-year-old policeman at his home in Audenshaw, Tameside.

His colleagues at Elizabeth Slinger road station in Withington, Manchester, expressed their shock at his death.

Chief Superintendent Lil King, the commander of south Manchester division, paid tribute to PC Weir.

She said: "He has been described by his colleagues and superior officers as a mature officer with bags of common sense, who regularly showed his courage, determination and a tremendous sense of humour.

"He was an astute and capable officer who dealt with many serious crimes and his arrest rate was high."

PC Weir's parents, who live in Botswana, have flown to Manchester after learning of their son's death.

Police investigators are trying to establish how PC Weir got hold of the drug, but one line of inquiry will check on confiscated drugs.

It is understood that the officer had been deeply affected by the death of a pensioner in February. He was the first on the scene after the murder of Violet Higgins, who had suffered facial and head injuries.

She was discovered with the body of her husband, Michael, who had Parkinson's disease and had apparently committed suicide.

Two days before his sudden death, PC Weir had proposed to his girlfriend, Stephanie Percival, and the couple had planned to marry.

Greater Manchester police refused to speculate on the cause of his death until the results of a postmortem examination were known.

webTitle: Clintons finally in clear over Whitewater land deal

fields.headline: Clintons finally in clear over Whitewater land deal
fields.trailText: Hillary Clinton dodged a cloud lingering over her campaign for a seat in the senate yesterday when the six-year Whitewater real estate investigation found insufficient evidence for criminal charges against her or the president.
fields.body:
Hillary Clinton dodged a cloud lingering over her campaign for a seat in the senate yesterday when the six-year Whitewater real estate investigation found insufficient evidence for criminal charges against her or the president.

But Robert Ray, the independent counsel whose inquiry cost a record $52m, stopped well short of saying there was nothing to the allegations. "This office has determined that the evidence was insufficient to prove to a jury beyond a reasonable doubt that either president or Mrs Clinton knowingly participated in criminal conduct or had any knowledge of criminal conduct," he said.

Mrs Clinton said: "I am confident that not only have New Yorkers and Americans made up their minds, but there's nothing to the report."

Mr Ray's work was submitted to a panel of three judges and its contents will not be known in full for at least three months, well after election day in November.

A White House spokesman said: "Robert Ray is now the latest investigator to complete an examination into the transactions related to the Whitewater Development Co and conclude that there are no grounds for legal action."

While the main part of Mr Ray's investigation is now over, he is still considering whether to bring criminal charges against President Clinton in connection with the Monica Lewinsky affair. A grand jury has been empanelled in Washington and no decision will be made until after Mr Clinton has left office.

Fourteen other people were convicted in the course of the inquiry into the Clintons' failed real estate operations in Whitewater in 1978, including their friend Webster Hubbell and a former governor of Arkansas, Jim Guy Tucker.

Mrs Clinton's role, including the question of whether she helped to make documents disappear, was at the centre of Mr Ray's endeavours. Whitewater was to have been a holiday complex dominated by time-share units but the deal collapsed when a local bank owned by the Clintons' part ners, James and Susan McDougal, failed.

webTitle: New cancer link to power lines

fields.headline: New cancer link to power lines
fields.trailText: New evidence that high voltage power lines cause cancer by making particles of pollution stick to people's lungs has been uncovered by a team from Bristol University.
fields.body:
New evidence that high voltage power lines cause cancer by making particles of pollution stick to people's lungs has been uncovered by a team from Bristol University.

The team's research shows that car exhaust particles get an electrical charge from overhead power lines that makes them "sticky" - giving people living close to the lines two or three times the average daily dose of potentially damaging pollutants in their lungs.

David Henshaw of Bristol University said the discovery is the missing link that shows how power lines can cause cancer clusters - something the global electricity industry has spent millions of pounds researching without finding a conclusive answer.

His work is supported by Dr Alan Preece at the Bristol Medical School, whose independent research in the west country showed that people living up to 500 metres downwind of power lines have a 29% greater chance of contracting lung cancer. This finding matches the area where "sticky" particles from car exhausts drift downwind of power cables.

Both men believe that building new houses near power cables, or allowing new power lines near houses should be stopped until their research is investigated. A ban already exists in US and Sweden.

The scientists have been backed by William Hague, the Tory leader. Northallerton, in his constituency, has an unexplained cancer cluster next to a power line.

Work to find a link between power lines and cancer has been going on for 20 years, but scientists have been studying a different possible cause - the effect of the magnetic field created by the lines.

What Prof Henshaw's team found was not a direct effect on the body, but an indirect mechanical effect, which allowed the build up of pollutants in the lungs.

Measurements taken all over the UK and Europe showed that all power lines were surrounded by a corona of electrically charged ions. The older and rougher the lines, the greater the corona. Ions from the corona were carried downwind of the lines, attaching themselves to up to 15,000 particles per cubic metre of pollution floating past in the air.

The ions gave the particles an electrical charge and made them stick to surfaces. When they got into the capillaries in the lungs they were attracted to the surface and stuck.

Prof Henshaw said: "This would not happen if the lines were buried. We have the technology to do it , it is just more expensive."

Dr Preece, an epidemiologist in the oncology department at Bristol will tell Radio 4's Costing the Earth programme today that he looked at the incidence of cancer in the whole of the south-west of England to judge the relative risk for those living within 400 metres of power lines.

"We found an excess, particularly lung cancer, in that group of people, who had been living within 400 metres of a line at the time of diagnosis." He said the most surprising element was the cancers only occurred downwind.

Dr Preece would not discuss his findings in detail until they had been reviewed by other scientists but a report to the Bioelectromagnetics Society in Munich earlier this year said the excess was 29% - and that had taken into account the effects of smoking.

Mr Hague said that in his constituency he had eight cases of childhood leukaemia, liver cancer and other illnesses near a power line. After meeting Prof Henshaw, he said: "In respect to construction of new lines, National Grid should look carefully at new evidence before going ahead with more."

Dr John Swanson, scientific advisor to the National Grid, and advisor on electric and magnetic fields for the Electricity Association said he accepted that Prof Henshaw had shown that power cables affected airborne particles. "I do not believe he has shown that has a consequence for health."

"We have never said in a categorical way that power lines are safe, that simply would not be honest. What we say is that when you look at the totality of studies you come to the conclusion that the balance of evidence is that power lines do not have an effect on health."

fields.headline: Lone Concorde cleared for takeoff
fields.standfirst: Special report: the Concorde crash
fields.trailText: In what could be Concorde's final flight, an Air France jetliner will cross the Atlantic in lonely supersonic splendour in the next couple of days, arriving in Paris to an emotional welcome from ground staff.
fields.body:
In what could be Concorde's final flight, an Air France jetliner will cross the Atlantic in lonely supersonic splendour in the next couple of days, arriving in Paris to an emotional welcome from ground staff.

"We've all missed it and we'll be happy to see it back home again," said Lucien Guy, a mechanic at Roissy-Charles de Gaulle airport's QN hangar, where all the French carrier's Concordes have been in storage since the catastrophic crash in July.

A team of 12 French technicians has been in New York for a week preparing the return of Concorde F-BVFC, which was stranded at New York's JFK airport after Air France's decision to ground its five remaining supersonic jetliners.

France's civil aviation directorate, the DGAC, said yesterday it had given the airline permission to bring the miss ing plane home, exceptionally reinstating Concorde's airworthiness certificate, which was withdrawn by British and French authorities last month.

No passengers - not even Air France's chief executive, Jean-Cyril Spinetta, who is reported to have asked to make the trip - will be allowed on the flight, which is scheduled for today or tomorrow and will probably by captained by Edgard Chillaud, Air France's chief Concorde pilot.

The airline has had to obtain one-off clearance from all the countries along the Concorde's planned flightpath. "It's by no means a straightforward flight," Mr Guy said. "When a plane's been out of service for nearly two months, there's a danger of leaking joints in the fuel or hydraulic systems. We've flown out quite a few spare parts already."

The plane's right-to-fly was withdrawn after French accident investigators said it was likely that a single burst tyre triggered the chain of events that sent the Air France jetliner spiralling in flames into a hotel in the town of Gonesse on July 25, killing 113 people.

While aviation experts are working on safety measures that might allow the plane to fly again, and both Air France and British Airways say they are hopeful about its future, many industry observers say the legendary 31-year-old plane's years of commercial service are probably over.

webTitle: 'There's been a policy to portray us as violent'

fields.headline: 'There's been a policy to portray us as violent'
fields.standfirst: Special report: IMF and the World Bank
fields.trailText: Martin Shaw, 35, is an electrician from London. He has spent the last two years campaigning against genetic engineering and was deported from the United States for demonstrating.
fields.body:
Martin Shaw, 35, is an electrician from London. He has spent the last two years campaigning against genetic engineering and was deported from the United States for demonstrating.

He has been in Prague since June working with a group committed to non-violent direct action.

"I was in Seattle and saw how effective that model was of organising activists, and I learned that some of those lessons could be applied to the Czech situation. I believe that non-violent direct action can have a profound impact on the political process.

"The IMF and World Bank are architects of the global economy and I don't believe that the global economy is an accident. I'm really disgusted with the way that the media, including the Guardian, has dealt with Prague so far.

"There's been what I regard as a very deliberate policy, directed by both the Czech police and the government, to portray us as violent people who don't know the issues and are going to be involved in a random smashing up of Prague.

"It's a classic case of divide and rule. There are various scare stories coming out that are causing people to overreact, like telling people to get all the food, water and medication they need because it s going to be like world war three. People are genuinely scared. As a result, the question of violence is constantly being addressed as opposed to the real issues.

"The press has widely been reporting these lies, without checking what the real situation is.

"Everybody who has come out to Prague to campaign is very culturally sensitive, and we're conscious of the fact that we, as foreign activists, don't want to impose our will or working models on the Czech people. But in many cases we ve had more experience of different campaigns and large street actions, so what you ve got is this classic melting pot of ideas."

fields.headline: At this price?
fields.trailText: Executives at Airtours, Britain's largest tour operator, are feeling bullish. Yesterday the company announced it had acquired 50% of Hotetur Club, a 19-strong hotels group based in Majorca.
fields.body:
Executives at Airtours, Britain's largest tour operator, are feeling bullish. Yesterday the company announced it had acquired 50% of Hotetur Club, a 19-strong hotels group based in Majorca. This move, according to Airtours chairman David Crossland, furthers the company's strategy of expanding its "long term access to quality hotel capacity and securing accommodation in key destinations".

Hotels are "increasingly important for the long term success of major tour operators".

The company also identified ventures it does not want to be involved in, such as luxury cruises, and has disposed of its 50% stake in Costa Crociere for £350m, having bought it for £225m three years ago. Airtours will invest in its market of choice: North America.

However, analysts say that facing down the competition while investing heavily in Europe and the US will soak up cash.

One of the biggest drains on Airtours' profitability is German company Frosch Touristik, which lost £80m last year, when Airtours had only a small stake. Airtours, which was forced to issue a profits warning a couple of months ago because of losses at FTi, now has a 100% stake. Analysts predict, assuming improvements, FTi will lose £40m next year.

Missing out in the consolidation of the European market could also lead to difficulties. With German company C&N Touristik expected to buy Thomas Cook, analysts predict Airtours' preferred option of merging with C&N is unlikely.

Mr Crossland famously set up Airtours 37 years ago when working in a travel agency for £2 10s a week and changed the face of travel. There are many who bet he can do that again.

Analysts at UBS Warburg rate the stock a "hold" and say the share price of 246p is in line with expectations.

With profits expected to be down year on year, investors should be cautious.

fields.headline: Lesson for Labour
fields.standfirst: Sixth former tells of school shortages
fields.trailText: An A level student spoke of her "disgust" at the inadequate funding of her 1,700-pupil comprehensive school at the conference yesterday, saying ithad just one computer with internet access and out-of-date text books.
fields.body:
An A level student spoke of her "disgust" at the inadequate funding of her 1,700-pupil comprehensive school at the conference yesterday, saying ithad just one computer with internet access and out-of-date text books.

Jane Mabbut, from Milton Keynes, said she was also wary of pursuing a career as a teacher because of poor resources and static class sizes. The sixth former, studying politics, economics and AS levels in biology and psychology, said: "I am disgusted by the fact that I am deprived of some of the text books I need." She added: "Tony Blair has stressed the importance of the internet, and it is the way forward, yet in my school of 1,700 we have one computer with internet access."

 Phil Willis, the party's education and employment spokesman, said teachers had been swathed in red tape since Labour came to power: "Schools have been inundated with 73 consultation papers, 220 guidance documents, 58 data collection forms and 15 ministerial letters."

webTitle: Net workers log on to American Utopia

fields.headline: Net workers log on to American Utopia
fields.standfirst: Net news
fields.trailText: He works 10 hours a day, makes more than £70,000 a year, doesn't bother to take holidays, dresses as he pleases, has never been happier and is looking for another job. This 33-year-old, white, university-educated creature is, according to the first comprehensive survey of the industry, the typical internet worker.
fields.body:
He works 10 hours a day, makes more than £70,000 a year, doesn't bother to take holidays, dresses as he pleases, has never been happier and is looking for another job. This 33-year-old, white, university-educated creature is, according to the first comprehensive survey of the industry, the typical internet worker.

There is also a reasonable chance that his employer will arrange his dry cleaning, allow him to bring his dog to work, offer him free massages and give him stock options. And he still thinks people in other firms are doing better.

The profile of the typical internet employee has emerged from a survey carried out by the Industry Standard, the San Francisco-based news magazine of the internet economy. The typical worker, it appears, not only enjoys an income about three times the national average but also has the gall to enjoy himself.

Currently 2.5m people are employed by internet firms in the US and the results of the survey give plenty of reasons why so many people believe that the grass is indeed greener in Silicon Valley. Even after the economic downturn in April closed many of the over-optimistic start-ups, there is still a mood of enthusiasm and privilege among those still employed.

So what makes 51% of them"very happy"? "Challenging work" is given as the main reason and "salary" is unsurprisingly close behind. The respondents to the survey also listed working weekends and long holidays as indicators of the pleasures of the workplace. Only 13% were paid for the extra hours worked while 14% put in more than 12 hours' work on an average day.

"For the past two years, this workforce utopia has held the attention of everyone from Wall Street to Main Street," writes Maryann Jones Thompson in the Industry Standard's introduction to the survey.

"But it wasn't all about money. It was fun. What other job could a college graduate walk into at 10am wearing shorts and sandals? And spend days with his dog at his feet, working on projects that required real brain power - then leave at 9pm with a belly full of free food, a few happy-hour beers and a big fat check?"

The average income, consisting of salary, bonuses and commission, worked out at $104,000 with the average basic salary at $84,700. Given that around a third of the workforce is under 30 and often without family responsibilities, it is clear that for many new graduates - 88% of the workforce went to college - there is only one job in town.

Despite the recent influx of techno-migrants from India and other Asian countries, the industry remains predominantly white (83%) and around two-thirds male. The average age is 33.8

Internet firms know they must do all they can to keep their high-flyers, as only 20% say they are doing nothing to find another job and more than one in four reckon that by this time next year they will have a new employer.

More than two-thirds dress entirely as they please with 31% of them being offered a dry-cleaning service by their boss. Around 15% are offered free massages. Not that the jolly extras are to everyone's liking, with some complaining that the "non-stop party atmosphere" was almost as tyrannical as the old economy's tie-wearing deference.

In 1986, in his prophetic verse novel about Silicon Valley, The Golden Gate, writer Vikram Seth recounted how "...Silicon Valley / Lures to ambition's ulcer alley / Young graduates with siren screams / Of power and wealth beyond their dreams". The survey seems to confirm that the young graduates are still listening to the sirens, still dreaming and now may even have expert advice on how to deal with that ulcer.

fields.headline: Going home
fields.standfirst:
French journalists relive dramatic escape from Philippine rebels
Special report: Indonesia and East Timor
fields.trailText: Two French journalists abducted by Muslim separatists in the Philippines used the confusion created by a military attack on the guerrillas to escape, they said yesterday.
fields.body:
Two French journalists abducted by Muslim separatists in the Philippines used the confusion created by a military attack on the guerrillas to escape, they said yesterday.

Basking in the partial success of his military operation, the Philippine president, Joseph Estrada, said the assault on the Abu Sayyaf rebels on the southern island of Jolo would continue until the remaining 17 hostages held by separatists were free, despite reports of widespread civilian casualties.

Television journalists Jean-Jacques Le Garrec, 46, and Roland Madura, 49, who were picked up by an army patrol after their escape and whisked to safety in Manila, said a group of Filipino evangelist hostages were in good health. But they knew nothing about the remaining captives, thought to comprise three Malaysians, one American and one other Filipino.

"For the last four days, we've been very afraid because of the operations in the field," Mr Madura said. "It seems their [rebels'] safety and our own safety was very weak."

Speaking at a press conference with Mr Estrada and the Philippine army chief of staff, General Angelo Reyes, the Frenchmen said the chance to escape arose on Tuesday night because the rebels were unable to keep a close guard on their prisoners during the nightly moves made necessary by the military pressure.

"We took the opportunity of last night's move when we left at seven[pm] from the place we were," Mr Le Garrec said. "And when we got [to] a road, we took the opportunity of the deep darkness to escape."

He said the rebels tended to panic when crossing roads. "Everybody was afraid because getting across the road, we could be seen by the military control," Mr Le Garrec said. "In that big mess, we took the opportunity of jumping on the side. We hid for some minutes and then we ran on the road."

With no idea of where they were on the island, the two men hid in the jungle until it started raining at about 4am yesterday. "The noise of the rain gave us the opportunity of moving ourselves without being heard," Mr Le Garrec said. "We walked until day time, having the feeling that we were going towards [the town of] Jolo and expecting to meet the checkpoint."

They were, in fact, walking away from the town but eventually came across a military patrol. The soldiers took them to Jolo and then flew them out to the regional centre Zamboanga and on to Manila.

Mr Le Garrec said the rebels had taken such a liking to the two journalists that he began to fear they would not let them go.

"We were afraid that in the end they would keep us out of affection," Mr Le Garrec told his employer, France-2 television, by telephone.

He said the rebels sought them out after they withdrew to a corner of the camp.

"They got bored very soon and came to see us, saying 'No, no, come back with us, we want to chat, we are bored when you are not with us'," Mr Le Garrec said.

He said the rebels helped them cook and gave them rice. In return the journalists gave them cigarettes and goodies from the parcels that reached them from France.

"We had established a perfectly trusting relationship and they could not in any way imagine that we would play such a trick on them," he said.

He later said that he and Mr Madura would have been freed on Saturday if the military had not launched the assault. He said as far as he knew no rebel was hit, although many civilians were.

The French president, Jacques Chirac, who had been highly critical of the military operation, welcomed their escape with "joy and relief".

Mr Estrada said no effort would be spared to free the other hostages and end the crisis that began on April 23 when the Abu Sayyaf kidnapped 21 people from a Malaysian diving resort.

All but one Filipino of the original captives were freed after millions of dollars were paid in ransoms. The evangelists were captured when they paid the Abu Sayyaf to be allowed to enter their jungle lair to pray for the hostages. The two men free yesterday were seized on July 9 when they went into the rebels' camp to interview the hostages.

Mr Estrada ordered the military strike when the Abu Sayyaf, running out of foreign prisoners, seized three Malaysians from another resort island last week.

Jolo residents who fled to Zamboanga yesterday described how they had been caught up in the fighting. One woman said she saw 10 people die when the military bombed a wedding party.

fields.headline: Good day, bad day
fields.standfirst: Special report: Liberal Democrat party conference 2000
fields.body:
Good day

Charles Kennedy won over pupils at Bethany junior school in Bournemouth with tales of his own shortcomings as a schoolboy. "I wasn't good with figures, I liked words," he told them. "And there was an awful lot of Sammy Snake [a speech therapy game] in my life when I was your age."

Blush of the day

The Lib Dem leader will blush to learn that knickers bearing the legend "I [heart] Charles Kennedy" have been outselling all other political pants on the conference stalls. One of the few not to plump for the loyalist lingerie, however, was former London mayoral candidate Susan Kramer. Fresh from her successful motion on civil partnerships for homosexuals, she chose a risque yellow pair emblazoned with "Read my lips", and black knickers carrying Ann Widdecombe's memorable line about her one-time Home Office boss - "Something of the night."

Verdict of the day

David Howarth, 40, law and land economy lecturer, and leader of Cambridge city council: "The pensions debate went the way I think most people expected it to go. The media will portray it as a challenge to the leadership but that's rubbish. It was important because it was a discussion on the principles behind our policies."

Today

9.30am: Delegates discuss how best to protect the public from sex offenders

10.30am: Improving quality and capacity in the NHS

12pm: Party leader Charles Kennedy's speech to end conference.

fields.headline: Ofwat argument just won't wash
fields.standfirst: Pricing row could cause instability
fields.trailText: Puffs of steam are still coming out of the Office of Water Services, following a competition commission report last week. This reduced the price cuts imposed by the regulator on two small water companies, Mid Kent and East Surrey, igniting hopes across all the utility sectors that perceived regulatory aggression was at last being tamed.
fields.body:
Puffs of steam are still coming out of the Office of Water Services, following a competition commission report last week. This reduced the price cuts imposed by the regulator on two small water companies, Mid Kent and East Surrey, igniting hopes across all the utility sectors that perceived regulatory aggression was at last being tamed.

Now a row has broken out between Ofwat and various bits of the City over the competition commission's calculations on the water companies' cost of capital - important, since it directly affects the rate of return water companies are able to make for their shareholders.

Ofwat reckons the commission figures are as close as damn-it to the regulator's, implying that the Mid Kent and East Surrey ruling does not have a knock-on effect across the rest of the sector. Others have disagreed, helping (alongside bid speculation) to push share prices in the sector higher on hopes of a general re-rating of the sector's potential profitability.

So Ofwat, in turn, has now taken to sending out letters aimed at "correcting" any misleading impressions, pointing out the specific figures for cost of capital and blowing one final triumphant raspberry: "All companies in the industry had the opportunity to appeal against the price determinations in November last year and 23 out of the 25 chose not to do so. The time limit for such appeals has now passed."

This is quite extraordinary. It is only a couple of months since Philip Fletcher took over from Sir Ian Byatt as Ofwat's director general, but he seems to have got the wrong idea of what his job entails. It may be that the industry should never have been privatised. It might also be the case that water company managements will do everything in their power to smudge the true state of their finances and in the process maximise their profitability. And it is certainly true that the customers of water monopolies need protecting.

But to brag about "doin' 'em over" risks a complete breakdown in relations between the companies and the regulator. Worse, the creation of an an unstable industry, where the taps run dry.

On the face of things, the competition commission report says that Sir Ian's last price review was much too harsh. Rather than sneering, Mr Fletcher should be examining whether he needs to right a few wrongs.

Liffe at odds

There was more embarrassment for the London Stock Exchange yesterday. As one insider was briefing the media, indicating that one of four options to see off the unwanted approach from Sweden's OM Gruppen was a merger with the Liffe futures market, Liffe's chairman Brian Williamson was simultaneously telling anyone who would listen that a futures and cash market merger is not on the cards.

There is a simple reason for this. Most of Liffe's shareholders are also shareholders in the exchange, and a takeover would amount to Liffe's equity holders being asked to provide cash to buy themselves out as LSE shareholders.

Instead, Mr Williamson reckons, mischievously, that the exchange might adopt Liffe's technology - a system called Connect - and a full proposal to his opposite number, Don Cruickshank, is already in the post. Having almost been sunk by its rivals in Frankfurt last year (when the Germans used new technology to undercut the London futures market and stole a good portion of its business in double quick time) Liffe is busy reinventing itself as a technology company capable of helping other exchanges develop modern, online markets. The pitch to the LSE must have been irresistible.

That aside, Liffe is already pushing ahead with plans to launch things called stock futures (futures contracts on individual companies) early in the new year. This will further blur the demarcation between the two markets and the Liffe man does not rule out fully-fledged "cash" trading in individual stocks at some stage in the future.

Meanwhile, Mr Williamson has declined any interest in taking over from Gavin Casey as the exchange's new chief executive - although he still ranks as second joint favourite in a wide-open field, according to fixed-odds financial bookmaker Blue Square.

fields.headline: Opel fined £28m by EC
fields.standfirst: Brussels clampdown on cross-border sales ban
fields.trailText: Opel was yesterday fined £28m by the European Commission for deliberately preventing customers from Britain and other European countries from buying cheap new cars in the Netherlands.
fields.body:
Opel was yesterday fined £28m by the European Commission for deliberately preventing customers from Britain and other European countries from buying cheap new cars in the Netherlands.

The fine is the fifth highest ever imposed on an individual company for breaking EU anti-trust rules and is a sign that Brussels is getting tough with car makers who try to stop cross-border sales. The EC is in the process of investigating DaimlerChrysler, Peugeot and Renault for similar reasons. Volkswagen was fined a record £62m in 1998 which was reduced on appeal to £55m.

Prices in the Netherlands are substantially lower than those in countries such as Britain, France and Germany. In Britain Opels are sold under the Vauxhall badge and are considerably more expensive than in the Netherlands. The EC yesterday disclosed that Opel Nederland, a subsidiary of General Motors, had deliberately "developed and pursued a strategy" to restrict sales to anyone living outside Holland. It decided to investigate after receiving a number of complaints from German consumers. EU anti-trust commissioner Mario Monti said: "Such measures constitute a very serious infringement of European competition rules and must be dealt with severely.

Opel stopped cross-border sales by threatening to withhold bonus payments from dealers who sold to non-Dutch customers between 1996 and 1998, a powerful weapon to ensure that they fell into line. Such bonuses represent an important element of a dealer's profit margin.

Dealers close to the border were particularly affected after they witnessed a huge demand for cars from other European buyers.

The EC gathered evidence against Opel in a series of high profile inspections and raids in the Netherlands.

It opted for a smaller fine because the infringement had continued for just 17 months compared to Volkswagen's three years.

Opel has three months to pay the fine and can appeal. A company spokesman said yesterday it was disappointed with the ruling and would look into the matter thoroughly.

fields.headline: Probation service gets more staff
fields.standfirst: Special report: policing crime
fields.trailText: An extra 4,500 probation staff - an increase of one-third in the number of frontline posts - are to be recruited over the next three years, the Home Office minister, Paul Boateng, announced yesterday as part of the government's attempt to arrest the rising crime rate.
fields.body:
An extra 4,500 probation staff - an increase of one-third in the number of frontline posts - are to be recruited over the next three years, the Home Office minister, Paul Boateng, announced yesterday as part of the government's attempt to arrest the rising crime rate.

The extra staff are to be financed as part of a £500m programme designed to cut the 56% reoffending rate of convicted criminals by a further 5%.

Mr Boateng told a probation service "what works" conference in Manchester that the staff and money were to be invested in developing programmes to tackle the root causes of criminal behaviour. The extra 4, 500 staff would include 1,500 probation officers, 2,500 probation service assistants and 500 support staff.

"The research evidence from both the prison and probation service is that the accredited programmes do work, with each achieving reductions in offending of the order of 15%," Mr Boateng said.

Among the programmes are a "think first" reasoning and skills course, and others tackling sex offending, violent behaviour by women and persistent drink-driving. Some 10,000 offenders are expected to undergo such programmes next year, rising to 30,000 a year over the next three years.

A new target is also being set to improve the reading and arithmetic skills of offenders.

Mr Boateng said 80% of jobs needed at least the literacy and numeracy skills of an 11-year old, but 40% of those under probation service supervision lacked even those skills. He wanted to see 12,000 offenders a year achieve at least this level by 2004.

He also revealed that Lord Birt, the former BBC director general, has been asked by the home secretary, Jack Straw, to review which court punishments will most cost-effectively reduce crime.

webTitle: City jobs at risk in Chase merger

fields.headline: City jobs at risk in Chase merger
fields.trailText: Hundreds of City jobs may be lost as a result of Chase Manhattan bank's £23bn takeover of US rival JP Morgan.
fields.body:
Hundreds of City jobs may be lost as a result of Chase Manhattan bank's £23bn takeover of US rival JP Morgan.

The two companies predicted up to 3,000 posts would be cut worldwide from its investment banking side but refused to speculate on how many would disappear from London or the likely timescale.

Bill Harrison, who will be chief executive of the combined group, admitted it was an uncertain time for staff but insisted final decisions had not been taken.

There was "some natural tension" among staff but they still felt it was a "wonderful strategy move" for the company.

"We have honestly not come up with a head count ... This is not about massive lay-offs, it's about growth."

The deal, announced last week, sees Chase paying 3.7 of its shares for each JP Morgan share. The combined group, to be called JP Morgan Chase & Co, will be split into two sections: retail, which is Chase's sole domain, and investment, involving both companies.

The two companies employ 95,000 staff, although only the 32,000-strong investment side will be affected by job cuts. Of them, 11,700 are based in London.

The new group's chairman designate, Sandy Warner, at present JP Morgan's chairman and chief executive officer, said agreeing to sell was the only way to push the business forward.

Speaking alongside Mr Harrison, on a visit to brief London staff, he said: "Every firm in this business is talking to each other, but not always about merging. For the growth opportunity, there is no better partner than Chase."

The two said retaining key members of staff would be a priority.

fields.headline: News in brief
fields.trailText: Veterans stage pay blockade
fields.body:
Veterans stage pay blockade

Russian servicemen back from service in Chechnya blockaded the Rostov headquarters of their commanding officers yesterday in protest at their lack of pay.

Around 30 of the soldiers, who signed up for military service voluntarily, stepped up their protest after a month of being ignored as they staged hunger strikes, picketed the commanders' offices and slept in the open.
Ian Traynor, Moscow

More violence in Kashmir

Pakistan and India both claimed to have inflicted heavy losses when they exchanged artillery and mortar fire on the frontier in Kashmir for the third day running yesterday.

Pakistan said seven civilians were killed and 11 hurt when India fired 600 shells on Dudhnial in northern Kashmir.
AP, Islamabad

Bangladesh top of assault table

Around 47% of Bangladeshi women are subjected to violence by their partners, sometimes including induced suicide, the UN population fund said yesterday.

Violence against women was recorded at 40% in India, 29% in Canada, 22% in the United States and 20% in South Africa, the report said.
Reuters, Dhaka

MP urges ban on sexy sports

Kuwaiti politician Waleed al-Tabtabaie wants Olympic sports including women's beach volleyball and synchronised swimming to be banned from state television due to "flagrant scenes which are unacceptable".
Reuters, Kuwait

Putin meets Solzhenitsyn

President Vladimir Putin visited Alexander Solzhenitsyn, one of the most famous Soviet dissidents, at the writer's Moscow mansion yesterday. The Kremlin gave no reason for the meeting.
Reuters, Moscow

webTitle: War crime trial convicts Serb of murder and rape

fields.headline: War crime trial convicts Serb of murder and rape
fields.standfirst: Special report: Serbia
fields.trailText: In the first war crimes trial in Kosovo, a Serb student was yesterday sentenced to 20 years in prison for murder and rape committed during the crackdown on ethnic Albanians by Yugoslav forces last year.
fields.body:
In the first war crimes trial in Kosovo, a Serb student was yesterday sentenced to 20 years in prison for murder and rape committed during the crackdown on ethnic Albanians by Yugoslav forces last year.

Milos Jokic, 21, was found guilty of killing Rexhep Emerllahu, 27, ordering the killing of another ethnic Albanian and of raping an ethnic Albanian woman. He was also found guilty of illegal possession of arms.

Prosecutors had levelled a charge of genocide against the student, arguing that a single ethnic group was targeted but he was convicted of "war crimes against civilians", and not of genocide.

His lawyer said he would appeal against the verdict. "Without any reason they have sentenced a young boy with the harshest verdict," Zivojin Jokanovic said after the trial. "This is shameless sentencing in order to satisfy an excited public."

Emerllahu was killed on May 9 1999, when returning home to collect food during Nato's 78-day bombardment of Yugoslavia. Residents had fled the village in the face of a Serb crackdown.

Prosecutors had accused Jokic of running a paramilitary gang that terrorised ethnic Albanians in the village of Vrban, about 40 miles south of the capital, Pristina.

A French judge, Patrice de Charette, joined Kosovo Albanian judges for the hearing under a United Nations programme designed to guarantee impartiality. But all but one Serb witness refused to testify, citing fears for their safety, defence lawyers said.

The verdict and sentence come six weeks after a court in the same Kosovo town, also attended by Mr de Charette, cleared three Serbian men of murdering an ethnic Albanian last year a month after the United Nations took over the province.

It was the first time the UN-run Kosovo courts had acquitted a Serb charged with killing a member of the majority Albanian population in the region. The verdict on Miroljub Momcilovic, 60, and his sons Jugoslav, 32, and Boban, 25, pleased international observers who said the case had become a test of the ability of the courts to deliver impartial justice.

The Momcilovics were accused of killing Afrim Gagica in a shootout outside their house in July last year, after a gang of ethnic Albanians tried to storm their home.

The United States eventually admitted that one of its peacekeeping soldiers had shot Gagica, but has still not explained why it took months to take responsibility. The delay and the initial refusal of ethnic Albanian judges to admit key video evidence put the fairness of the trial at risk, observers said.

War crimes trials of 15 other Serbs were stymied earlier this month when they escaped from a UN-run detention centre in Mitrovice. Bernard Kouchner, Kosovo's UN administrator described it as a catastrophe. The centre had only four poorly trained foreign guards instead of the necessary eight, and there was no alarm system.

Meanwhile, in a further escalation of violence among Albanians in the run-up to Kosovo's elections next month, a regional commander of the Kosovo Protection Corps was found murdered yesterday.

The KPC grew out of the disbanded rebel Kosovo Liberation Army. No motive was immediately clear for the reported killing of Skender Gashi, a leading commander of the KPC's 2nd battalion.

fields.headline: A Country Diary: Highlands
fields.body:
Problems with transporting poultry and other stock were highlighted for us recently by two incidents. The first came about because the last of our silkie hens, a small black one, died of old age. Although we'd resolved to run down the number of hens, ducks and geese, it seemed strange not to have silkies. We're still getting eggs from the ducks and geese, but the smaller silkie eggs have a different taste. So we decided to get seven silkies, and refurbished two hutches and runs, but weeks went by and all our usual contacts in the poultry world failed us.

In the end someone went on the internet for us and came up with a list. A call to a carrier in Inverness informed me that no carriers in the Highlands would take livestock because of EU regulations. A call to the nearest railway station told me they could only take day-old chicks. The last contact was to someone 100 miles or so away, but they would be willing to meet us half way. By then we knew a lot more about silkies: there are five basic colours; they're classed, surprisingly, as Large Fowl; and there is a Silkie Club of Great Britain, founded in 1898. We waited until they could be sexed and then picked up seven 12-week-old silkie hens. Two were gold, two partridge and one each of black, white and blue. We'd forgotten how good it feels to have young birds around, although one of the six dachshunds does not approve.

The second incident started when I found a racing pigeon in the drive. It was so weak, it let me pick it up, and was soon in a cardboard box, eating and drinking. After looking at the ring I rang the pigeon society in Gloucester and was told the owner lived in Leicester. The pigeon had been released at Lerwick in Shetland and had won many prizes in the past. Again, no carrier could be found in the Highlands, and one eventually drove up from way down south.

A Country Diary has moved from Comment.

webTitle: MPs lead activists in pensions outcry

fields.headline: MPs lead activists in pensions outcry
fields.standfirst:
Revolt averted after emotional debate

Special report: Liberal Democrat party conference 2000
fields.trailText: The Liberal Democrat leadership yesterday deployed its big guns to squash a determined attempt by grassroots activists and several MPs to strengthen the party's policy for pensions by restoring the link to average earnings which Margaret Thatcher severed 20 years ago.
fields.body:
The Liberal Democrat leadership yesterday deployed its big guns to squash a determined attempt by grassroots activists and several MPs to strengthen the party's policy for pensions by restoring the link to average earnings which Margaret Thatcher severed 20 years ago.

It produced the most impassioned debate of the 2000 Lib Dem conference in Bournemouth in which the party was clearly torn between its heart and its head, but finally drew back from embarrassing Charles Kennedy with a vote which critics warned would prove costly and politically damaging.

Heavyweight policy analisyts including Professor Steve Webb, Lord Russell, Lord Goodhart and Paddy Ashdown's policy chief, David Laws, were wheeled out to crush the revolt which would have left the party open to charges of a multi-billion pound hole in their election sums. Mr Kennedy's team plans to enter the coming election with a commitment to raise the basic state pension by "at least £5 a week" with a further £5 for the over-75s and a £10 top-up at 80, where some of the most acute poverty exists.

The official plan would cost £3bn and be paid for by a 50% tax rate on incomes above £100,000 a year. "Honest, fair and long overdue," the conference was told.

But it immediately became clear that many delegates were unhappy with what one called a "weak and timid"gesture. MPs, including Paul Burstow, the party's spokesman on the old, and Archie Kirkwood, chairman of the Commons social security committee, joined in demands that the earnings link be restored.

Mr Kirkwood, MP for Roxburgh and Berwickshire, said:"This issue is less about money. It's more about the importance of giving dignity back to a generation that has paid its dues." Mr Burstow said more and more old people are selling their homes to pay for care and 400,000 more now live in poverty.

But other delegates and the leadership's allies - who had been organised by Lord Russell, social security spokesman in the Lords - warned that, while the sums might be affordable in the short-term, they might bankrupt the system in a few years time.

Lord Russell urged a compromise - later adopted by the conference - which would set up an independent pensions authority to report annually to government on what could be afforded, taking into account pensioner poverty, national income and affordability. Urging them not to repeat William Hague's mistake he asked: "We can afford it now, but for how long?"

webTitle: It's time for sex, says the internet

fields.headline: It's time for sex, says the internet
fields.standfirst: Net news
fields.trailText: Mobile phone text messages saying "It's time to get into bed" and "I'm ready and waiting" may not be from a passionate partner but from an internet service alerting couples as to when they are most likely to conceive.
fields.body:
Mobile phone text messages saying "It's time to get into bed" and "I'm ready and waiting" may not be from a passionate partner but from an internet service alerting couples as to when they are most likely to conceive.

The service, launched today by motherandbaby.co.uk, will tell women "It's time to get to bed - the next four days are your most fertile", while those sent to men will include "I'm ready and waiting", "Tonight's the night" and "I've got my lucky knickers on".

The website's editor, Sarah Stone, said: "Trying for a baby can have a devastating effect on a couple's relationship. For many the tension leads to arguments, sex becomes robotic and the whole relationship can become less romantic.

"We want to put some of the fun back into conception and help couples achieve their dreams.

"Once the egg is released into the fallopian tube, it can only be fertilised within six to 24 hours. However, as sperm can survive in the female reproductive tract for at least five days, the best time to make love is in the five days before you ovulate and on the day of ovulation itself.

"With all the things going on in people's lives today, it's easy to forget exactly when this fertile period is."

fields.headline: Hear this
fields.trailText: Fischer-Dieskau Night/The Wrong Leader?
fields.body:
Radio 3's evening is devoted to a Fischer-Dieskau Night (7.30pm, Radio 3), with the accompanist Iain Burnside presenting recordings and interviews celebrating the 75th birthday of one of the 20th century's most remarkable baritone voices. There is no shortage of material: with a repertoire of 1,000 Lieder, Dietrich Fischer-Dieskau has made more recordings than any singer in history. His personal obsession is with Schubert's music. "That wonderful natural flow has accompanied my whole life."

When James Callaghan surrendered the Labour leadership in 1980, Dennis Healey attracted 25 per cent more of the Parliamentary party's votes than Michael Foot - but fell 23 short of the required absolute majority. With the party in turmoil and leading members preparing to jump ship, the second ballot a week later saw Foot scrape home by 10 votes. What tipped the balance? Steve Richards spills the beans in The Wrong Leader? (8.0pm, Radio 4).

fields.headline: Animal Olympics
fields.standfirst: Last night's TV:  Nancy Banks-Smith
fields.trailText: Animal Hospital In Oz/Coronation Street/EastEnders
fields.body:
I once heard a koala keeper at London Zoo say "I have a soft spot for marsupials. Nothing that stupid should be allowed to survive on the planet. But they come from Australia."

This was strikingly illustrated in Animal Hospital In Oz (BBC 1). A koala, who was the loser in a treetop fight, fell 30 feet and knocked himself out. The Friends of the Koala were looking after him. Australia does indeed seem endearingly endowed with what George Bush once called the spotted owl crowd, people helping animals hanging on for dear life.

Finding the koala insensible at her feet, one kindly lady rubbed his chest to try to get him going. The effect, as is often the case, was gratifying. The Friends of the Koala assured us that he was now full of beans. This required the eye of faith. It is difficult to distinguish between a stunned and an unstunned koala. The koala clung to a eucalyptus. He did not blink. He did not stir. No hair on his big, round, fringed ears moved.

Even for a veterinary programme, marsupials seem peculiarly prone to accidents. I saw a vet in an Australian soap ministering to a wombat on a table with the usual cheery assurance that "He'll be right!" In fact, he fell off immediately with a rather solid thud. A wombat looks like a guinea pig which has been inadvertently radiated in a low-budget movie. Huge and, like koalas, not as cuddly as you expect...

When approaching a wombat, try to think in terms ("Get her by the back legs!") of a rugby tackle.

I was pleased to see the widely promoted Sydney Zoo at last. Wherever you turn at the Olympics, it is advertised. On the swimmers' starting blocks, on the archery green, on the presenters' table. It is so whistle-worthy that they always add an extra "o", as in "Sydney Zooo".

I confess I expected a bit more than a one-eyed ichidna. An ichidna is a hedgehog with attitude ("Quickly! Try to get your hands between his legs.") This one gave the benevolent Rolf Harris ("Listen, kid, I'm on your side") something to remember him by ("Oh! Ah! Oh!"). Like Mrs Patrick Campbell, marsupials seem to be sinking ships, firing on their rescuers.

This week, there are palpably decent people arriving at police stations in droves, confessing to murder. It is a sore trial for the peelers, as Jim McDonald calls them.

In Coronation Street (ITV) Jim turned up at Weatherfield nick in proudly polished shoes and a regimental blazer to confess that he killed Gerald Quigley. You felt for the little peeler on duty. Jim, reared up on his hind legs, reminds you of those bears which stroll into Churchill, Manitoba every year as if they owned the place.

The unlamented Jez was an all-round bad egg (not to be confused with the blameless Father Gerald Quigley, who wrote to Wogan protesting his innocence). He died after a fight with Jim, who's now under arrest for manslaughter.

"Tomorrow's the Big House. Is that the crack?" It is often quite difficult to grasp what Jim is on about. It's best to agree with him and leave before he gets on to "Tell me this and tell me no more."

At the Rovers, Rita - in Witch of Endor mode and a wasp-coloured cardigan - prophesied that he would not be drinking there again. Jim has ordered his last pint of bitter. It's the porridge of adversity and the water of affliction for him now.

Tomorrow in EastEnders (BBC 1) Dot, having helped her old friend Eth to die - at Eth's insistence - will arrive at Walford nick to confess. And she will be looking, in her own wild-eyed and gaunt way, just as unnerving as Jim.

Order your Jim And Dot Are Almost Innocent T-shirts now.

webTitle: TV guide: The price is right

fields.headline: The price is right
fields.standfirst: Which of these proposed 70s sci-fi remakes will do best at the US box office?
fields.trailText: Which of these proposed 70s sci-fi remakes will do best at the US box office?
fields.body:
Westworld ...................8-15

Logan's Run ...................7-4

Rollerball .......................4-1

Solyaris .........................6-1

Test Pilot Pirx .................8-1

The 70s produced some of the most consistently intelligent and weirded-out SF around. But will the future flicks still score at the box office more than two decades later?

Westworld (pictured: Yul Brynner from the 1973 original) features an amusement park where rich vacationers go to live out their fantasies. "This has to be favourite, simply because plans and casting are so far advanced", says Sean Boyce, entertainment odds compiler at Ladbrokes. The high-profile proposed cast includes Chris Klein, LL Cool J and Jean Reno, with Joel Silver to produce.

An obsession with youth is the premise behind Logan's Run. To maintain population balance, computers in a post-apocalyptic Washington have decreed that everyone must die at 30. "The original has such enduring appeal that any remake will have to be extra special in order to avoid unfavourable comparisons", says Sean. Writer/director Skip Woods plans a return to the novel's death-at-21 theme (MGM upped the age to 30 to ease casting problems.) "If they do pull it off, it could be a monster at the box office."

The year is 2018, and a violent futuristic game called Rollerball is now the world's recreational sport. It's used to control the populace by demonstrating the futility of individuality. "The classic combination of sport and gladiatorial violence has tremendous appeal. A competent remake has got to do good business with the right star."

Solyaris, meanwhile, is a seminal piece about psych-ology and alternative realities. But according to Sean, "The plot could be a bit too cerebral for the modern audience."

"Finite nonlinears", robots closely resembling human beings, get a test run in Test Pilot Pirx. "Like Solyaris, it's a neat idea for a novelette, but might struggle to hook a contemporary multiplex crowd."

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Appeal by Paula Yates lawyer
fields.body:
Appeal by Paula Yates lawyer

The lawyer of Paula Yates, the television presenter found dead in her home on Sunday, yesterday appealed for her family to be left in peace. Solicitor Anthony Burton was speaking after the inquest into Yates's death was opened at Westminster coroner's court.

Big black hole at centre of things

US astronomers claim to have got the exact position of a black hole at the centre of our galaxy, the Milky Way, it was disclosed today. It is 26,000 light years away and has a mass equivalent to nearly 3m suns.

Whisky sells for £4,400

A bottle of 72-year-old whisky sold for £4,400 at a Sotheby's auction in London yesterday. The Macallan Fifty Year Old OB was one of 500 distilled in 1928 and bottled in 1983 by Macallan-Glenlivet at Craigellachie.

Pilots' strike strands tourists

Hundreds of tourists were stranded at airports in the UK and Cyprus for up to 13 hours as pilots for Eurocypria, a charter firm run by Cyprus Airways, held a 24-hour strike in protest over promotion opportunities.

Airship to spot landmines

An airship which is normally used for filming sports events is to be deployed by the UN to help locate unexploded bombs and mines in Kosovo. The airship, Mineseeker, is owned by the Lightship Group, based in Telford.

Family of five barred

Five members of a family who harassed and abused their neighbours have been made the subject of anti-social behaviour orders, West Midlands police said. Terence Tift, 43, his wife Sandra, 45, and their children Jason, 23, David, 15, and Gemma, 14, have been barred from areas of Walsall for two years. Magistrates in Walsall allowed the teenagers to be named.

The Macallan Fifty Year Old OB was one of 500 distilled in 1928 and bottled in 1983 by Macallan-Glenlivet at Craigellachie. Pilots' strike strands tourists Hundreds of tourists were stranded at airports in the UK and Cyprus for up to 13 hours as pilots for Eurocypria, a charter firm run by Cyprus Airways, held a 24-hour strike in protest over promotion opportunities. Terence Tift, 43, his wife Sandra, 45, and their children Jason, 23, David, 15, and Gemma, 14, have been barred from areas of Walsall for two years. fields.headline: Watch this
fields.trailText: The Wings Of The Dove/Heat/The Taking Of Pelham 123 /M
fields.body:
The Wings Of The Dove
(Iain Softley, 1997) 1.25am, Sky Premier

Softley and scriptwriter Hossein Amini create a surprisingly modern romantic drama out of the Henry James novel. Set in Edwardian London and Venice, it has Helena Bonham Carter remaking her prim Merchant-Ivory image: as well-to-do Kate, she is involved in a heated affair with lowly Merton (Linus Roache), and is prepared to act disgracefully to keep both him and her position in society. Alison Elliott plays her unfortunate friend; Elizabeth McGovern, Charlotte Rampling and Michael Gambon are high-class support.

Heat
(Michael Mann, 1995) 10pm, FilmFour

Mann's masterly gangster movie uses the familiar tale of cop chasing cunning criminal to set up a deadly contest between two of the screen's most charismatic performers: Al Pacino's driven detective cat-and-mousing with hood Robert De Niro in the coffee shop is a classic scene, both recognising they're two of a kind. The acting throughout (cast includes Val Kilmer, Tom Sizemore, Diane Venora) is beefy and authentic, the action is superbly staged; and it's full of a melancholic air of tragedy.

The Taking Of Pelham 123
(Joseph Sargent, 1974) 9.15pm, Carlton Cinema

Enough to keep you off the tube for life: four masked gunmen hijack a New York subway train and demand $1m, or the passengers start dying. Robert Shaw as the ruthless gang boss and the late great Walter Matthau as the transport cop try to out-gruff each other in a relentlessly grimy, gloomy thriller.

M
(Fritz Lang, 1931) 3.10am, FilmFour

Lang's first talkie, and one of his masterpieces. Based on the true story of a Dusseldorf murderer, it turns a cold, detached eye on the hunt by police and underworld alike for a brutal child-killer. Peter Lorre made his name as the killer; and Otto Wernicke leads the hunt.

fields.headline: Options cashed in
fields.trailText: The recent revival in the fortunes of Durlacher, the internet investment specialist, could be over if investors follow the example of various directors.
fields.body:
The recent revival in the fortunes of Durlacher, the internet investment specialist, could be over if investors follow the example of various directors.

After touching 62p at the start of August, the Durlacher stock price has had a strong run, reaching 113p in the wake of annual figures published last Friday.

According to chairman and chief executive Geoffrey Chamberlain, sentiment towards e- business is "emerging from a trough of excessive pessimism".

Nevertheless, recent optimism about the stock appears to have tempted Mr Chamberlain, his brother, finance director Graham Chamberlain, and research director Andy Bottomley to exercise and then immediately cash in some stock options.

On Monday the three sold 2.5m Durlacher shares at 105p each. Durlacher shares closed down 3p at 87.5p yesterday.

webTitle: Ireland begs its exiles to return

fields.headline: Ireland begs its exiles to return
fields.standfirst: Global recruiting tour to fill gaps in boom economy
fields.trailText: For well over a century the Irish have been doing the world's dirty work, leaving in their tens of thousands to build Britain's motorways, work on Australia's farms or serve in the bars of America.
fields.body:
For well over a century the Irish have been doing the world's dirty work, leaving in their tens of thousands to build Britain's motorways, work on Australia's farms or serve in the bars of America.

But after a decade of breathtaking economic growth, Ireland finds itself in an unfamiliar position - it is running out of workers. With unemployment close to zero, the government estimates it will need to attract 200,000 people to its workforce in the next six years to sustain its boom.

In a historical twist, it is to the vast Irish diaspora that the country is now turning. On Saturday the Irish government's training and employment agency, Fas, will launch a global recruitment tour in Manchester, offering access to 50,000 vacancies in the republic. Over four months the tour will go from Newfoundland to New Zealand, via Birmingham, London and Sydney, in an attempt to address an employment shortage that one Dublin recruiter yesterday described as desperate.

The reversal in Ireland's economic fortunes could scarcely be more spectacular. In 1993 unemployment was running at 16%, and as recently as 1988 60,000 people were leaving the country each year to find work. That trend has reversed: last year 42,000 people moved to Ireland, 7,000 of them from the UK. But according to the Economic and Social Research Institute, an independent Dublin think tank, even if the country's double digit growth should slow in the next few years as many economists are predicting, the Celtic Tiger will still need fresh meat.

Recruitment levels have reached particularly critical levels in five industries: communications, information technology, construction, the health services, and hospitality and catering.

"Companies over here are becoming more desperate," said Alan O'Rafferty of Atlanco, a Dublin recruitment consultancy specialising in the construction industry. "It could be said that some companies are at breaking point if they don't get the staff. They don't ring us any longer and say, 'We want this and this,' they just ring and say, 'We want to see anything you have got.' It is entirely an employee's market."

Louise Fisher, a personal assistant at a Dublin construction firm, moved from Manchester this year. She had made two weekend trips to the republic, was impressed by the opportunities on offer, and decided to move on a trial basis.

"I flew over on Monday, and on the same day I had interviews with two employment agencies," said Ms Fisher, 36. "I had been offered my job by Wednesday, I flew home on Thursday to pack, and started my new job the following Monday.

"There's so much work out there it's unbelievable. I am now seriously considering settling here, because you can really pick and choose your career."

Dermod O'Byrne, the events manager at Fas, who is coordinating the tour, said the initiative had started as an attempt to encourage Irish exiles to come back but was then widened to include those whose families were of Irish origin.

All such restrictions have now been abandoned - the tour will also take in Berlin, Prague and even Ljubljana in Slovenia. Any workers who were "job ready, skilled and experienced", were welcome to apply, he said.

"We are going to a number of locations, and in each we will try to identify beforehand the market skills that may be available. Once we know what's available we know which employers to bring with us."

But he said the agency was sensitive to suggestions that it was attempting to poach workers. "We say we're only borrowing our cousins for a little while, and they can have them back later if they want to return."

fields.headline: Virgin Mobile plots American invasion
fields.trailText: Sir Richard Branson has turned the thrust of his Virgin Mobile business across the Atlantic with plans to launch an assault on the US mobile phone market.
fields.body:
Sir Richard Branson has turned the thrust of his Virgin Mobile business across the Atlantic with plans to launch an assault on the US mobile phone market.

The company is understood to be holding discussions with US networks AT&T, Voicestream and Sprint in the hope of setting up a joint venture modelled on the existing British business.

Virgin Mobile in Britain is a 50/50 split between Virgin and One2One.

The negotiations with the US networks are described as being at an advanced stage.

Virgin Mobile has opened an office in San Francisco and appointed former McKinsey consultant John Tantum to run the US operation.

Since the agreement with One2One was signed last year, Virgin has brokered similar agreements with Singapore Telecom to expand the business throughout South-east Asia and with Cable & Wire less Optus in Australia. Mr Tantum said the company was seeking an equity relationship in the US but declined to comment on individual negotiations.

"We've talked to all the operators in the US and there is a high level of interest," he said. "We are engaged with a number of operators and in some cases in fairly detailed negotiations about what sort of relationship Virgin will have with a network operator."

The deal with Singapore Telecom saw the Asian busi ness injecting $450m and Virgin contributing a further $50m.

"We are very likely to have an equity relationship with a carrier," Mr Tantum added. "The appealing thing of the 50-50 arrangement to us is that it aligns the incentives. We both have the same interests in making the company successful."

The US presents a vastly lucrative opportunity with current penetration rates far lower than in most parts of Europe. The development of the industry in the US was hampered by a system whereby the recipient of a call paid the bill and by the failure to agree a standard technology across the country.

The lack of a national operator may make it difficult, however, for Virgin to achieve its ambition of becoming a player across the length and breadth of the US.

Sir Richard has outlined hopes of developing a global mobile brand and the business has become one of the main focuses of the Virgin empire. He recently sold a stake in his flagship Virgin Atlantic airline to fund investments in mobile phones and the internet.

Virgin Mobile UK, which began last November, claims to have signed up 400,000 customers. The company introduced an integrated MP3 mobile phone earlier this month.

The Virgin brand name is less well known in the US where its most high profile business is its chain of 20 Megastores - the group's music retailer. Other ventures in cluding Virgin Cola have proved less successful.

In the US, the mobile business will target a younger market than the UK, aiming at 15-to 30-year-olds.

At home, Sir Richard will discover today whether his bid for the National Lottery will face a renewed challenge from incumbent operator Camelot. A verdict is due in the high court in the judicial review of the National Lottery Commission's decision to negotiate exclusively with Sir Richard's People's Lottery.

fields.headline: Bookham shares sale raises £100m
fields.trailText: Bookham Technology yesterday raised almost £100m from the sale of a block of new shares although the total placing was cut by 23% because of market conditions.
fields.body:
Bookham Technology yesterday raised almost £100m from the sale of a block of new shares although the total placing was cut by 23% because of market conditions.

The business, which found itself in the FTSE 100 just two months after its flotation, announced plans to place 18.5m shares at the beginning of September.

Cisco Systems, which had planned to sell 1.7m shares, decided against divesting any, while Celtic House cut its placement from 1.7m to 0.4m.

Analysts said they had been persuaded to hang on to the shares by the volatility of hi-tech stocks. Bookham shares were worth around £40 when the sale was announced and were placed yesterday at £33.50.

The total placing was 14.3m of which 3m were new shares.

Bookham's chairman and chief executive, Andrew Rickman, made £40m from the sale of 1.2m shares and still holds 27.6m.

Mr Rickman said he was encouraged by the continued "strong interest" sby investors. The shares closed 71p lower at £33.50.

Cash raised from the placing will be used for R&D, expansion of production facilities and bolt-on acquisitions.

fields.headline: North's war museum takes shape
fields.trailText: A dramatic new museum, funded without a penny of lottery money, was topped out on the banks of the Manchester ship canal yesterday.
fields.body:
A dramatic new museum, funded without a penny of lottery money, was topped out on the banks of the Manchester ship canal yesterday.

Daniel Libeskind, architect of the Imperial War Museum - North, watched as the traditional evergreen bough was fixed to the top of a jagged slab rising 180ft on a site across the water from the Lowry centre.

The building, facing the office blocks of Salford Quays, is itself a metaphor of conflict. Mr Libeskind, who designed the Jewish museum in Berlin and the spiral extension to the Victoria and Albert Museum in London, said his design was based on the structure of a sphere shattered into fragments and reassembled.

"There are three shards, representing the conflict on land, in the air and on water," he said. "The vertical air shard is the entrance and observatory, the earth shard houses the large volume of exhibits, and the concave water shard is where the restaurants are, looking right over the canal."

When a lottery bid was turned down, funds were packaged from Trafford council, the European regional development fund, English Partnerships and Peel Holdings, the investment company behind the Trafford Centre shopping mall.

Costs were cut from £40m to £28m, and Mr Libeskind said some materials in the original design had been modified. "But the building will be there in a strong and stark form without any compromise to the original concept I hope it will contribute to the debate about the impact of conflict, particularly the impact of 20th century conflicts."
