webTitle: Reggae: Keith Cameron  talks to Sizzla

fields.headline: Haile Selassie told me to do it
fields.standfirst: Keith Cameron  talks to Sizzla, the hottest name in reggae since Bob Marley
fields.trailText: Keith Cameron talks to Sizzla, the hottest name in reggae since Bob Marley.
fields.body:
When visiting New York, the average musical prodigy heads for the gleaming spires and fleshpots of Manhattan. Sizzla, however, is not your average musical prodigy. Summoned for a meeting with the brightest star in reggae's firmament, I am directed to a room at the Holiday Inn at Kennedy airport, where the muffled drone of incoming traffic makes a poor substitute for the city's fissile buzz. As a priest of the isolationist Bobo Ashanti sect, has this militant Rastaman elected to stay in such dreary surroundings to be as far removed as possible from the modern embodiment of Babylon? No, his UK record label representative scoffs. He is staying here "to keep him out of trouble".

Trouble has a habit of following Sizzla around. Last year he was due to make a rare foray into Europe to play the Montreux jazz festival, only to be arrested by the Jamaican police for possession of marijuana. This only consolidated his hero status in the eyes of the youth of Sizzla's native northeast Kingston, a disenfranchised constituency who share the authorities' belief that the young man born Miguel Collins is a revolutionary. But the Sizzla legend has extended far beyond the backyard where he spends his days amid clouds of smouldering holy weed.

As evinced by a torrent of brilliant records over the past four years, Sizzla has the potential to catapult reggae out of the dancehall ghetto to which it retreated after the death of Bob Marley in 1981. His conscious lyrical themes seduce roots traditionalists for whom the ragga era's glorification of slackness and violence was anathema, while state-of-the-art digital production satisfies those of a more hardcore persuasion. He has looks, charisma and the ability to tease a live audience from mere overexcitement to full-on delirium.

Above all, he possesses the ultimate weapon to unlock the hearts of the masses: a stunning voice capable of moving between spiritual supplication and abrasive polemic quicker than you can say Haile Selassie. Which is something Sizzla says a lot.

"Selassie I! Jah! Rastafari!" he exclaims as the tape recorder is switched on. "A Rastaman pass through New York to give the word of right unto his children. You know? Yeah. Through any medium which I found possible I could send word afloat to keep them unified until the day of redemption, repatriation. That's what I am doing here, as a Rastaman. Singing few songs for ma nation, because ma nation had wanted me to sing songs for them. See, the psalms are songs. Written by the famous King David, chief musician, so we sing music to keep ourselves together, to rid ourselves of oppression and ignorance. Rastafari."

The notion of Sizzla ever cashing in on his innate pop-star qualities is swiftly dispelled on meeting him. For him, music is not a career, but the means to disseminate The Truth: that the former Emperor of Ethiopia, Ras Tafari, Haile Selassie (who died in 1975), is God, and that the children of those taken from Africa and sold into slavery in the New World should return to Africa in an act of mass repatriation. There, free from the west's influences, they will lead lives of rural Arcadian bliss.

Sizzla professes bewilderment at the concept of fame. "I'm not aware of being a pop star," he says. "I am aware of being someone who stands up for equal rights and justice and stands up to see the redemption of my people going to Africa. Yes."

Slightly built, with wire-rimmed spectacles and a soft, lilting voice, he neither looks nor sounds like a revolutionary. Born to Rasta parents some 25 years ago, he has been heard to utter anti-white and homophobic comments at concerts in Jamaica, but today is professing love for all people who love Rastafari. His producer, on the other hand, the ominously proportioned Philip "Fatis" Burrell, is a man not to be messed with. Fatis runs Xterminator, one of Jamaica's foremost production houses, and has worked on the bulk of Sizzla's best work, including last year's Royal Son of Ethiopia album.

Fatis guards his young charge like a mother goose whose golden egg is ready to hatch but could equally disintegrate any minute. Sizzla himself seems indifferent to anything that resembles a measured release schedule or conventional promotional campaign: this is his first interview in four years, to coincide with his 12th album in that period. The prospect of his music making much of an impact globally is further diminished by his favours being shared between two record labels, both of which have just released a new Sizzla album: Bobo Ashanti on the UK's Greensleeves and Words of Truth on New York's VP. Great news for the diehard fans, but a paragon of marketing non-strategy.

Sizzla is oblivious to it all. He's just a prophet, doing God's work, referring everything back to the scriptures and the chief musician, the man he credits with writing the songs in the first instance. "Everything is in history, what I am saying is nothing new," he says. "It's just that I would have to come and make it brand new in thoughts again to let you know that we are still here and need to go home. No one should feel upset when I speak for my nation, because that's how I stand, and I look on TV and I see how these great presidents speak for the people. So I have to speak for my people also. Blessed. Holy Emmanuel I, Selassie I, Jah, Rastafari."

Sizzla's first interview for years ends, as it began, in surreal circumstances, with a mild-mannered yellow-turbaned Rastaman blessing a tape recorder. Whatever you might think about life on Planet Jah, this little man with the big voice makes life down here on Earth a whole lot more interesting.

Bobo Ashanti is out on Greensleeves.

Singing few songs for ma nation, because ma nation had wanted me to sing songs for them. See, the psalms are songs. Written by the famous King David, chief musician, so we sing music to keep ourselves together, to rid ourselves of oppression and ignorance. Rastafari." fields.headline: The end of the world as we know it
fields.standfirst: Even before it opens, the Royal Academy's new show is under attack. But there's more to Apocalypse than squashed popes and tortured Nazis, says  Adrian Searle
fields.trailText: Even before it opens, the Royal Academy's new show is under attack. But there's more to Apocalypse than squashed popes and tortured Nazis, says Adrian Searle.
fields.body:
There are two ways into Apocalypse, the much-discussed new exhibition at the Royal Academy. You can either walk in, or you can crawl. Norman Rosenthal, co-curator of this exhibition with Max Wigram, invited me to take the latter route. Concertinaed through a grubby, cramped little hatch on my hands and knees, I found myself in a narrow, dank, rubbish-strewn and dimly lit maze. Unsure which way to go, ducking and bungling my way through, I turned and turned again, following what little light there was. Poking my head into a cement-lined cell, I found myself reflected between greasy mirrors, a head in a grim void. Moving on, crab-wise, I finally wormed my way out.

This is not so much a habitation or an art installation as a model of an artist's mind, his ever inward-digging bolt hole. Gregor Schneider's Cellar (1985-99) is a version of the house where he lives in Germany, a house he has altered and goes on altering all the time, constructing within it hidden rooms, false windows, spaces within spaces. It is a series of illusions and traps, a sinister lair. How the artist lives, one can only imagine with reluctance and trepidation. There is apparently a room in Schneider's house whose sound-proofed door can be opened neither from within nor from without, should it slam behind you.

There is a way out here, a stumble into the larger space of the darkened gallery that contains Schneider's structure. Did the air-kiss-and-tell socialites at Monday's exclusive Prada party at the Royal Academy snag their rags on the rough concrete, rip their tights and spoil their creases on the dirty floor of Schneider's contribution to the show? Heavens, I do hope so. Did the conversation pall in the room where the Holocaust happens, the table-top world that Jake and Dinos Chapman have spent two years making, corpse by corpse, violation by violation? I have no doubt. Nor that the cognoscenti parked their expensive behinds on the polished wooden slatted seats of Darren Almond's shiny glass-and-aluminium bus shelters, which are eventually to be installed in Auschwitz. Almond's work is expressive because of its normality, its hygiene, its cleanliness, its sense of forgetting.

Mike Kelley's installation, on the other hand, is a false memory, a reconstruction of the photo of a play in a high-school yearbook. The original photograph is scary in itself, and Kelley has upped the ante, producing a perfect simulacrum of the set - a dingy room containing a rumpled bed, a stupid sculpture on a plinth, an oven with an open door. He has also produced a play, shown on video, whose two participants, closely modelled on the original photo, act out a dark and funny two-hander. Like Endgame, or Steptoe and Son, or Joseph Losey's 1963 film The Servant, the play acts out two lives trapped in the room. It deserves several viewings. It is mannered, twisted, obscene and hilarious. Suicide, Sylvia Plath, ass-fondling, power games and art are its subjects, all done in an early-sitcom style.

Like Jeff Koons's work, and like Richard Prince's paintings with stupid old jokes stencilled on them, Kelley's installation digs into the familiar world of the American banal. Whether Kelley wants to be heir to Edward Albee or David Mamet is another matter. Bleak as hell, made bleaker yet by its hilarity and ponderous cliches, Kelley's work has a lightness that most of the rest of the show tries for but can't quite manage.

In Chris Cunningham's new video installation Flex, life and death and sex are given a booming Aphex Twin soundtrack. Bodies are beautiful, against interstellar smoky blackness. It is terribly compelling and exciting, but where does it leave us? Looking at a woman with her mouth mashed in and red with blood from a man's punch. His foreskin peeled back in close-up, prelude to an atavistic fuck. It is as though Cunningham was trying to live up to the show's full title, Apocalypse: Beauty and Horror in Contemporary Art.

Looking at Wolfgang Tillmans's photo of a rose, a rose bleeding red into its white background, I cannot but find it, in the context of Apocalypse, sick, like Blake's rose, like a bloom of blood on a sheet, the tell-tale fleck in the sputum. Tillmans's virulent towering cloudscapes, updating John Martin's eschato- logical 18th-century paintings, are born of aeroplane-window views, stains in the developing tank. In the age of Aids (from which Tillmans's lover died) maybe his work is about grabbing beauty where you can, holding on to moments, seeing beauty or the poignant in the simplest things. The tenderness of his images shines through.

As does the malaise in Luc Tuymans's paintings. The reddish-green light, the shapelessness of his rendering of pillows, the bare bulbs dangling in Lamproom, the banality of his image of a folkloric festival, are all some way repulsive. His painting of a cloth embroidered with stilted leaves and flowers, tobacco-stained yellow and hopeless (they have, like Lady Bertram's needlepoint in Mansfield Park, little wit and no beauty) points to the same thing: a sort of disgustedness. They deal, in a certain way, with corruption, in which the bourgeois taste for painting is implicated. There is a deceptive relationship between the image and the manner of its articulation, the work's actual subject and its motif.

Maurizio Cattelan's joke sculpture of the Pope, a life-size and realistic sculpture of the pontiff floored by a meteor that appears to have crashed through the glass roof of the gallery, may be found offensive. This act of Cattelan - not God, nor an indifferent universe - is no more troubling, nor funnier, than many of the cartoons one finds in newspapers in Catholic countries. Impeccably staged, it presents a very old kind of apocalyptic vision - of horsemen and fires in the sky, heavenly portents and divine retribution - that we might have thought had disappeared. Yet only this week a Liberal Democrat was promoting a Star Wars offensive against falling rocks and cosmic debris. Plus ça change - Cattelan's work is a see-once-then-forget-it gag. That so much effort has gone into it renders it monumentally absurd.

Tim Noble and Sue Webster's spotlit pile of rubbish bags and detritus casts a shadow image of the artists on the wall - as a prelapsarian couple on a country hillside. Like Mike Leigh's Nuts in May, or Beckett's ever more hopeless peregrinations through bogs and corncrake-inhabited fields, this tableau associates the bucolic with the road to heaven or hell. A road, in this case, paved not with good intentions, but with pure crap. And what are the couple thinking, up there on the hill? I imagine their heads filled with air, or with the endlessly spinning images in Angus Fairhurst's hand-drawn film animation, with its mesmerising cycle of proliferating forms, which wheel, wiggle, multiply and mutate. The forms become overlaid as they turn, ending up with a rotating circle of jumbled black scribble. Being mesmerised can be trance-like and transcendental, which I guess has a kind of beauty in it. Or it can be distressingly repetitive, like an inner voice saying the same thing again and again till you'd chop your own head off to make it stop. Or the whole experience can be merely irritating, and watching Fairhurst becomes a scopophilic version of picking at a scab. His work makes you want to run amok through the galleries, beating other visitors about the head with your Acoustiguide. Time for my medication.

The works that - I can only guess - are intended to show a modern idea of beauty are at best horribly pretty. I was too tall to crouch in a praying position in Mariko Mori's high-tech, translucent pagoda, and had to sit with my knees somewhere up about my ears as though I were straining on a potty. Before me, on a curved, womb-like screen, water rose and fell, rain twinkled, jewelly little shapes flickered and swam. This 3-D multimedia experience (you'll have to queue, probably for hours) is all the more tiresome and pathetic for the effort that has gone into it. It bought out the inner child in me, the one that wants to smash things up.

Ditto Jeff Koons's paintings of kiddy toys in their world of popcorn, plastic smiles and gaily coloured balloons. This is a heaven made of Mylar. It is impossible to know whether Koons is celebrating childhood's world of grimacing, wide-eyed plastic, or if he is telling us something about the horror of our formative, Toys R Us years.

His room comes directly after Hell, the Chapmans' concentration camp diorama, in which mutants run the camp, and the Nazis are the victims. One traces a thread between Koons's infantilism (which makes us realise that children don't inherently like this stuff, but have it imposed on them by adults) and the pre- adolescent grisliness and black humour of the Chapmans' evil world. Hell is a grotesque spectacle of the unconscionable. So too, we must remind ourselves, is Schindler's List. Spielberg's attempt to be sensitive was as meaningless as the Chapmans' impulse to horrify and entertain, which at least has the merit of honesty about our voyeuristic urges. Dealing with the Holocaust as imagery for art, the movies, or literature is inevitably difficult. Hell is saved - if salvation has any meaning here - by the gags, the ludicrousness of it, the impossibility of treating its subject fully and truthfully, without becoming mawkish, mendacious or prurient. The Chapmans' answer is to go too far, which is perhaps not even far enough.

In his 1967 book on the apocalypse, The Sense of an Ending, Frank Kermode observed that it is only the outward signs of apocalypse that have changed with the centuries, and that its threat has always been felt to be imminent. "It is commonplace to talk about our historical situation as uniquely terrible," he wrote, "but can it really be so? Many of [our predecessors] felt as we do. If the evidence looks good to us, so it did to them. Perhaps if we have a terrible privilege, it is merely that we are alive and are going to die, all at once or one at a time." This is either itself a common-place, or it is profound. It only matters if this knowledge helps us live more fully. If this show is anything, it is also either banal or profound. Perhaps it is both, but not always in the way it was intended.

Apocalypse is at the Royal Academy, London W1 (020-7300 8000), from Saturday to December 15.

fields.headline: Inaction man keeps party faithful happy
fields.standfirst:
Speech must include strategy concerns

Special report: Liberal Democrat party conference 2000
Special report: Charles Kennedy
fields.trailText: As Charles Kennedy put the finishing touches to today's party conference speech in Bournemouth a trusted ally was asked if the genial Liberal Democrat leader is really hungry enough to be a successful modern politician.
fields.body:
As Charles Kennedy put the finishing touches to today's party conference speech in Bournemouth a trusted ally was asked if the genial Liberal Democrat leader is really hungry enough to be a successful modern politician.

"Of course, Charles is hungry, he's very ambitious. He wants to be prime minister," his colleague replied. The answer will surprise critics in the Lib Dem ranks who feel that Kennedy has not hit the ground running as fast as they would wish in the year since he succeeded the energetic Paddy Ashdown.

After Action Man, Inaction Man. "Where's the bloody strategy, Paddy had a strategy for everything, even lunch," the critics murmur. Today's speech must address that concern, MPs agree. There will be affection, but it will be tempered with expectation: solid policy thoughts, some inspiration and strategic direction.

Mr Kennedy refuses to be panicked. "I'm not going to do a William Hague. I'd rather people accuse me of having a low profile while my popularity goes up than have a high profile making a fool of myself while my popularity goes down," he tells his staff.

Mr Hague, at 39, a year his junior, has been an important factor in Mr Kennedy's first year. He privately admits it would have been harder finding political space for the Lib Dems with John Major or Kenneth Clarke as Tory leader. Mr Hague's populist lurch to the right - on crime, asylum, tax-and-spend - has genuinely angered Mr Kennedy.

It did not stop him inviting William and Ffion to dine at his Westminster flat with girlfriend Sarah Gurling to establish better personal rapport. Fortunately they turned him down. That was before the sensational byelection capture of Romsey by Sandra Gidley which cheered the activists.

This week's conference has (as so often) been overshadowed by dramas in the world beyond Bournemouth. But even here Mr Kennedy has been lucky. Furious with Tony Blair, voters have not all swung to the Tories. Half Labour's defectors have parked their votes with the Lib Dems, giving them poll ratings of 21% (NOP) and 22% (Guardian/ICM).

Lib Dem strategists believe it is a blip which will subside, but it is a handy blip, one which will still send them into the coming campaign with a higher base line and give some credibility to what will be the key theme of Mr Kennedy's speech at lunchtime.

It will be aimed at "One Nation" moderate Tories in the south where 50 potential Romseys lurk, provided they are not frightened off by tax-and-spend.

Even allowing for luck and bullish polls, what is surprising in Bournemouth this week is how little backbiting there has been among activists who like nothing better than to dwell on the shortcomings of whoever happens to be their leader. When one such sceptic, Lord Russell, dined the other night with MP Robert Maclennan, they agreed - to their surprise - that "Charles hasn't put a foot wrong".

"I haven't felt happier in the party for years," confided Mr Maclennan, Mr Kennedy's Highland neighbour. The historian in Lord Russell, often a thorn in Paddy Ashdown's flesh, believes that "Charles has a Gladstonian instinct for good timing and for the centre of gravity in his party. Any decision he takes will be in the interests of the party".

That last phrase is a dig at Mr Ashdown's obsession with Lib-Labbery and the joint consultative committee (JCC) he formed with Tony Blair - albeit without getting either of the promised referendums, on the euro or electoral reform for Westminster. One of Mr Kennedy's tasks this past year has been what aides call "a gentle distancing" from the JCC, ready to fight Labour hard in the election, but done without a fuss.

A few delegates complain that Mr Kennedy privately promised to get more out of Mr Blair. They also say that he may be good at doing media, but lacks drive or organisational skills.

Policy needed a shake-up when he inherited the leadership. They had even slipped on the environment where Lib Dems were once ahead of the game. Europe, another key policy area, was frustrating for different reasons, Labour's caution on the euro.

Those fields, plus a strong commitment to good public services and a Highlander's gut instinct for social justice are what will distinguish the Lib Dem manifesto.

But Mr Kennedy's hold on his party also rests on the tours he has made of the grassroots and the "more open and collegiate, less military" style he has adopted among Commons colleagues.

His most nervous moment in the past year was his appearance at the Cenotaph on Remembrance Sunday. Mr Kennedy is old enough to remember the fury over Michael Foot's duffle coat appearance in 1981. Notoriously parsimonious about clothes ("I've been trying to get him out of £99 suits," says one aide) he went out and bought a £500 overcoat.

Optimistic talk of winning an extra 50 seats is just that. Mr Kennedy (always a byelection pessimist) believes he can do better than the current 47 seats, but his chief interest is in positioning Lib Dem candidates in second place, not third place, with an eye to the general election of 2005.

That last phrase is a dig at Mr Ashdown's obsession with Lib-Labbery and the joint consultative committee (JCC) he formed with Tony Blair - albeit without getting either of the promised referendums, on the euro or electoral reform for Westminster. One of Mr Kennedy's tasks this past year has been what aides call "a gentle distancing" from the JCC, ready to fight Labour hard in the election, but done without a fuss. A few delegates complain that Mr Kennedy privately promised to get more out of Mr Blair. They also say that he may be good at doing media, but lacks drive or organisational skills. Policy needed a shake-up when he inherited the leadership. They had even slipped on the environment where Lib Dems were once ahead of the game. Europe, another key policy area, was frustrating for different reasons, Labour's caution on the euro. Those fields, plus a strong commitment to good public services and a Highlander's gut instinct for social justice are what will distinguish the Lib Dem manifesto. But Mr Kennedy's hold on his party also rests on the tours he has made of the grassroots and the "more open and collegiate, less military" style he has adopted among Commons colleagues. His most nervous moment in the past year was his appearance at the Cenotaph on Remembrance Sunday. Mr Kennedy is old enough to remember the fury over Michael Foot's duffle coat appearance in 1981. Notoriously parsimonious about clothes ("I've been trying to get him out of £99 suits," says one aide) he went out and bought a £500 overcoat. Optimistic talk of winning an extra 50 seats is just that. Mr Kennedy (always a byelection pessimist) believes he can do better than the current 47 seats, but his chief interest is in positioning Lib Dem candidates in second place, not third place, with an eye to the general election of 2005.

webTitle: Mafia shooting set to ignite Bombay gang wars

fields.headline: Mafia shooting set to ignite Bombay gang wars
fields.trailText: Police in India were bracing themselves last night for an explosion of gangland violence after Bombay's leading mafia don survived an audacious assassination attempt during a roof-terrace party in Thailand.
fields.body:
Police in India were bracing themselves last night for an explosion of gangland violence after Bombay's leading mafia don survived an audacious assassination attempt during a roof-terrace party in Thailand.

Chhota Rajan was relaxing at the gathering in Bangkok when six men wearing suits burst in and sprayed the terrace with bullets. Rajan was hit in the arm and the stomach, but appeared to have survived by jumping off the roof of the bungalow and hobbling away with an injured leg.

His right-hand man, Rohit d'Souza, died in the hail of gunfire. D'Souza's wife, Sikandi, and their two-year-old daughter were critically injured. Police later recovered pistols and 48 spent bullets.

Responsibility for the assassination attempt has been pinned on Chhota Shakeel, a rival Bombay mafia don based in Dubai. The two men - once allies, now bitter enemies - have been trying to kill each other since 1993 when they fell out.

Thai police said they had arrested four suspects in connection with the shooting, three Pakistanis and a Thai national. The suspects apparently told police they had been sent from India as part of a 10-strong gang hired to kill Rajan.

According to Indian police sources, the gangsters were recruited by Shakeel in Bombay last month before being whisked to Bangkok via Nepal and Pakistan.

The plan to kill Rajan was hatched in Karachi, Pakistan's conspiratorial port city, with the arms used in last Friday's hit smuggled to Thailand by boat. Pakistani intelligence agents may also have been involved, the sources added.

Rajan's whereabouts was unclear last night , but the most authoritative report suggested that he was being treated in a Bangkok hospital under the false name of Vijay Daman.

Earlier rumours suggested that he had chartered a plane and fled back to his base in Malaysia, from where he masterminds his vast criminal empire. Questions were also being asked as to why Rajan's six normally reliable and heavily armed bodyguards appeared to have let him down.

Detectives said privately that, after two years of relative underworld calm, they now expected a wave of tit-for-tat killings as the rival Rajan and Shakeel gangs wrestled for control of Bombay's lucrative drug running and extortion rackets. With Rajan recovering from his wounds, the balance of power has tipped decisively in Shakeel's favour, they added.

"We are still working on various leads," Bombay's joint commissioner of crime, D Sivanandan, said. "We are on top of the situation and will keep a tight grip on underworld activity."

Shakeel's boss, Dawood Ibrahim, almost undoubtedly sanctioned the attempted killing. It was Ibrahim, resident in Dubai since 1984 and India's most infamous don, who gave Rajan his first break by recruiting him as a contract murderer. Seven years ago, however, following anti-Muslim riots, Ibrahim orchestrated a series of bomb blasts against the Hindu community in Bombay by way of revenge.

Rajan, a Hindu, walked out of the gang and a plot to have him drowned failed. Since then the feud has prompted at least 200 killings. But until the Bangkok shootout none of its leading protagonists had been hurt.

A school dropout who began his criminal career selling black market cinema tickets, Rajan, 41, now heads an empire with a monthly turnover estimated at £150m.

As well as drug running, he is also involved in the shady world of Bollywood film financing, and extorting protection money, or hafta, from local businessmen. He is named in at least 17 murder cases.

fields.headline: Mauve with the times
fields.standfirst: Since its accidental creation in the 1850s, the colour has aroused strong emotions.  Simon Garfield  chronicles a vivid history
fields.trailText: Since its accidental creation in the 1850s, the colour has aroused strong emotions. Simon Garfield chronicles a vivid history.
fields.body:
Last month, a branch of Sainsbury's in London's Kensington launched a new shopping trolley. It was revolutionary not only because its wheels tended to go in a straight line, but because of its charming and novel refinements. This being a posh people's store, the trolley had a champagne chiller and a handy canape tray. Its baby seat was padded. The trolley came in what a Press Association reporter referred to as "this season's fashionable colour". It was mauve.

Dodgy choice, perhaps. Mauve, a colour with a more dramatic history than any other, doesn't suit everyone and doesn't go with much. When people wear it they look great or awful, with not much in between. How you feel about it depends on when you were born. If you were 20 in the early 70s, mauve equals Biba and loon pants. If you were 20 a decade later, it is the most vile colour on the planet, and it came as no surprise when Prince rejected it for the more regal purple. But if you were alive in the 1850s, mauve meant never having to wear natural colours made from molluscs again.

Invented in 1856 by an 18-year-old chemistry student called William Perkin, mauve was the first artificial colour to be produced on a grand scale. It was made from coal tar, and came about by accident when Perkin was trying to make artificial quinine to save the British troops dying from malaria in India. He got the molecule wrong, but found that the oily dark sludge he produced dyed his shirt a brilliant purple. He also found that the colour didn't fade much on washing or in light, and realised that artificial dyes would greatly reduce the cost of everyday clothing. He packed in his course and set up a factory in Harrow, and within a few years he had made his fortune.

Perkin sparked a revolution not only in the dye and fashion trades but also in science, particularly medicine, where artificial dyes were instrumental in early work with chromosomes and the conquest of disease. Initially, Perkin referred to his invention as Tyrian purple, but the French called it mauve, the word used to describe the stems of their common mallow plant. And it was in France where the colour first took off - a mauve mania inspired by Empress Eugenie.

London turned mauve between 1859 and 1861, and the weekly journal All the Year Round, edited by Charles Dickens, described a scene never witnessed before or since. Mauve was everywhere: streaming on hair ribbons, waving from car riages, jamming up railway stations on the newly fashionable crinolines, "all flying countryward, like so many migrating birds of purple paradise". At a Drury Lane pantomime, policemen told people to "get a mauve on". Punch magazine ran many cartoons lampooning what it referred to as "mauve measles".

The fad for the colour was superseded by other artificial shades - Manchester brown, Magdala red and artificial indigo - and mauve became the Victorian colour for half-mourning. But mauve is a colour that likes to hang around. What it likes to do more than anything, however, is change its hue. These days, mauve isn't one colour, the way lavender or pink seems to be. Mauve moves from lilac to lush purple depending on the light, on descriptive prowess, on memory, on upbringing. Even its pronunciation splits the country - moave down south, morv up north.

The word has been used to describe opulence and excess: in the US, the 1890s has been called the mauve decade. The colour has been used as gay slang: in Bruce Robinson's screenplay for Withnail and I, the lecherous Uncle Monty defines Withnail with the phrase: "He's so mauve." For Oscar Wilde, the colour took on an absolute significance in The Picture of Dorian Gray: "Never trust a woman who wears mauve," wrote the man in the green waistcoat, "whatever her age may be ... it always means they have a history."

In the OJ Simpson trial, defence lawyer Johnnie Cochran wore a snappy double-breasted suit, the precise colour of which eluded the court reporters. During a break in procedings, Cochran insisted his suit was blue. "Just don't call it mauve," he said. And last year, a leaked memo from Buckingham Palace revealed the Queen's instructions to the management of foreign hotels. One of these stipulated that the flower arrangements should not contain anything mauve.

Colour experts like to pick on mauve. In the US, the Color Marketing Group, one of many bodies that dictate trends to style folk and product designers, declared in 1990 that the colour was finished. But now here it comes again, featuring in autumn/winter collections from Alberta Ferretti, Blumarine and Chanel, and on supermarket trollies. William Perkin, buried near Harrow School and largely forgotten, will be smirking in his grave.

Mauve: How One Man Invented a Colour That Changed the World by Simon Garfield is published by Faber & Faber (£9.99).

fields.headline: Talking dirty
fields.body:
"She wasn't a Diana, yet the comparisons were there from the moment the news broke ... another woman who lived life too fast and too recklessly, a flawed and sexually magnetic figure who died too young. Her passing is the flipside of Jill Dando's. If Dando's murder carried an echo of the Princess of Wales's death, it was for her beauty and her goodness, the incomprehensibility of it all. In Yates's death is the other side of the Diana tragedy - the woman spiralling out of control. A shocked and saddened Britain grieved for Dando, but we couldn't really relate to her. She was too professional, too carefully beautiful, too wholesome and too kind. Yates was flawed and cheap and self-destructive, fiercely intelligent and wilful, the thrift-store Diana, the end-of-the-pier Monroe"

Ros Wynne-Jones on Paula Yates, Daily Express

"Women such as Yates, Monroe and Princess Diana have more in common than their hair colour, although that in itself is evidence of an ambition to embody a particular feminine type. No matter how often blondes protest they are tough and sassy, they tend to be perceived as vulnerable and infantile, a perception confirmed when they break down and show their emotions in public"

Joan Smith, Independent

"If you're vivacious and a bit wild, they call you mad. That's the thing about being a woman and successful, if you were a bloke you would just be eccentric"

Tracey Emin, i-D

"I think she misunderstood when we said we wanted more Blair Babes"

Unnamed Labour whip on Ruth Kelly MP who has given birth to her third child in one parliamentary term, Mail on Sunday

"Every man is insecure about the number of lovers his partner has had. He can't help it. It's in his blood. It is a territorial trait that has evolved from peeing on trees ... Men are like dogs. When we pass each other in the street, we sniff and growl. We don't forget about the other male until they are well out of sight. We are the same about our lover's ex-boyfriends"

Actor Jon Favreau who plays a man less sexually experienced than his girlfriend in the forthcoming film Love And Sex, Cosmopolitan

"He's the spokesman for the teenage male unconscious, and the inexpressible"

Danny Goldberg, president of Artemis Records and a director of the American Civil Liberties Union Foundation, defends rapper Eminem, George magazine

fields.headline: Germany deports race hate victims
fields.trailText: A bitter row has broken out among senior German politicians over two victims of neo-Nazi violence who were ordered out of the country after their ordeals.
fields.body:
A bitter row has broken out among senior German politicians over two victims of neo-Nazi violence who were ordered out of the country after their ordeals.

One has already left. The other is awaiting deportation. In both cases, the results of the attacks are said to have been used by regional officials in eastern Germany as grounds for getting rid of them.

Their cases have been taken up by the speaker of the federal parliament, Wolfgang Thierse, who has claimed they demonstrate covert official backing for the far right.

One of the foreigners, an Egyptian, Salah el-Nemr, owned a pizzeria in the town of Elsterwerda, 100 miles south-east of Berlin. After it was burned down by skinheads in October 1998, he was told he had lost his right to stay in Germany because his resident's permit was dependent on his having a viable business.

Mr el-Nemr, who lived in Germany for 10 years, left the country voluntarily to avoid getting a deportation stamp in his passport that would have prevented him from returning as a visitor. He told a correspondent for the newspaper Berliner Zeitung in Cairo that he hoped to be allowed back in to marry his German fiancee.

An Algerian asylum seeker, who has so far been identified only as Khaleb B, lost his right to stay on the grounds that he was no longer mentally fit to manage his life by himself.

However, he and his lawyer maintain that this is because of the trauma he underwent in February 1999 when he watched as a friend was lynched in the streets of Guben near the Polish border.

He is currently awaiting deportation. The trial of his friend's alleged killers began last week.

The political row has erupted against a background of mounting alarm in the federal government over the prevalence of far right and xenophobic sentiment in the formerly communist east. The Brandenburg region around Berlin where both men lived has become notorious for race hate attacks.

On July 28, Mr Thierse wrote to the interior minister in the Brandenburg regional government, describing the treatment of the two men as "devastating".

The speaker, a member of the governing Social Democratic party (SDP), said that decisions taken by the regional administration's aliens department "give the impression that German government agencies not only accept the consequences of rightwing and racist activity, but even use them as an official pretext".

His accusation brought a heated reaction from the authorities in Brandenburg. Earlier this month, the regional interior minister, Jörg Schönbohm, a Christian Democrat, replied to Mr Thierse demanding an apology. The head of the Christian Democrat group in the Brandenburg regional assembly accused the speaker of "abusing his position".

Mr Thierse has taken a keen interest in the issue of neo-Nazi violence and its social underpinnings. He is a frequent visitor to schools in the east.

The Brandenburg authorities have claimed that Mr el-Nemr's engagement is a ploy aimed at securing his return. However, when Berliner Zeitung's correspondent traced him in Cairo, he produced an intimate love letter from his fiancee. He was also carrying photographs of the dog and flat he left behind and of his fiancee before and after their separation.

One of his friends was quoted as saying: "Salah changed in Germany. He is serious about his work and always punctual. But what use are these German values if these people are capable of destroying the life of a peaceable, hard-working man from one moment to the next?"1818

fields.headline: No: 1725
fields.standfirst: Frederick Forsyth
fields.trailText: Frederick Forsyth
fields.body:
Age: 61.

Appearance: Traditional, conservative, Euro-sceptic with a penchant for outdoor pursuits such as fox-hunting.

Status: Traditional, conservative, Euro-sceptic and a lifelong supporter of fox-hunting.

Anything else that distinguishes him from the riff-raff? Oh yes. He writes novels.

Thought so. What is the word on the jackal these days? It's been all quiet in recent years. The master of the international thriller hung up his typewriter in 1997 after publishing his last novel, Icon.

Any particular reason? "The excitement and challenge have gone," says Forsyth. "I've done assassins, done terrorists. Done mercenaries, done revolutionaries. Done communists, done spies ... "

Well, that is a lot, yes. " ... done fighter-pilots, done infiltration agents. I've done SAS, arms trafficking, espionage, international crime . . .

Thank you. I think we've got the idea. "... People say, 'Why don't you do the IRA?' Bor-ring! The pleasure and excitement have gone."

Oh dear. So, what is the solution to his writer's blues? He's going to publish a book on the internet.

What! That beastly new-fangled thing that tarnishes our youth with uncensored pornography and destroys the delights of the handwritten word? Actually, Forsyth likes it. "I believe the advent of e-books is one of the most exciting developments in my experience as a professional writer," he says. His own e-book, Quintet, will be a series of five short stories, published one at a time, starting next month.

How inventive. It's just like The Day of the Jackal: the challenge for the Englishman is to stay one step ahead of the competition. Well, not exactly. Stephen King has already been there. In July he became the first novelist to publish a book on the internet.

Do say: "The E-dessa File."

Don't say: "No Comebacks."

That beastly new-fangled thing that tarnishes our youth with uncensored pornography and destroys the delights of the handwritten word? Actually, Forsyth likes it. "I believe the advent of e-books is one of the most exciting developments in my experience as a professional writer," he says. His own e-book, Quintet, will be a series of five short stories, published one at a time, starting next month. How inventive. It's just like The Day of the Jackal: the challenge for the Englishman is to stay one step ahead of the competition. Well, not exactly. Stephen King has already been there. In July he became the first novelist to publish a book on the internet. Do say: "The E-dessa File." Don't say: "No Comebacks."

webTitle: Farm trials in jeopardy after verdict

fields.headline: Farm trials in jeopardy after verdict
fields.standfirst: Special report: GM debate
fields.trailText: Yesterday's verdict acquitting 28 Greenpeace protesters of criminal damage to a field of GM crops is likely to have ramifications far beyond the confines of Norwich crown court.
fields.body:
Yesterday's verdict acquitting 28 Greenpeace protesters of criminal damage to a field of GM crops is likely to have ramifications far beyond the confines of Norwich crown court.

According to Charles Secret, director of Friends of the Earth, the jury's decision could spell disaster for the government's plans to increase the number of genetically modified farm scale crop trials. "As far as I can see this throws the door open for people to legitimately destroy GM crops that are about to go to pollen.

Under government plans, trials in 25 fields for maize and oilseed rape and 30 more for either sugar or fodder beet are due to get under way by the end of this year, with more farm-scale trials planned for next year and in 2002 before the results are fully evaluated in 2003.

A total of 75 participating farms are needed over the next three years for a viable study, but even before yesterday's verdict, doubt had been cast on the government's ability to recruit enough farms, a fact confirmed by the National Farmers Union yesterday.

"It is vital that any farmers involved in future trials are better protected or of course they are not going to want to take part," a spokesman said. "We are extremely shocked and angered by the verdict. This is about criminal damage to farmers' crops and has distressing implications for all farmers."

In March, two weeks after the government announced the location of 31 farms in England and Scotland that had signed up for the trials, two of the farms pulled out under pressure from local people. Greenpeace has also issued a hit list of 26 farms it says are taking part in the trials.

The government had issued only a six-figure grid reference to identify the fields where the trials are due to take place, but anti-GM campaigners will be hoping that the jury's decision in the Greenpeace case will trigger a domino effect, with more farmers deciding to boycott the trials.

Although the jury's verdict does not set a precedent for future cases, legal experts said yesterday that a number of similar verdicts would probably see the crown prosecution service re-evaluating whether to bring similar cases to trial.

Yesterday the Department of Environment Transport and the Regions was adamant the trials would continue. "If we halted our strictly controlled research then there would be widespread GM crop planting, without us getting the real scientific evidence we need," the department said in a statement. "Our priority is to protect the environment and human health. These farm scale evaluations are vital for us to assess whether there are any unacceptable effects."

fields.headline: Confrontation on GM battlefield
fields.standfirst:
Greenpeace trial: Short but epic meeting of farmers and protesters

Special report: GM debate
fields.trailText: When Lord Melchett, former Labour minister, working farmer and head of Greenpeace UK, arrived at remote Walnut Tree farm, near Lyng, Norfolk, with 27 others just before dawn on July 26 last year, he knew the environmental group had just a few minutes to destroy the six acre GM maize crop being grown by the three Brigham brothers for seed company Agrevo.
fields.body:
When Lord Melchett, former Labour minister, working farmer and head of Greenpeace UK, arrived at remote Walnut Tree farm, near Lyng, Norfolk, with 27 others just before dawn on July 26 last year, he knew the environmental group had just a few minutes to destroy the six acre GM maize crop being grown by the three Brigham brothers for seed company Agrevo.

With luck, the farm machinery they had brought would work faultlessly, the police would be alerted too late and the "polluting" maize would be bagged up and on its way back to the company's head office in King's Lynn before anyone could stop them.

The first half of the operation went to plan. Lord Melchett had set off at night from his family farm, some 30 miles away at Ringstead, Norfolk, with an industrial crop cutter on the back of a wagon. Most of the other Greenpeace members had travelled there from London in two minibuses.

The rendezvous was near the GM field at 5am. By the time Lord Melchett arrived, the 27 volunteers - who included nine Greenpeace staff and supporters from all over Britain including a Baptist minister - were waiting behind a hedge.

Decontamination suits

Within seconds, the padlock on the gate barring the GM trial field had been cut, lorry and cutting machine had gone in, followed by the volunteers all dressed in white "decontamination" suits. The gate was immediately re-padlocked and Melchett spent an infuriating few minutes trying to set up the machinery.

What Greenpeace had not counted on was the alertness and the anger of the Brigham brothers and their determination to protect their crop. Within seconds of the environment group's cutter speeding through the field like a whirling dervish, the three brothers were heading from the farmhouse towards the field on foot and by tractors.

The meeting was short but epic. There were moments of real drama and danger for the volunteers and the clash was described as a confrontation between outsiders and locals, with Greenpeace being alternately hailed by the anti-GM lobby and condemned by government and most of the media.

William Brigham tried to physically stop the volunteers who had immediately begun cutting the crop by hand and putting it into bags. Meanwhile, John and Eddie Brigham were turning their tractors into mobile battering rams.

The two Greenpeace minibuses were damaged. As one brother on his Massey Ferguson ambushed the Greenpeace cutter on its second revolution round the field, striking it down with one blow of his front end loader, another was slamming a heavy JCB-type shovel on top of the Greenpeace lorry preventing it moving.

Within 10 minutes, the Greenpeace action was effectively over, with only the volunteers left cutting by hand. At most, one sixth of the field which was about to flower and pollinate, causing what Lord Melchett said would be "inevitable pollution", had been cut down.

The brothers had caused an estimated £5,000 of damage to the Greenpeace machinery and Greenpeace had caused about £650 of damage to the crop.

The police arrived at about 5.30am. By this time one of the Brighams was speeding round the field in his tractor in pursuit of anyone in a white suit and the volunteers were hiding or throwing themselves deep into the maize to avoid injury,

Ecological arguments

As the police moved in to arrest Greenpeace members and lead them to relative safety, the political and ecological arguments started. William Brigham confronted Lord Melchett, accusing him of being a criminal: "I find it amazing that a man calling himself a democrat and is a former government minister sees fit to take the law into his own hands."

Lord Melchett said: "This is decontamination of the countryside. This crop shouldn't be grown. We are doing something that the public wants and is for the benefit of the environment." He added that Greenpeace was trying to protect other farmers.

William Brigham argued that he, rather than Lord Melchett, was working for the community, and that he and his brothers were acting in an ecologically responsible way.

"I wanted to trial these crops to see if there were any downsides," he said.

Within hours, the Greenpeace 28 had been driven off and Lord Melchett was preparing to spend two nights in Norwich prison after being refused bail.

webTitle: Canary Wharf in profit for first time

fields.headline: Canary Wharf in profit for first time
fields.trailText: Shares in Canary Wharf Group hit a high yesterday as the company which built the monument to Thatcherite corporate excess produced its first ever 12-month profit figures eight years after near bankruptcy.
fields.body:
Shares in Canary Wharf Group hit a high yesterday as the company which built the monument to Thatcherite corporate excess produced its first ever 12-month profit figures eight years after near bankruptcy.

Chief executive George Iacobescu said the full-year, pre-tax profit of £54.1m - compared with a £42.8m loss last time - was helped by rising rental income and the sale of completed properties.

He was delighted the company was "two or three years ahead of the business plan" it had drawn up when it floated 18 months ago, but there was no dividend for shareholders.

Canary Wharf, a development centred around Britain's tallest building, was originally built up by Olympia & York under the control of Paul Reichmann, Canary Wharf's chairman. But the 1987 property crash put the whole scheme into the hands of a group of rescuing banks.

The development on the Isle of Dogs in east London has made a comeback and now challenges the City as a key location for finance and business and Canary Wharf announced yestreday that the John Lewis-owned supermarket group Waitrose had signed a lease for an 80,000sq ft store which would open in two years time.

Discussions are also going on with US energy group Enron while a host of other top City names such as international law firm Clifford Chance have taken office space.

Deutsche Bank has been considering a move down the river which would follow its rivals such as HSBC and Citigroup who have already gone to Docklands. Competition between the City and Canary Wharf is so intense that it has encouraged the former to consider relaxing planning controls to allow buildings such as the 41-storey "erotic gherkin" under consideration by Swiss Re.

Canary Wharf shares ended the day up 5.5p at 535.5p with Mr Iacobescu saying there would be no dividend because the money was best reinvested in development. He predicts higher rents as reviews get under way with the whole site occupied by 2003 or 2004.

webTitle: Brussels threatens £40m grant to keep new Micra in Sunderland

fields.headline: Brussels threatens £40m grant to keep new Micra in Sunderland
fields.trailText: Britain's campaign to build the new Nissan Micra ran into trouble last night after the European commission began investigating the legality of a £40m government grant designed to encourage the Japanese company to choose the UK over France.
fields.body:
Britain's campaign to build the new Nissan Micra ran into trouble last night after the European commission began investigating the legality of a £40m government grant designed to encourage the Japanese company to choose the UK over France.

Brussels disclosed that it harboured serious doubts about the "necessity and proportionality of the aid". Officials suggested that the commission could block the money altogether or authorise only a fraction of the £40m grant.

The subsidy would be approved, officials said, only if Nissan could prove it was intended to redress a competitive disadvantage at its Sunderland plant compared to a factory in France.

More than a thousand jobs would be at risk if the investment was blocked, Sir Ken Jackson, the general secretary of the Amalgamated Engineering and Electrical Union, warned yesterday.

Nissan officials did their best to play down this figure and said the company would not necessarily have to lay off some of the 5,000 workers employed at Sunderland if the EC decision went against it.

French carmaker Renault has a 36.8 % stake in Nissan and its factory in Flins is also in the running to produce the new Micra, which is due to be rolled out in 2003.

EU sources familiar with the issue yesterday suggested that Flins was not a viable alternative but merely a ploy by Nissan to secure the £40m.

Nissan must prove this is not the case if it is to win its case, in the same way Rover was asked to prove that the Longbridge plant could lose out to a factory in Hungary.

"The money can't be used to modernise the [Sunderland] factory to give it a competitive advantage," one EU source said, adding that the inquiry could take up to 18 months.

Nissan's president, Carlos Ghosn, is due to take a decision on where the new Micra will be produced by the end of the year. He is known to be unhappy about the strength of sterling.

In July he told Tony Blair that the strong pound was threatening his investment plans at Sunderland, Nissan's biggest British plant.

A Nissan spokesman yesterday echoed this view and warned that the variable euro/sterling exchange rate was a real problem.

"We have the option to either build the car at Renault or in the UK, but the UK plant is less competitive because it is disadvantaged by the strength of the pound," said Stuart McKee.

"The strength of the pound is the biggest hurdle we face because we're making cars in pounds and selling them in euros right across Europe."

The grant would be spent on "capital projects and tooling" and, although important, was not the only factor which would decide whether Sunderland won the contract or lost out to France.

Mr McKee stressed that Nissan had expected the inquiry to be ordered but felt that its application for the grant was within EU rules.

If the £40m grant is blocked, Nissan has the option of appealing against the decision to the European Court of Justice in Luxembourg.

This is not the first time the European commission has questioned the legality of state aid to the car sector. Fiat and Volkswagen have had to scale back or reject government subsidies in recent years after Brussels raised objections.

fields.headline: Ofwat view
fields.standfirst: New chief upsets status quo
fields.trailText: New chief upsets status quo
fields.body: New regulator Philip Fletcher has signalled that he favours a substantial restructuring of the industry less than two months after succeeding Sir Ian Byatt , the former Ofwat chief. Shares in the sector have fallen 50% since their peak two years ago - not least because Sir Ian imposed average price cuts of 12% and hefty capital spending targets to improve the environment in his last review. That settlement prompted arethink. Kelda announced plans this year to return Yorkshire to its original owners, its customers, and make it a debt-financed mutual. Sir Ian scotched that idea but variants are known to have been considered by Anglian and Pennon , or South-west Water . Mr Fletcher, former receiver for the Metropolitan Police and an environment department official, has said he favours separating ownership of water and sewage assets from their operation. The idea lay at the heart of the bidding war between Nomura and WPD for control of multi-utility Hyder , won by US-owned WPD last month. WPD plans to retain the assets of Hyder's Welsh Water but hand over operations to Warrington-based United Utilities . Severn Trent has challenged this in the high court, where the case will be heard today. Mr Fletcher has upset the status quo by endorsing such schemes: his remarks have been seen as the catalyst for the announcement from Thames Water . But he said yesterday he would like Ofwat to move from being a "facilitator" to a "promoter".

webTitle: Leader: Mr Ecclestone's money still shames Labour

fields.headline: Truth and Gordon Brown
fields.standfirst:
Mr Ecclestone's money still shames Labour

Special report: New Labour in power
fields.trailText: Mr Ecclestone's money still shames Labour
fields.body:
Gordon Brown was meant to be in a party mood on Monday night. He and 500 of his closest friends had just gathered in a trendy London venue to celebrate his wedding last month: the champagne and good cheer flowed freely. The chancellor returned home that evening, doubtless in a mood to put last week's fuel crisis behind him and begin the long climb back to recovery in time for next week's Labour conference. But the light on the answering machine would have been blinking furiously: the Daily Mail was carrying a front-page story the next day branding him a liar over comments he made three years ago on the Bernie Ecclestone affair. Within 24 hours he was resisting demands calling for his resignation from his Conservative opposite number, Michael Portillo.

First, the charge. According to a new book by Andrew Rawnsley (of our sister paper, the Observer), Mr Brown lied when he told the Today programme he did not know the truth about the formula one boss's £1m donation to the Labour party: in fact, writes Mr Rawnsley, Mr Brown had been briefed on the gift by Tony Blair two days earlier. This is a serious charge. The chancellor was not under oath, nor was he speaking in the House of Commons, but to speak on the radio is to speak to the nation and if he was telling a lie then he cannot easily be forgiven.

But Mr Brown has a substantial defence. His aides say he was telling the truth when he told John Humphrys: "I've not been told and I certainly don't know what the true position is." That was true, say the Brownites, because the chancellor had not been told the full details by Mr Blair - at his own insistence. They note Gordon Brown's scrupulous determination, going back to his days as shadow chancellor, to steer well clear of party finances: with responsibility for the nation's money, he could not afford even the appearance of a conflict of interest. They insist that Mr Brown did not want to know the crucial details of the Ecclestone loan - including its size - and confined his conversation with Mr Blair to generalities. His advice was to refer the whole business to the standards watchdog, Lord Neill, and to wait for his response. Since that response had not yet arrived when the chancellor was confronted on the Today programme, he was speaking honestly when he said he did not know "the true position". Finally, the Brown camp notes Mr Rawnsley's change of wording, altering "the true position" into "the truth." They say the actual wording fits their account.

There may be a touch of Clintonism about this defence, stretching the meaning of words almost to breaking point. But linguistic slipperiness and evasiveness are misdemeanours in a politician, not capital crimes. They dent Mr Brown's reputation for near-monastic, rock-solid integrity - reducing him, perhaps, to the level of most politicians - but they do not warrant his resignation.

Which is not to say that the Ecclestone affair itself does not remain the blackest of black marks on the record of this administration. The formula one donation came to light when Labour was still in its 1997 honeymoon; if it had surfaced later, it may well have proved fatal. At the time this newspaper condemned it for what it was: sleaze. A government changed policy - exempting formula one from a ban on tobacco advertising - after it had been given a huge dollop of cash from an interested party. It looked then, and looks now, like a clear case of cash-for- influence. Labour has to learn the lessons of that mistake - but making Gordon Brown the scapegoat is not the right one.

They dent Mr Brown's reputation for near-monastic, rock-solid integrity - reducing him, perhaps, to the level of most politicians - but they do not warrant his resignation. Which is not to say that the Ecclestone affair itself does not remain the blackest of black marks on the record of this administration. The formula one donation came to light when Labour was still in its 1997 honeymoon; if it had surfaced later, it may well have proved fatal. At the time this newspaper condemned it for what it was: sleaze. A government changed policy - exempting formula one from a ban on tobacco advertising - after it had been given a huge dollop of cash from an interested party. It looked then, and looks now, like a clear case of cash-for- influence. Labour has to learn the lessons of that mistake - but making Gordon Brown the scapegoat is not the right one.

fields.headline: Diary
fields.trailText: • Entertaining though this whole Blair-Brown business has been, things have gone far enough. It's time to stop spreading stories about how Gordon is a mendacious, power-crazed weirdo. Those sorts of stories really do not help matters, however true. Labour should now close ranks and unite against the real enemy: Peter Mandelson. Ha ha, just kidding Peter. No, the real enemies are still the Tories, and all it takes is a glimpse of Michael Portillo to remind us. Polly popped up yesterday on GMTV (well known for its Spanish Inquisition interviewing style). "Sometimes [politicians] try to avoid issues, but if we are asked something head-on you have really got to answer it," Polly said. An excellent attitude, and as it happens Michael there are one or two questions you could answer. Such as, how much exactly do you get paid by the Kerr McGee oil and multinational, and for what? And how did the Tory party tally donations from Michael Ashcroft's Belize trust with its ban on foreign donations? Hmm?

No, the real enemies are still the Tories, and all it takes is a glimpse of Michael Portillo to remind us. Polly popped up yesterday on GMTV (well known for its Spanish Inquisition interviewing style). "Sometimes [politicians] try to avoid issues, but if we are asked something head-on you have really got to answer it," Polly said. An excellent attitude, and as it happens Michael there are one or two questions you could answer. Such as, how much exactly do you get paid by the Kerr McGee oil and multinational, and for what? And how did the Tory party tally donations from Michael Ashcroft's Belize trust with its ban on foreign donations? Hmm?

 "Sir - The article published under the name Sin Simon (Sept 18) reinforces my belief that no such person exists. No rational being could write such hysterical nonsense. It must have been derived from a word processor amalgam of Alastair Campbell's ravings." Lord Tebbit in the Daily Telegraph yesterday.

 I'm not sure which of these news items is the more bizarre. One is that the Young Fabians annual reception (guest speaker P Mandelson) at Brighton is being sponsored by the Sunday Telegraph. The other (and this may be what our editor wistfully calls a "scoop") is that the reception will launch a leaflet by Mr Tony Blair entitled "The Case for Socialism". Apparently it fills the back of an entire first class stamp.

 "Sir -I note with interest that Sin Simon is an anagram for 'On Mission', which can be the only explanation for the intemperate and insulting tripe in his column." Another happy Telegraph reader.

 An intriguing offer arrives on a poster for a candidate in a Kent county council byelection. "Dave Hammock has run a local pub for 20 years," it reads. Next to a photo of Mr Hammock is the winning slogan: "Elect Dave Hammock and you'll get one." Now there's a politician taking things head on. So how are you going to "give one" to all your electors? "With 13,000 constituents, that could take me all week," jests Dave when we call the Black Horse pub in Bean. But he won't be drawn into a pub landlord rant, even on the "It's a pint for the fella and a glass of white wine for the lady" issue.

 "Sir - Surely Sin Simon can only be the imaginary creation of Peter Simple."

 Marking the first anniversary of the Ladbroke Grove rail disaster is a sensitive issue for First Great Western rail franchise. But it has come up with a very British mark of respect by cancelling a rail service - the 6.03am Cheltenham service on October 5. A better mark of respect would be if the company invested in Automatic Train Protection for its entire network to ensure it never happens again.

 Many thanks to all those readers who called to say that the Bill Gates joke in yesterday's Diary (the one with the punchline "F*** off Gates, can't you see I'm busy!") is in fact older than the printed word. Frankly I'm shocked, having heard it from a man in a pub who read it on an email. If that's not an impeccable source then I don't know what is.

 Speaking of old gags, hats off to the Express for its campaign to increase pensions, illustrated by a bag of peanuts. "This year state pensions have risen by 75p, just enough to buy a bag of peanuts," it proclaimed yesterday. A striking metaphor - just as striking as when my colleague Nick Timmins and I first coined it on the front-page of the FT on September 15, 1999.

webTitle: Police warn women of sex attacks 'risk taker'

fields.headline: Police warn women of sex attacks 'risk taker'
fields.trailText: A sex attacker who takes deliberate risks was linked by detectives yesterday to seven violent assaults on women in Leeds over the last fortnight.
fields.body:
A sex attacker who takes deliberate risks was linked by detectives yesterday to seven violent assaults on women in Leeds over the last fortnight.

Five of the victims, including a woman pushing her daughter in a pram and a middle-aged angina sufferer, were punched or wrestled to the ground in daylight near main roads before the white man, in his late teens to early 20s, carried out indecent assaults.

Police warned women in the York road area of the city to take precautions while an intensive hunt for the attacker continued. Det Supt Eddie Hemsley, leading the investigation, said: "I don't want to alarm people, but I would urge women walking in the area to be extra careful, especially if they are alone or at night."

Victims have ranged from a 17-year-old school-leaver to a woman of 43 who was grabbed round the neck from behind and thrown to the ground. Several of the women fought back and drove the man off, including one who battered him with a tin of food after he threw her into a hedge.

Police believe the man, described by the inquiry team as "a risk taker", is likely to live locally because of his knowledge of escape routes.

fields.headline: Kim Roberts
fields.standfirst: Vocalist Kim Roberts is the latest among a number of comparatively early deaths among entertainers whose recording careers began at producer Joe Meek's RGM studio in London's Holloway Road.
fields.trailText: Vocalist Kim Roberts, who has died, apparently of heart problems, aged 55, is the latest among a number of comparatively early deaths among entertainers whose recording careers began at producer Joe Meek's RGM studio in London's Holloway Road.
fields.body:
Vocalist Kim Roberts, who has died, apparently of heart problems, aged 55, is the latest among a number of comparatively early deaths among entertainers whose recording careers began at producer Joe Meek's RGM studio in London's Holloway Road.

She was born Rosemary Cottman, in Halifax, the only child of professional boxer Tommy Cottnam and his wife Mary, who ran a guest house catering for sport and showbusiness clientele. At school she was active in amateur dramatics, concerts and talent contests; in 1963, she met Heinz, late of the Tornados and by then a solo pop singer. Impressed by Kim he arranged a recording test for her with Joe Meek.

The producer provided her with her stage name and an initial single, Prove It, on which she was backed by the Outlaws - with guitarist Ritchie Blackmore (later of Deep Purple) and bass player Chas Hodges of Chas and Dave. She was featured with its B-side, For Loving Me This Way, in Live It Up (1963), one of those pre-Hard Day's Night British comedy-cum-pop movies. It featured Heinz, Steve Marriott and David Hemmings.

Her living then hinged on ballroom one-nighters. There her path crossed with Screaming Lord Sutch, whose string-pulling got her lucrative German club work. She subsequently taped a dozen tracks at RGM, none of which were released at the time although two came out on the 1997 CD Joe Meek's Girls.

Free of RGM by 1965, Kim returned to Germany, briefly worked and recorded with the Zaras, a Spanish-American family of entertainers, got her own television show in South Africa and toured the Middle East. In 1970 she joined the pop-folk trio the Settlers, and after their sundering in 1973 became a backing singer with Gilbert O' Sullivan. Family commitments led her to quit showbusiness until, with her children no longer babies she resurfaced in the 1980s to front two blues-rock bands, Rusty and the Renegades and later the all-female Limehouse.

During her final decade she worked as a studio session singer, and backed Lord Sutch during his more prestigious engagements. Her final performance was last June, at a concert to mark the first anniversary of Sutch's death.

Her first marriage - by which she had two sons - ended in divorce. Generous, talented and humorous, she was to marry Savages drummer Jack Irving next spring. She is survived by her parents and sons.

Kim Roberts (Rosemary Ann Cottnam), singer, born April 11 1945, died July 22 2000

webTitle: Ministers may ignore human rights rulings

fields.headline: Ministers may ignore human rights rulings
fields.trailText: Ministers may refuse to change some laws which are declared by judges to be incompatible with human rights legislation, the lord chancellor said yesterday.
fields.body:
Ministers may refuse to change some laws which are declared by judges to be incompatible with human rights legislation, the lord chancellor said yesterday.

Judges will have the power from October 2, when the Human Rights Act comes into force, to declare statutes incompatible with the European convention on human rights. They will not be able to strike down a statute, but the act sets up a fast track procedure for parliament to amend it.

But Lord Irvine said: "In some cases, government and parliament could take the view that there was some sort of overriding reason not to change the law to make it compatible."

Lord Irvine was asked at a media briefing on the act what the government would do if judges declared the home secretary's power to determine murderers' release dates incompatible with the convention. He replied: "Decisions of the higher courts should be respected. Some of those decisions will be controversial. The ultimate authority, however, is parliament."

He added: "There would be no obligation on government to bring forward legislation. But I do think in the overwhelming majority of such cases government would want to do so. In such a case the government and parliament would have to decide, not judges."

If the government refused to introduce legislation, it would be up to the aggrieved individual to take the case on to the European court of human rights in Strasbourg.

Lord Irvine predicted that declarations of incompatibility would be rare. In "99.9% of cases", judges would use their power to interpret a statute in such a way as to make it compatible with the convention.

Some commentators argue that the act, the biggest change to British law in 300 years, will shift power from parliament to unelected, unaccountable judges. Others predict that the courts will be clogged with lawyers putting forward specious human rights claims.

Playing down the likely effects of the act, Lord Irvine said: "The heavens are not going to fall as a result of the Human Rights Act. I think the prophets of doom will be proved completely false."

There would be lawyers who argued hopeless points, he said, but judges would resist them. There would be wrong decisions by the lower courts. "But with every piece of legislation there are teething troubles before it settles down."

webTitle: Girl made to push-start rapist's car

fields.headline: Girl made to push-start rapist's car
fields.trailText: A sex attacker who repeatedly raped a schoolgirl later forced her to push his car when it failed to start, police said yesterday.
fields.body:
A sex attacker who repeatedly raped a schoolgirl later forced her to push his car when it failed to start, police said yesterday.

The man subjected the 15-year-old to a "terrible ordeal", police said, after snatching her as she walked through suburban Chingford, east London, early on Saturday morning. The man, in his 20s, forced her into the passenger side of a beige four-door automatic car, possibly an old Citroen. He jumped a red light, nearly hitting a lorry, before heading to a "wooded area with houses opposite" where he attacked the girl.

The girl told police that the man then pushed her back into the front passenger seat. When the car failed to start he lifted the bonnet and hit the engine with an object. Still the car would not start and he told the girl to get out and push. When the car started, he drove to Woodford Green, Essex, where he threw her out at about 8am.

Police believe the attack took place in a wooded area next to Gascoigne Gardens, Chingford. The man they are looking for is white, about six feet tall, of medium build, with brown eyes, dark blond hair parted in the middle "curtain style" and a scar above his left eye. He was wearing a beige polo-style T-shirt with black markings on the collar and a black emblem on the left breast, dark blue zip-up jeans and black shoes with a silver buckle. Officers hope to trace a woman in her mid-20s whom the girl saw walking a grey dog through the wooded area where she was raped. Detective Inspector Stuart Wratten, heading the inquiry, said: "This poor girl was subjected to a terrible ordeal and it is vital that we catch this man as quickly as possible."

Anyone with information should call the CID office at Chingford police station on 020 8345 3156 or Crimestoppers on 0800 555 111.

webTitle: Judge asks for help in finding boys

fields.headline: Judge asks for help in finding boys
fields.trailText: A high court judge has appealed to the public to help find two boys who were snatched while playing in the street.
fields.body:
A high court judge has appealed to the public to help find two boys who were snatched while playing in the street.

Mrs Justice Hogg, a family division judge, said she was "gravely concerned" about the safety of Joe Lillington, nine, and his brother Louis, eight.

The boys had been living with their aunt in Bow, east London, since being taken into police protection after their mother, Toni Lillington, 30, a heroin addict, attempted suicide in July last year.

The children were taken on August 29.They were seen being put in a yellow Ford Fiesta by a man and a youth.

The aunt, Helen Goody, 49, and her twin brother, John, the boys' father, told the judge of their fears that the brothers might be back with their mother; their alternative fear was that the two might have been abducted by paedophiles. Mrs Justice Hogg lifted reporting restrictions and said : "I have grave concern for these children."

webTitle: Trident protesters may face retrial after non-verdict

fields.headline: Trident protesters may face retrial after non-verdict
fields.trailText: Two protesters who swam 150 metres in wetsuits to a Trident submarine and smashed testing equipment with a lump hammer could face a retrial for criminal damage, after a   jury at Manchester crown court failed to reach a verdict yesterday and was discharged.
fields.body:
Two protesters who swam 150 metres in wetsuits to a Trident submarine and smashed testing equipment with a lump hammer could face a retrial for criminal damage, after a jury at Manchester crown court failed to reach a verdict yesterday and was discharged.

Rachel Wenham, 28, from Leeds, and Rosie James, 25, from London, were earlier found not guilty of criminal damage for spray painting slogans on the side of HMS Vengeance when it was berthed at Barrow-in-Furness, Cumbria, in February last year.

But after more than six hours of deliberation, the jury said it could not reach a majority verdict on another charge of criminal damage for smashing equipment valued at thousands of pounds.

During the trial, the women, from the nuclear disarmament group Trident Ploughshares, admitted attacking the submarine. But they pleaded not guilty, arguing that they were acting to prevent a crime because Britain's Trident fleet posed a threat to residents of Barrow-in-Furness and the surrounding area. They claimed their actions were justified under international law.

Under cover of darkness, the women swam through Barrow dock and spray-painted the words "Death Machine" and "Illegal" on the side of the submarine, which was designed to carry a quarter of Britain's nuclear arsenal. They hung a banner saying "women want peace" from the conning tower and smashed testing equipment with a lump hammer they had dragged with them.

The crown prosecution service is expected to reach a decision on a retrial by the end of the week, but the prosecuting counsel, Dennis Watson, told judge Gerard Humphries that it was likely one would be sought.

A spokeswoman for Trident Ploughshares Aldermaston women's affinity group said: "Our case clearly caused a serious dilemma for the jury and it shows that instinctive morality is alive and well.

"If there is a retrial we believe it will be a complete waste of public money to add to the £1.5bn already being spent this year on the Trident system."
